questions.text: A 74-year-old man presents to the emergency department with discharge from an ulcer on the left foot. He has had the ulcer for nearly a year. However, the ulcer started giving off copious white discharge over the past few days. There has also been some pain and increasing redness around the area. Past medical history is significant for poorly-controlled type II diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin and insulin. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), blood pressure is 117/84 mmHg, pulse is 87/min, and respiratory rate is 12/min. Physical examination reveals a well-demarcated ulcer with a tender erythematous border and a sizeable purulent discharge on the left foot. Foot radiography does not show evidence of osteomyelitis. Wound cultures grow methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. Blood cultures are negative. He is started on vancomycin and linezolid but fails to show improvement. He is subsequently started on tigecycline. What is the most likely adverse effect this patient will experience with tigecycline?
questions.solution:
Tigecycline antibiotics are tetracycline derivatives developed to overcome traditional tetracycline resistance. Tigecycline can treat multidrug-resistant bacteria such as methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. It binds to the 30S bacterial ribosomal subunit to inhibit protein synthesis.

Its side effects are similar to tetracycline antibiotics and include nausea and vomiting, headache, photosensitivity, and tooth discoloration. Moreover, there has been an increased risk of death associated with tigecycline use. As a result, it should only be used when there are no alternative treatments.  

Option Analysis

✅ Nausea and vomiting:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Peripheral motor neuropathy:
Incorrect: This adverse effect can be seen with dapsone therapy. This antibiotic inhibits dihydropteroate synthase and is used to treat leprosy and Pneumocystis jiroveci prophylaxis.  
❌ Orange discoloration of urine:
Incorrect: This adverse effect can be seen with rifampin therapy. The drug inhibits DNA-dependent RNA polymerase and is used for tuberculosis and leprosy treatment.  
❌ Vitamin B6 deficiency:
Incorrect: Vitamin B6 deficiency is a significant adverse effect caused by isoniazid. The drug inhibits the synthesis of mycolic acids and is used to treat tuberculosis. Isoniazid should be administered with pyridoxine (vitamin B6) to prevent peripheral neuropathy and sideroblastic anemia.  
❌ Disulfiram-like reaction:
Incorrect: This side effect is most commonly seen with drugs such as metronidazole, griseofulvin, sulfonylureas, procarbazine, and certain cephalosporins are taken with alcohol. A disulfiram-like reaction can present with severe flushing, tachycardia, and hypotension.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of recurrent boils and skin infections. The patient has had 3 skin infections in the past 5 months that were treated with antibiotics. Anterior nare culture is performed, which yields gram-positive cocci in clusters. These bacteria are able to grow in a medium containing oxacillin. Which of the following is the most appropriate antibiotic for the treatment of this patient’s infection?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with recurrent boils and skin infections due to methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). Methicillin-resistant strains are able to grow in the presence of oxacillin due to a mutation in the gene that encodes for penicillin-binding proteins. Among the cephalosporins, only ceftaroline is effective against MRSA.

Ceftaroline is a fifth generation cephalosporin that differs from the other cephalosporins due to its activity against MRSA, which is resistant to all other β-lactams. Ceftaroline’s Gram-negative activity is similar to that of the third-generation cephalosporins but does not include coverage of Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Ceftaroline may be used in community-acquired pneumonia and skin infections.

In contrast, the fourth-generation cephalosporin cefepime is a broad-coverage agent with potent activity against both Gram-negative bacilli (including P. aeruginosa) and Gram-positive cocci. The fourth-generation cephalosporins have clinical uses similar to that of the third-generation drugs, but are more resistant to beta-lactamases. However, they do not provide coverage against MRSA. Fourth-generation cephalosporins can be used in bacteremia, febrile neutropenia, as well as intra-abdominal and urinary tract infections.  

Option Analysis

❌ Cephalexin:
Incorrect: Cephalexin is a first-generation cephalosporin effective against Gram-positive cocci, Proteus mirabilis, Eschereria coli, and Klebsiella pneumoniae. It can be used for surgical prophylaxis and for the treatment of urinary tract infections as well as minor skin and soft tissue infections. However, cephalexin does not provide coverage against methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus.  
❌ Cefoxitin:
Incorrect: Cefoxitin is a second-generation cephalosporin that has extended Gram-negative coverage. It can treat infections caused by Haemophilus influenzae, Serratia marcescens, and Enterobacter aerogenes. However, cefoxitin does not provide coverage against methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus.  
❌ Ceftriaxone:
Incorrect: Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin with improved activity against Gram-negative bacteria but reduced activity against Gram-positive bacteria. Ceftriaxone is most commonly used to treat infections caused by Haemophilus influenzae, Pneumococci, Meningococci, and Neisseria species. However, it does not provide coverage against methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus.  
❌ Cefepime:
Incorrect: Cefepime is a fourth-generation cephalosporin with potent Gram-positive and Gram-negative coverage. It is also effective against Pseudomonas aeruginosa and crosses the blood-brain barrier. However, cefepime is ineffective against methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus, which is the cause of this patient’s cutaneous symptoms.  
✅ Ceftaroline:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for an intensely itchy rash on her bilateral hands, wrists, and feet. The rash has been present for six days and the itching is worse at night. She has not experienced malaise, fever, chills, or sweats. The patient has a history of schizophrenia with sporadic use of her prescribed medications and has been experiencing homelessness, recently residing in shelters. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, respiratory rate is 20/min and blood pressure is 142/82 mmHg. On examination, she appears agitated, frequently scratching her hands and feet. Ears, eyes, nose, and throat examinations are within normal limits other than poor dentition. Cardiopulmonary exam is unremarkable. The skin rash, as pictured below, is seen on the bilateral hands, wrists, and feet.  Excoriations are noted near the lesions on the feet. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her presentation? 



Image is licensed under Public Domain, reproduced from WikiCommons
questions.solution:
This patient’s intensely itchy rash, composed of fine papules with areas of burrowing over the hands, wrists, and feet, is classic for scabies. Scabies is a contagious skin infection caused by mites that are most commonly seen in individuals with inadequate hygiene or poor nutritional status and in those with crowded living conditions. The pruritis is often worse at night and excoriations may be seen surrounding the lesions.        

The diagnosis of most skin rashes is clinical; therefore, a thorough history and physical examination is key. Important historical features to discuss are whether the rash is itchy or painful, the duration of the rash, associated symptoms including fever, malaise, weight loss, and joint pain, the patient’s demographics (pregnancy status, age, living situation), and any associated medical conditions such as an immunocompromised state. Features of the physical examination that will help guide the differential include the rash location, rash distribution (local vs widespread), rash description (macular, papular, vesicular), presence or absence of erythema and whether it blanches, tenderness of the lesions and surrounding skin, and any associated findings such as joint swelling, fever, or neurologic changes. Based on the features of the history and physical examination, the diagnosis can generally be narrowed down to one of three categories: adverse medication reaction, infectious etiology, or inflammatory/autoimmune etiology, which will guide the need for additional workup. And treatment.    

Option Analysis

✅ Mites:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Fungal infection:
Incorrect: Fungal infection of the skin commonly presents as single or multiple patches of erythema with sharply demarcated, scaley borders, as seen in tinea corporis. The pictured erythematous papules with areas of skin burrowing are more consistent with scabies which are caused by mites.  
❌ Bacterial infection:
Incorrect: Common bacterial infections of the skin include folliculitis, which presents as papules or pustules over hair-covered areas; impetigo, characterized by honey-crusted lesions; cellulitis, presenting as a focal area of swollen, erythematous, warm skin; and abscesses, which manifest as a focal area of fluctuance, or induration covered by erythematous, warm skin. This patient’s history and examination findings are more consistent with scabies. 
❌ Viral infection:
Incorrect: Common viral infections of the skin include herpes simplex, viral warts, human immunodeficiency virus, and various childhood illnesses such as chickenpox, and hand, foot, and mouth disease. This patient’s rash location and pattern, age, and risk factors are most suggestive of scabies. 
❌  Immune-mediated process:
Incorrect: Common immune-mediated processes that can result in skin rash include atopic dermatitis, contact dermatitis, seborrheic dermatitis, acne vulgaris, rosacea, and psoriasis. These conditions often present with erythema, itching, and specific types of lesions such as vesicles, papules, or plaques. This patient’s rash location and pattern, age, and risk factors are most suggestive of scabies.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man comes to the office due to severe irritation of the left foot, which has been ongoing for the past 2 days. The patient went to the beach 5 days ago for a barbeque lunch with friends. The patient has not had a cough, fever, or gastrointestinal symptoms. The patient lives with his partner and 2 children, who are healthy and have not experienced similar symptoms. Past medical history is unremarkable. Family history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus in the patient’s mother. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals the findings below. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with intensely pruritic, serpiginous, reddish-brown tracks on the sole of foot after a likely exposure to contaminated sand. These findings are consistent with cutaneous larva migrans, which is caused by a species of hookworm called Ancylostoma duodenale. Ivermectin is the treatment of choice for this patient.  

Ivermectin interferes with the nervous system of invertebrates by binding to glutamate-gated chloride channels on neurons and muscle cells. The medication causes the channels to open permanently, leading to a rapid influx of chloride ions, which hyperpolarizes the cells. Hyperpolarized neurons cannot fire off action potentials and hyperpolarized muscles cannot contract. As a result, the parasites become paralyzed and die.  

Ivermectin can be used for the treatment of onchocerciasis (ocular lesions and dermatitis), strongyloidiasis (urticaria, abdominal pain, respiratory problems), cutaneous larva migrans, and scabies. Side effects of ivermectin include headache, dizziness, muscle pains, nausea, and diarrhea.  



Option Analysis

❌ Topical permethrin:
Incorrect: Permethrin is the first-line treatment for scabies, which present as intense pruritus that is associated with papules and burrows. In contrast, this patient presents with intensely pruritic, serpiginous, reddish-brown tracks on the sole of the foot after a likely exposure to contaminated sand. These findings are more suggestive of infection by the helminth Ancylostoma duodenale. Permethrin is ineffective against helminths.   
✅ Oral ivermectin  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Topical glucocorticoid:
Incorrect: Topical glucocorticoids are the treatment of choice for psoriasis, which presents with symmetric, sharply defined skin plaques with overlying scales on the knees, elbows, and scalp. In contrast, this patient most likely has a parasitic infection.  
❌ Oral terbinafine:
Incorrect: Oral terbinafine can be used to treat dermatophyte skin infections that usually present with erythema and skin erosions. In contrast, this patient most likely has a parasitic infection.  
❌ Oral acyclovir:
Incorrect: Oral acyclovir is the treatment of choice in herpes simplex virus infections, such as herpes labialis, which is unlikely in this patient with intense pruritus on the sole of the foot.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man comes to his physician’s office to evaluate a lower extremity rash. The patient visited several months ago to evaluate mild trembling of his hands and a slow, shuffling gait. The physician started the patient on an anti-Parkinsonian medication at the time. The patient states that his tremors have improved, but he noticed a rash on his lower legs several weeks after starting the medication. The rash is not itchy or painful. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a widespread, patchy rash on the lower legs as shown in the image below. Which of the following medications is the most likely the cause of this patient’s current skin condition?


Reproduced from: Store Norske Leksikon
questions.solution:
This patient, who has signs and symptoms of Parkinson disease, was recently initiated on an anti-Parkinson medication and is now presenting with bilateral lower extremity rashes. The reticular, lacy nature suggests livedo reticularis, likely caused by recent amantadine use.    

Amantadine is an antiviral medication that was found to have antiparkinsonian activity. Studies have demonstrated that amantadine acts on dopaminergic neurons as a weak, non-competitive antagonist of the NMDA receptor, where it increases dopamine release and prevents dopamine reuptake. The primary clinical use of amantadine includes treatment of early PD, although it can be used as adjunctive treatment with levodopa.  

Central side effects associated with amantadine include confusion, hallucinations, insomnia, and nightmares. These are more common in older patients but can occur in patients of any age. Peripheral side effects include livedo reticularis and ankle edema; however, these side effects are typically benign and not treatment-limiting. The mechanism of amantadine-induced livedo reticularis is thought to occur secondary to altered catecholamine metabolism, which induces vasoconstriction in the dermal arterioles and limits flow to the capillary skin surface.  

Option Analysis

✅ Amantadine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Selegiline:
Incorrect: Selegiline, an MAO-B inhibitor, is often used in patients <65 years of age with mild Parkinson symptoms. A major side effect of MAO-B inhibitors includes drug interactions. Although interactions with SSRIs or SNRIs are rare, these two classes of medications should be used with caution due to the risk of precipitating serotonin syndrome. Other side effects of MAO-B inhibitors include CNS depression, dyskinesias, and hypertension.  
❌ Levodopa:
Incorrect: Levodopa is a common medication used in the treatment of Parkinson disease. Typical side effects include nausea and vomiting. This patient presents with evidence of livedo reticularis, which is likely caused by a different medication. 
❌ Trihexyphenidyl:
Incorrect: Trihexyphenidyl, an anticholinergic, can be used as an adjunctive treatment for tremors. Anticholinergics have an extensive adverse effect profile, especially among elderly patients. These side effects include memory impairment, confusion, and hallucinations. 
❌ Pramipexole:
Incorrect: Pramipexole, a dopamine agonist, can be used in the treatment of Parkinson disease. Adverse effects include somnolence and impulse control disorders (e.g., gambling, hypersexuality).

questions.text: A 47-year-old man presents to the clinic for evaluation of a new black scab on his right arm. He initially thought it was a bug bite since it was itchy and red. However, one day later, he noticed that the area had developed an ulceration and was swollen. Several days later, the lesion had turned into a black scab. The patient works as a sheep farmer. On physical examination, there is a black eschar surrounding light red erythema on the right arm. A skin biopsy is performed, and there is suspicion of cutaneous anthrax. The patient is started on a 60-day course of ciprofloxacin. What of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this antibiotic?

choices.text: Binding of D-ala D-ala in cell wall precursors
Inhibition of the 30S subunit of the bacterial ribosome
Blockade of translocation at the 50S ribosomal subunit

questions.solution:
This patient most likely has cutaneous anthrax caused by the Gram-positive rod Bacillus anthracis. As a result, he was started on a 60-day course of ciprofloxacin, a fluoroquinolone.  

The fluoroquinolone class of antibiotics includes ciprofloxacin, norfloxacin, and ofloxacin. Levofloxacin, moxifloxacin, and gemifloxacin are known as respiratory fluoroquinolones since they have activity against respiratory pathogens.    

Fluoroquinolones are bactericidal antibiotics that inhibit prokaryotic topoisomerase II (DNA gyrase) and topoisomerase IV. They are used in treating infections by Gram-negative rods in the urinary and gastrointestinal tracts, Pseudomonas, and some Gram-positive bacteria.  

Fluoroquinolones are associated with several adverse effects, including gastrointestinal upset, rashes, headache, and dizziness. They can also cause cartilage damage. As a result, fluoroquinolones are contraindicated for use in pregnant women, nursing mothers, and children under 18 years old. Moreover, fluoroquinolones can cause tendon rupture and tendonitis, particularly in individuals over 60 years old or those concurrently taking prednisone. Finally, fluoroquinolones can cause QT prolongation. 

Option Analysis

❌ Binding of D-ala D-ala in cell wall precursors:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of vancomycin. Vancomycin is a bactericidal agent effective in treating serious multidrug-resistant infections caused by Gram-positive bacteria. Vancomycin is associated with nephrotoxicity, ototoxicity, thrombophlebitis, red man syndrome, and DRESS syndrome. 
❌ Inhibition of the 30S subunit of the bacterial ribosome:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of tetracyclines. They are used to treat infections caused by organisms such as Borrelia burgdorferi, Mycoplasma pneumoniae, Chlamydia species, and methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. The most common adverse effects include gastrointestinal distress, photosensitivity, tinnitus, and hepatotoxicity.
❌ Blockade of translocation at the 50S ribosomal subunit:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of clindamycin. It is a bacteriostatic antibiotic that treats anaerobic infections, such as those caused by Bacteroides species and Clostridium perfringens. Clinically, it can treat lung abscesses, aspiration pneumonia, and pseudomembranous colitis. 
❌ Inhibition of dihydropteroate synthase :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of sulfonamides (e.g., sulfamethoxazole, sulfisoxazole, sulfadiazine), which prevent folate synthesis. In contrast, fluoroquinolones work via a different mechanism of action. 
✅ Inhibition of DNA gyrase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy presents to the emergency department for evaluation of right middle finger pain. Several days ago, the patient noticed small fluid-filled sacs in the right middle finger, which progressed into painful lesions yesterday. His mother, who is accompanying him, states, “He has got a finger infection from chewing on his nails all day.” The patient is otherwise healthy and takes only a multivitamin daily. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 115/73 mmHg, and pulse is 78/min. Physical examination is notable for the following finding:


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
The patient has multiple vesicular lesions on his finger, which is concerning for herpetic whitlow, or herpes simplex infection of the finger. Herpetic whitlow occurs frequently in patients with recurrent nail biting, children who suck their fingers, and those who work in healthcare or dentistry. This condition is best treated with oral acyclovir.

Herpes simplex virus (HSV) is a double stranded-DNA virus that causes a characteristic pattern of skin involvement. Patients develop clear vesicles that overtime merge, become cloudy, and eventually burst leaving behind painful ulcerations. In general, HSV-1 is the viral strain implicated in herpes labialis (cold sores), herpetic whitlow, and erythema multiforme, whereas HSV-2 is more commonly implicated in herpes genitalis. Transmission typically occurs via oral-oral, oral-genital, or genital-genital contact. However, it can also occur via contamination of skin abrasions with infected oral secretions.

Regardless of the viral strain involved, recurrent dermatologic lesions are commonplace due to the virus’s ability to lie dormant in the dorsal root ganglion. During acute infection, the virus is able to enter sensory nerve endings and travel via retrograde transport to the dorsal root ganglion. During episodes of reactivation, the virus replicates and travels via anterograde axonal transport to epithelial cells, thus causing recurrent symptoms.

Option Analysis

✅ Acyclovir:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Cephalexin:
Incorrect: Cephalexin is a second generation cephalosporin used for a variety of treatments including skin and soft tissue infections, urinary tract infections, and pharyngitis. However, cephalexin lacks antiviral properties and is not used in the treatment of herpetic whitlow.
❌ Ganciclovir:
Incorrect: Ganciclovir is used in the treatment of cytomegalovirus infection, but not herpes simplex viral infections.
❌ Needle aspiration:
Incorrect: This patient has multiple vesicular rashes on his finger, which is concerning for herpetic whitlow. Needle aspiration, along with incision and drainage, are inappropriate for the treatment of herpetic whitlow. These interventions may actually result in disseminated HSV.
❌ Incision and drainage:
Incorrect: Simple incision and drainage is performed for skin abscesses or paronychia but not for herpetic whitlow. Incision and drainage can actually increase the risk of disseminated HSV.

questions.text: An 11-month-old girl was brought to the emergency department by her parents for the evaluation of high fever and a rash. The rash first appeared on her face last night and has now spread over her entire body. Prior to the onset of the rash, the patient had intermittent cough and runny nose. She did not receive any vaccinations since birth due to parental preference. The rest of the history is noncontributory. Temperature is 38.8°C (102°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 27/min and blood pressure is 90/55 mmHg. Physical examination shows an irritable and restless child with a diffuse erythematous maculopapular rash all over the body sparing the palms and soles bilaterally. Oral examination shows tiny, white round lesions on the buccal mucosa. Administration of which of the following is associated with decreased morbidity and mortality in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with measles (rubeola), which is characterized by a prodromal illness of fever, cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis followed by Koplik spots and a maculopapular rash that spreads in a cephalocaudal progression (sparing the palms and soles). Administration of vitamin A to children with measles is associated with decreased morbidity and mortality.  

Vitamin A acts as an immunomodulator that boosts the antibody response to measles. The WHO recommends vitamin A to be administered to all children with acute measles. It has shown to prevent complications associated with measles (e.g., pneumonia, keratitis, etc.) and reduce the recovery time and hospital stay.  

There is no specific antiviral treatment for measles. Instead, the medications are generally aimed at treating superinfections, maintaining good hydration with adequate fluids, and pain relief. In an outbreak setting, the measles vaccine can be given to household contacts, and measles immunoglobulin can be given to pregnant women and young infants to help prevent others from getting sick. 

Option Analysis

❌ Folic acid:
Incorrect: Folic acid plays an important role in the production of erythrocytes and helps in the development of the neural tube into the brain and spinal cord. It is shown to decrease the risk of neural tube defects in newborns. It has no proven benefit in the treatment of measles.
✅ Vitamin A:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Corticosteroids:
Incorrect: In the active phase of viremia, use of steroids will suppress the immunological response, which may worsen the disease course. There is no evidence of the role of steroids in the prevention of morbidity and mortality associated with measles.
❌ Live-attenuated measles, mumps, rubella vaccine:
Incorrect: Although administration of live-attenuated measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccine is important for the prevention of these infections, it is not indicated in patients in the active phase of viremia.
❌ Airborne precautions:
Incorrect: Airborne precautions are indicated for four days after the onset of rash in otherwise healthy patients infected with measles. This measure is important to prevent the spread of infection to susceptible individuals. However, it does not help reduce morbidity and mortality associated with measles in the affected individual.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy living in Ohio presents to the office for a sore throat and rash for five days. The rash started on the neck and then spread to the arms and chest. There is no history of joint pain, headache, or cough. There has been no recent travel or exposure to sick contacts. Past medical, family, and surgical histories are non-contributory. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 119/min, respirations are 26/min, blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical exam, there is evidence of exudative pharyngitis, circumoral pallor with a strawberry tongue, and cervical lymphadenopathy. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are unremarkable. Which of the following best describes the type of rash that would be expected in this patient?

choices.text: Erythematous target lesions with a dusky center

questions.solution:
Scarlet fever rash and white strawberry tongue by Estreya and Azizova. Licensed under CC BY 2.5 and CC BY-SA 3.0 respectively.         

Reproduced from Wikipedia and Wikipedia respectively.        

This patient presenting with fever, rash, sore throat, and physical exam findings of exudative pharyngitis, circumoral pallor, strawberry tongue, and cervical lymphadenopathy most likely has scarlet fever. The rash seen with scarlet fever is described as a sandpaper-like rash.   

Scarlet fever is caused by group A streptococcus (GAS) exotoxins, most commonly in association with GAS pharyngitis. Affected patients are typically school-aged and present with fever, sore throat, headache, and often abdominal pain. Patients with scarlet fever will have generalized diffuse erythema with a fine papular “sandpaper” textured rash that typically starts in the groin or armpits and then spreads to the trunk and then the extremities. Other findings of scarlet fever include circumoral pallor, strawberry tongue, and cervical lymphadenopathy. Pastia lines, which are linear accentuation of erythema in flexor surfaces, may also be seen. A positive rapid strep test or throat culture growing GAS confirms the diagnosis of scarlet fever.       

Fever and rash are common manifestations of bacterial infections in children. History may reveal a sick contact or recent travel. Evaluation of rash morphology can often help determine the underlying cause. Maculopapular or macular rashes with annular lesions are associated with erythema multiforme and Lyme disease. Rose spots are seen with typhoid fever. Plaques can be seen with erysipelas, while diffuse papular erythema and a sandpaper-like rash are suggestive of scarlet fever. Fluid-filled lesions such as vesicles, bullae, and pustules can be caused by impetigo, staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome, or rickettsial pox. Petechial or purpuric rashes are seen with Rocky Mountain spotted fever.  

Option Analysis

❌ Erythematous bull’s eye lesion :
Incorrect: Erythema migrans, which is seen in patients with Lyme disease, presents as an erythematous bull’s eye lesion. This patient does not live in an area endemic to Lyme disease, and he has exudative pharyngitis, strawberry tongue, cervical lymphadenopathy, and a skin rash; the most likely diagnosis is scarlet fever, which causes a sandpaper-like rash. 
❌ Erythematous target lesions with a dusky center :
Incorrect: Lesions from erythema multiforme (EM) appear as erythematous target lesions with a dusky center. The findings in this patient are more consistent with scarlet fever, which causes a sandpaper-like rash. 
✅ Sandpaper-like erythematous blanching rash :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Bullous lesions :
Incorrect: Bullous lesions are often seen with infections with Staphylococcus aureus or with autoimmune disease. The history and physical exam findings in this patient are more consistent with scarlet fever due to Streptococcus pyogenes, which causes a sandpaper-like rash.  
❌ Faint salmon-colored macules  :
Incorrect: Rose spots appear as faint salmon-colored macules. They are seen in patients with typhoid fever who typically present with vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and history of recent travel. The history and physical exam findings in this patient are more consistent with scarlet fever, which causes a sandpaper-like rash.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy is brought to the office by his parents for the evaluation of a rash. The rash appeared on his trunk a few days ago and has gradually increased in size. The rash is slightly itchy but not painful. The family visited Vermont for camping two weeks ago and spent most of the time outdoors. Past medical and family history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination findings are shown. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?


Reproduced fromWikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient who recently visited a Lyme-endemic area has developed an annular (bull’s eye) rash, most likely has early localized Lyme disease. This patient should be treated with oral amoxicillin, which is a broad-spectrum penicillin.    

The mechanism of action of broad-spectrum penicillin (e.g., amoxicillin, ampicillin) is the same as that of penicillin (i.e., it blocks transpeptidase cross-linking of peptidoglycan in the cell wall). They have a wider spectrum of antibacterial activity than penicillin G but remain susceptible to penicillinases. Their clinical uses include indications similar to penicillin G as well as infections resulting from enterococci, Listeria monocytogenes, Escherichia coli, Proteus mirabilis, Haemophilus influenzae, and Moraxella catarrhalis. When used in combination with inhibitors of penicillinases (e.g. clavulanic acid), their antibacterial activity is often enhanced. In enterococcal and listeria infections, ampicillin is synergistic with aminoglycosides.  

This class is categorized as pregnancy category B, meaning no risks have been found for use during pregnancy.  



Option Analysis

❌ Biopsy of the rash:
Incorrect: Biopsy of a rash should be done when the lesion does not resolve with initial treatment or malignancy is suspected. This patient’s bull’s eye rash is suggestive of erythema migrans, an early Lyme disease manifestation.
❌ Observation only:
Incorrect: For patients who present with a single erythema migrans (EM) lesion, treatment with oral therapy is necessary to reduce the duration of symptoms and prevent progression to later stages of Lyme disease.
❌ Start oral fluconazole:
Incorrect: Oral fluconazole can be used in the management of tinea corporis, which usually present with annular-shaped scaly lesions with raised borders. This patient’s bull’s eye rash is suggestive of erythema migrans, an early Lyme disease manifestation
✅ Start oral amoxicillin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Obtain Borrelia burgdorferi serology:
Incorrect: Borrelia burgdorferi serology is usually negative in the early stages of Lyme disease and is not required before starting the treatment

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of a progressive skin rash and pain. The patient’s mother first noticed the rash around the neck folds and axillae two days ago while giving him a bath. The rash has worsened since then, involving the whole body. The patient is not eating well and has been irritable for the past two days. The rest of the systemic review is unremarkable. Temperature is 38.8°C (102°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 20/min and blood pressure is 100/65 mmHg. Physical examination shows diffuse erythema and desquamation that is most prominent in the neck, axilla, and gluteal folds. The perioral area has crusting and the lips are dry and cracked. The mucous membranes are normal. When gentle pressure is applied at the erythematous area, the epidermis easily comes off. The patient is admitted and started on intravenous fluids and antibiotics. Which of the following is an example of the drug most suitable for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s fever and desquamating rash is consistent with Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS), caused by exotoxin-producing strains of Staphylococcus aureus.   

Intravenous treatment with an antistaphylococcal antibiotic should begin promptly. Patients are typically initially treated with penicillinase-resistant penicillin (very narrow spectrum), such as oxacillin or nafcillin. These medications were created to fight bacteria like S. aureus and S. epidermidis, which often had the beta-lactamase enzyme. These antibiotics are resistant to beta-lactamase enzymes due to a bulky R-group that blocks access of β-lactamase to β-lactam rings.   

Other examples include methicillin, cloxacillin, and dicloxacillin. These antibiotics worked well initially, until some S. aureus developed the penicillin-binding protein (PBP) site mutations and became methicillin-resistant (MR) staphylococci (MRSA).  

Option Analysis

❌ Piperacillin:
Incorrect:  Piperacillin is an antipseudomonal penicillin that has activity against several Gram-negative rods, including Pseudomonas, Enterobacter, and in some cases Klebsiella species. It is not effective in the management of staphylococcal skin infections.
❌ Clindamycin:
Incorrect: Clindamycin has antistaphylococcal activity but is not recommended as a primary treatment because of high rates of clindamycin resistance in Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS).
✅ Nafcillin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Amoxicillin:
Incorrect: Amoxicillin is a penicillinase-sensitive penicillin and is effective against H. influenzae, H. pylori, E. coli, Listeria monocytogenes, Proteus mirabilis, Salmonella, Shigella, and enterococci. It is not indicated in the management of SSSS.
❌ Penicillin G:
Incorrect: Penicillin G is the first-line medication for the treatment of streptococcal pharyngitis and prophylaxis against acute rheumatic fever (ARF) in these patients. Moreover, they are also effective against infections caused by other organisms like S. pneumoniae, N. meningitidis, and spirochetes. It is, however, not effective against Staphylococcus aureus due to its penicillinase sensitivity.

questions.text: A 9-month-old boy is brought to the pediatrician for a new-onset rash. His parents report that he had a 3-day history of fever up to 40°C (104°F). The fever broke 24 hours ago, and this morning, the patient woke up with the rash. It does not appear to be painful or pruritic. The parents report no new exposures such as new soaps, lotions, or detergents. There have been no known contacts with a similar rash. The patient has a very mild runny nose but no other symptoms of an upper respiratory infection. He was seen in the office 2 days ago for the fever and was diagnosed with a viral illness at that time. The parents report he is eating and drinking well, with good urine output. Since the fever subsided, the patient has been active and playful. He was born full-term, and there is no significant past medical history. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 128/min, respirations are 32/min, blood pressure is 85/50 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is alert and happy. The anterior fontanelle is open and flat. There is mild rhinorrhea. The oral mucosa and oropharynx are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary examinations are normal. Given the most likely etiology for the rash, which of the following would best describe the likely rash?

choices.text: Erythematous maculopapular rash that started on the trunk and spread to neck and extremities
Erythematous maculopapular rash that started at the head and spread caudally
Erythematous vesicular rash on the distal aspects of arms and legs, including palms and soles
Diffuse vesicles on an erythematous base in various stages of healing
Erythematous malar rash with circumoral pallor and a reticulated rash on the extremities

questions.solution:
This patient presents to the pediatrician for a new-onset rash following 3-days of a high fever in the setting of mild rhinorrhea. The timing and progression of the fever and rash are consistent with roseola infantum. The characteristic rash in roseola infantum is an erythematous maculopapular rash that starts on the trunk and then spreads to the neck and extremities.

Once it is determined that a patient has a viral exanthem, the rash morphology should be assessed to help determine the likely underlying virus. In most cases, the diagnosis can be made clinically. Viral exanthems can be categorized as maculopapular, reticular, papular, and vesicular. Maculopapular rashes can be caused by measles, rubella, roseola, Epstein-Barr virus, and human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). The timing of the rash eruption, distribution, and spread can further help determine the etiology. For instance, the rash of roseola erupts once the fever breaks, starts on the trunk, and then spreads to the extremities. The measles rash, on the other hand, starts 2-4 days after the onset of fever, starts on the face, and spreads cephalocaudally. 

Erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease, features a reticulated rash that presents on the extremities, often accompanied by distinctive “slapped cheeks.” Gianotti-Crosti syndrome is a papular rash with lesions on the extensor surfaces of the extremities. Varicella and coxsackievirus are examples of vesicular rashes. Varicella presents as vesicles on an erythematous base in various stages of healing, whereas coxsackievirus causes a vesicular rash on the hands, feet, and/or buttocks.   

Option Analysis

✅ Erythematous maculopapular rash that started on the trunk and spread to neck and extremities:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Erythematous maculopapular rash that started at the head and spread caudally :
Incorrect: The history of several days of high fever followed by the eruption of a rash after the fever broke is consistent with roseola, which is characterized by an erythematous maculopapular rash that starts on the trunk and spreads to the neck and extremities. An erythematous maculopapular rash that starts at the head and spreads caudally is consistent with measles. However, this patient has none of the associated “3 C’s” (cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis) and a rosealaorash is more likely to be seen. 
❌ Erythematous vesicular rash on the distal aspects of arms and legs, including palms and soles :
Incorrect: The history of several days of high fever followed by the eruption of a rash after the fever broke is consistent with roseola, which is characterized by an erythematous maculopapular rash that starts on the trunk and subsequently spreads to the neck and extremities. An erythematous vesicular rash on the distal aspects of arms and legs, including palms and soles, is consistent with hand, foot, and mouth disease. However, this patient has no mouth or throat pain or lesions. 
❌ Diffuse vesicles on an erythematous base in various stages of healing:
Incorrect: The history of several days of high fever followed by the eruption of a rash after the fever breaks is consistent with roseola, which is characterized by an erythematous maculopapular rash that starts on the trunk and subsequently spreads to the neck and extremities. Diffuse vesicles on an erythematous base in various stages of healing are consistent with varicella, which is typically pruritic. 
❌ Erythematous malar rash with circumoral pallor and a reticulated rash on the extremities :
Incorrect: The history of several days of high fever followed by the eruption of a rash after the fever breaks is consistent with roseola, which is characterized by an erythematous maculopapular rash that starts on the trunk and subsequently spreads to the neck and extremities. An erythematous malar rash with circumoral pallor and a reticulated rash on the extremities is consistent with parvovirus B19, which would typically present with prodromal symptoms of coryza, headache, nausea, and diarrhea.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl presents to the immediate care office with her parent for evaluation of a rash on her right arm. The parent states that the rash has been present for the past 1-2 days. The patient has not had any constitutional symptoms, such as fevers or chills. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any daily medication. Vaccinations are up-to-date, and the patient has not had any recent sick contacts. The parent has a history of lupus. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 105/71 mm Hg, pulse is 90/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. The patient is well-appearing and in no acute distress. Skin examination demonstrates vesicles on an erythematous base on the right forearm. Nikolsky sign is negative. There is no mucous membrane involvement. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. Which of the following tests will confirm the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a rash that is consistent with early impetigo. Early infection can be difficult to distinguish from other diseases until the lesions rupture and form the characteristic honey-crusted lesions. Most cases of impetigo can be diagnosed clinically, but when diagnostic uncertainty exists, diagnosis can be made by obtaining a bacterial culture of the lesion. This will typically grow out Staphylococcus or Streptococcus species, confirming the diagnosis.        

Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS) and impetigo are common pediatric skin infections that are most often caused by Staphylococcus aureus. While impetigo usually results from direct bacterial invasion of the skin or minor skin trauma, SSSS is caused by hematogenous spread of staphylococcal exotoxins from colonized areas to distal sites.        
Typically, these conditions can be diagnosed clinically based on skin examination findings and history. However, when diagnostic uncertainty exists, further workups should be pursued. For patients with impetigo, a gram stain and culture of the lesions is typically sufficient to make the diagnosis. Patients with SSSS may require a skin biopsy, which will typically reveal a detached superficial epidermis. Due to the underlying pathophysiology of SSSS, bacterial culture of skin lesions in SSS will be negative.    

Option Analysis

✅ Skin lesion culture:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Skin biopsy:
Incorrect: Skin biopsy is indicated for patients with staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome; however, it is not necessary for patients with suspected impetigo.  
❌  Tzank smear :
Incorrect: Tzank smear testing can be used to confirm herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection. HSV lesions typically involve the mucous membranes (e.g., oral herpes) and are painful. In primary infections, patients may have systemic symptoms, such as fever, malaise, and lymphadenopathy.  
❌ Anti-streptolysin O testing:
Incorrect: Serologic testing for streptococcal antibodies is not useful for the diagnosis of impetigo, as the anti-streptolysin O (ASO) response is weak.  
❌ Anti-hemidesmosome antibody testing:
Incorrect: this test can be used to diagnose Bullous pemphigoid, which is a skin condition that results in large bullae. It is a disease occurring in elderly patients, not pediatric patients.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl presents to the pediatrician for evaluation of a rash on her elbows and knees that developed 5 days ago. The rash is pruritic but not painful, and there have been no new exposures to soaps, lotions, or detergents. The patient lives in the city and has had no exposure to plants or wooded areas. There has been no known contact with individuals with a similar rash. Her medical history is unremarkable. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 116/min, respirations are 26/min, blood pressure is 91/52 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is well-appearing. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. There are mildly erythematous papules on the extensor aspects of the elbows and knees, as well as on the buttocks. Which of the following findings would most likely be present on further evaluation?

choices.text: Recent history of Epstein-Barr virus/infectious mononucleosis
No immunizations since 18 months of age
Vesicles on the tongue and buccal mucosa

questions.solution:
This patient presents to the pediatrician with a mildly pruritic papular rash on the extensor surfaces (elbows and knees) and buttocks. This rash is consistent with Gianotti-Crosti syndrome, also known as papular acrodermatitis. A detailed history will typically reveal a recent viral infection, such as Epstein-Barr virus/infectious mononucleosis or hepatitis B.

When a patient presents with a suspected viral exanthem, it is important to ask about other symptoms such as fever (especially the length and timing of the fever compared to the rash), malaise, rhinorrhea, and sore throat. Exposure to other sick individuals and immunization status are also relevant. When evaluating specifics about the rash, it should be determined where the rash started and how it has spread and progressed. Rashes can be characterized as painful, pruritic, or asymptomatic.

On physical examination, the appearance and distribution of the skin lesions should be assessed. Rashes can be differentiated into maculopapular, reticulated, papular, and vesicular. Other physical examination findings such as mucous membrane involvement, lymphadenopathy, and conjunctival injection can help determine the etiology of the rash.       

Option Analysis

✅ Recent history of Epstein-Barr virus/infectious mononucleosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ No immunizations since 18 months of age:
Incorrect: This patient’s rash is consistent with Gianotti-Crosti syndrome (or papular acrodermatitis), which is often associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) or hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection. There is no immunization for EBV, and the HBV vaccine is given as a 3-dose series between birth and (up to) 18 months of age. Thus, a lack of recent immunizations is not directly relevant here. 
❌ History of chronic candidiasis:
Incorrect: Chronic candidiasis would suggest an underlying immunocompromising condition, like HIV infection. This patient’s rash is consistent with Gianotti-Crosti (or papular acrodermatitis), which is more often associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection. 
❌ Vesicles on the tongue and buccal mucosa:
Incorrect: This patient’s rash is consistent with Gianotti-Crosti syndrome (or papular acrodermatitis). The presence of oral vesicles would be more consistent with a primary coxsackievirus infection, rather than a manifestation of Gianotti-Crosti syndrome. 
❌ Slapped cheek appearance:
Incorrect: This patient’s rash is consistent with Gianotti-Crosti syndrome (or papular acrodermatitis), which is often associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) or hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection. Parvovirus B19, or erythema infectiosum, is characterized by a “slapped cheek” appearance.

questions.text: A 7-month-old girl presents to the pediatrician with one week of malaise. Her parents report that her symptoms started with a decreased appetite and progressed to a fever, cough, red eyes, and a runny nose. Over the last few days, the fever intensified, and yesterday, a rash developed. The patient’s family returned from India two weeks ago. Her routine immunizations are up-to-date. Temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 155/min, respirations are 36/min, blood pressure is 86/52 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is alert and appears uncomfortable. The anterior fontanelle is open and flat. There is mild conjunctival injection bilaterally, coryza, and small white spots with an erythematous base on the buccal mucosa. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. There is a diffuse erythematous maculopapular rash, as seen in the image below. Which of the following would confirm the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Human herpsevirus-6 (HHV-6) reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR)

questions.solution:
This patient presents with fever and upper respiratory symptoms, including a cough. Physical examination is notable for evidence of conjunctivitis, coryza, Koplik spots, and a maculopapular rash. There is history of travel to India, and most patients at 7 months have not yet received the measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccine. These findings are consistent with measles infection, which can be diagnosed with measles reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR).

Most viral exanthems are diagnosed clinically based on history and physical examination. Occasionally, further evaluation is necessary. Rashes due to roseola infantum, erythema infectiosum (fifth disease), varicella (chickenpox), and coxsackievirus (hand, foot, and mouth disease) usually do not require testing, since the clinical presentation provides enough information to make the diagnosis in most cases, and the care is supportive. Gianotti-Crosti syndrome is also usually a clinical diagnosis, but occasionally, testing is conducted to evaluate for the underlying virus (e.g., Ebstein-Barr virus, Hepatitis B) that precipitated the rash.

Since measles and rubella are vaccinated against with the measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccine, they are now infrequently seen in the United States. If there is suspicion for either one of these infections, confirmation should be done with serology or, in the case of measles, PCR testing. Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) and Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) can also cause a maculopapular rash and should be confirmed due to the implications of the diagnosis. Acute HIV can be diagnosed with a positive p24 antigen and elevated ribonucleic acid (RNA) RT-PCR. Epstein-Barr virus can be confirmed by a positive Monospot or positive anti-viral capsid antigen (VCA) immunoglobulin M.   

Option Analysis

✅ Measles reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Epstein Barr virus IgM:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation of fever, cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, Koplik spots, and rash is consistent with measles, which can be diagnosed with reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR. Epstein Barr virus IgM would test for infectious mononucleosis, which is not consistent with this patient’s clinical presentation.  
❌ Rubella IgM:
Incorrect: Although rubella can present similarly to measles, this patient’s presentation of fever, cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, Koplik spots, and rash is more consistent with measles. Measles can be diagnosed with reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR. 
❌ Human herpsevirus-6 (HHV-6) reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) :
Incorrect: HHV-6 reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) can diagnose roseola, but it is rarely used since roseola is often a clinical diagnosis. Additionally, this patient’s presentation of fever, cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, Koplik spots, and rash is more consistent with measles which can be diagnosed with reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR). 
❌ Enterovirus reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) :
Incorrect: Enteroviruses, such as coxsackievirus, are responsible for hand, foot, and mouth disease. This is often a clinical diagnosis and does not require diagnostic studies. This patient’s presentation of fever, cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, Koplik spots, and rash is more consistent with measles.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy presents to the clinic with 2 days of fatigue, malaise, arthralgias, and headache. The symptoms have progressively worsened. Ten days ago, the patient was hiking where he lives in northern Connecticut. The rash is not painful or pruritic. The patient has not had a sore throat, and there is no history of sick contacts. Past medical, family, and surgical histories are non-contributory. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 19/min, blood pressure is 119/76 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical exam, there is a rash present on the right thigh as shown in the picture below. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are unremarkable. The patient has full range of motion of the neck without stiffness. There is no swelling of the joints, and the patient has full range of motion of the joints with some pain associated with movement. Which of the following laboratory tests is needed to confirm the diagnosis before starting treatment? 


Reproduced from: Wikimedia commons. Licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 2.5 Generic.
questions.solution:
This 12-year-old boy who lives in Connecticut and was recently hiking presents with fatigue, malaise, arthralgias, headache, and a bull's eye rash consistent with erythema migrans (EM). The presence of EM rash indicates early localized Lyme disease. Treatment should be started immediately in early localized Lyme disease as no testing is needed to confirm the diagnosis before initiating treatment.        

Patients with Lyme disease may report a tick bite or travel to a Lyme-endemic area. Erythema migrans appear with early localized Lyme disease within days to two weeks after an infected tick bite. The skin lesion begins as a red or purple-colored macule or papule and expands with enhanced central erythema. It may appear as a bull’s eye lesion, as in this case. The rash is often non-painful and non-pruritic and may be accompanied by systemic symptoms, such as fever, malaise, headache, stiff neck, myalgias, and arthralgias. Carditis with a prolonged PR interval on electrocardiography is a manifestation of early disseminated Lyme disease. The most common manifestation of late Lyme disease, which occurs weeks to months after the initial infection, is arthritis, which is typically monoarticular, and affects the large joints, particularly the knee.        

The diagnostic evaluation of children who present with fever and rash involves narrowing down the most likely etiology based on history and physical exam including rash morphology. If the characteristic erythema migrans (bull’s eye lesion) rash is seen, and the patient lives in or has been to a Lyme endemic area, and there are no signs or symptoms of early disseminated or late disease, then no further work-up is required before treatment. If the patient has signs and symptoms of early disseminated or late Lyme disease, serology testing for Borrelia burgdorferi with an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) with reflex to Western immunoblot should be performed. Positive serology confirms a diagnosis of Lyme disease. Repeat testing is recommended several weeks later if initial testing is negative due to low sensitivity of serologic testing in early disease.   

Option Analysis

✅ No testing is required:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) :
Incorrect: Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) is commonly used to confirm infections such as Mycoplasma pneumoniae. Although PCR can be used to confirm Lyme disease, this test is not recommended for numerous reasons including a high false positive rate. A presumptive diagnosis of early localized Lyme disease can be made, and treatment should be given without the need for laboratory confirmation of disease. 
❌ Skin biopsy:
Incorrect: Skin biopsy is useful in confirming various skin infections such as Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome. This patient has early localized Lyme disease which can be diagnosed clinically, and treatment should be started without the need for laboratory confirmation. 
❌ Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays (ELISA):
Incorrect: This patient has early localized Lyme disease, and confirmatory lab testing is not necessary prior to starting treatment. Typically, testing will be negative in early Lyme, and ELISA should be only performed 4-6 weeks after the appearance of an erythema migrans rash.  
❌ Throat culture :
Incorrect: A throat culture can aid in diagnosing strep throat and scarlet fever secondary to group A streptococcus. This patient has early localized Lyme disease, and no laboratory testing is needed to confirm the diagnosis before starting treatment.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy is brought to the office for fever, headache, and rash. The patient returned from a camping trip in Oklahoma two weeks ago. He first developed an intermittent fever with temperatures as high as 40°C (104°F). Three days after the fevers first started, the patient developed a maculopapular erythematous rash on the ankles and wrists that subsequently spread to the trunk, palms, and soles. The patient also reports fatigue and abdominal pain. Past medical, family, and surgical histories are non-contributory. Temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 20/min, blood pressure is 100/66 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical exam, a non-blanching erythematous petechial rash is seen on the chest, trunk and extremities, including the palms and soles. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are unremarkable. Labs are shown below. Which of the following should be ordered to confirm the most likely diagnosis?  

 Laboratory value      Result     
 Serum chemistries           
 Hemoglobin      13.5  g/dL     
 Hematocrit      40 %     
 Leukocyte count      8,100 /mm3     
 Platelet count      142,000/mm3     
 Neutrophils, segmented      70%     
 Lymphocytes      20%     
 Alanine aminotransferase      60 U/L     
 Aspartate transaminase      80 U/L
questions.solution:
This patient recently returned from a camping trip in Oklahoma and presents with fever, headache, and a petechial rash that involves the palms and soles. Lab findings show mild thrombocytopenia and elevated liver enzymes. These findings are consistent with Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF) which can be confirmed with serologic testing for Rickettsia rickettsii.        

RMSF is transmitted by tick bite in endemic areas. It is commonly seen in the Southeastern and South-central United States. Patients present with fever, myalgia, headache, malaise, and rash and in severe cases may have altered mental status or meningismus. The rash is the most characteristic physical finding of RMSF and typically appears two to four days after the onset of fever. It appears initially as a blanching, erythematous maculopapular rash on the extremities, often including the palms and soles, which then spreads to the trunk and becomes petechial.        

If RMSF is suspected based on history, exposure to ticks, and physical exam findings of a petechial or purpuric rash, treatment should begin promptly because there is an elevated risk of mortality with RMSF. Patients with RMSF often have abnormal laboratory findings, such as thrombocytopenia, hyponatremia, and elevated liver enzymes. The diagnosis can be confirmed with serologic testing for Rickettsia rickettsii.    

Option Analysis

❌ Serologic testing for Rickettsia akari  :
Incorrect: Rickettsia akari is a gram-negative bacterium that causes rickettsialpox. Rickettsialpox is transmitted from mice and presents as a chickenpox-like rash that can progress to an eschar. This patient’s petechial rash includes the palms and soles, and developed after travel to Oklahoma, which is instead consistent with Rocky Mountain spotted fever; serologic testing for Rickettsia rickettsii should be performed to confirm the diagnosis. 
❌ Serologic testing for Borrelia burgdorferi  :
Incorrect: Borrelia burgdorferi is the gram-negative spirochete that causes Lyme disease. The classic rash of Lyme disease is erythema migrans or a bull's eye rash. This patient’s petechial rash includes the palms and soles, and developed after travel to Oklahoma, which is instead consistent with Rocky Mountain spotted fever; serologic testing for Rickettsia rickettsii should be performed to confirm the diagnosis. 
✅ Serologic testing for Rickettsia rickettsii  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Blood cultures :
Incorrect: Blood cultures can diagnose infections associated with other rashes like typhoid fever and Streptococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS). Patients with typhoid fever present with vomiting, diarrhea, rose spots on the trunk or abdomen, and history of recent travel to high-risk countries. Patients with SSSS present with bullae and desquamation. This patient’s petechial rash involving the palms and soles, as well as recent travel history to Oklahoma, makes Rocky Mountain spotted fever more likely. Serologic testing for Rickettsia rickettsii should be performed to confirm the diagnosis. 
❌ Rapid plasma reagin (RPR) :
Incorrect: RPR is used to screen for syphilis. Patients with secondary syphilis can present with fever and a maculopapular rash that involves the palms and soles. This occurs after the initial chancre of primary syphilis resolves in sexually active patients. This patient’s prepubertal age and recent travel to Oklahoma makes Rocky Mountain spotted fever more likely.

questions.text:
An 8-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents for evaluation of a fever and rash. The parents report that the patient developed a rash covering his body and has been increasingly fussy and difficult to console for the past four days. He has had a fever of 38.3°C (101°F). The parents became concerned today because the skin began to slough off. The patient was born full-term and has not had any significant medical issues since birth. Vaccinations are up-to-date. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), blood pressure is 90/67mm Hg, pulse is 155/min, respiratory rate is 25/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. The patient is crying in his mother’s arms and is difficult to console. Skin examination reveals moist, erythematous, denuded skin, as well as perioral and perinasal crusting. There is no mucous membrane involvement. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are within normal limits. Which of the following is the best next step in management? 


Reproduced from: Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with findings consistent with Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS), including a characteristic desquamating rash (without mucous membrane involvement), fever, and irritability. Most cases occur before the age of 6 years. Acute management of this condition includes administration of an intravenous antibiotic with appropriate coverage against Staphylococcus species, such as nafcillin or oxacillin.        

SSSS and impetigo are common pediatric skin infections that are most often caused by Staphylococcus aureus. While impetigo usually results from direct bacterial invasion of the skin or minor skin trauma, SSSS is caused by the hematogenous spread of staphylococcal exotoxins from colonized areas to distal sites. Exam findings can be used to distinguish mild staphylococcal infections, such as impetigo, from more severe infections, like SSSS.        

Acute management of each condition differs significantly. Patients with SSSS are much more likely to present with critical illness, superimposed sepsis, and significant fluid loss from desquamated skin and temperature dysregulation. Therefore, these patients require special attention to airway, breathing, and circulation before further management. Once stabilized, patients with SSSS should be admitted to the hospital and receive intravenous fluids and antibiotic therapy targeted at Staphylococcus species. Since most strains of S. aureus produce penicillinase, a penicillinase-resistant antibiotic, such as nafcillin or oxacillin, is preferred. If risk factors are present for methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA) or if the local prevalence of MRSA is high, vancomycin should be considered. Additional management includes application of mupirocin to the nares if S. aureus colonization is suspected, as well as pain control and wound management.    

Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous nafcillin:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Intravenous clindamycin:
Incorrect: Clindamycin has anti-staphylococcal activity but is not recommended as primary treatment for staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS), which is the likely diagnosis in this case, because of high rates of clindamycin resistance in patients with (SSSS).  
❌ Oral clindamycin:
Incorrect: Clindamycin has anti-staphylococcal activity but is not recommended as primary treatment because of high rates of clindamycin resistance in patients with staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS). This patient with SSSS requires admission to the hospital and intravenous antibiotic therapy. 
❌ Intravenous ciprofloxacin:
Incorrect: Ciprofloxacin provides adequate coverage against gram-negative organisms like Pseudomonas; however, it does not provide adequate coverage for Staphylococcus aureus sp which is the most common cause of SSSS. 
❌ Topical mupirocin:
Incorrect: Topical mupirocin is used to treat localized, non-bullous impetigo. This agent can be applied to the nares of patients with staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS) to manage colonization with Staphylococcus aureus, but it is not an appropriate treatment without the use of systemic therapy, such as nafcillin or oxacillin.

questions.text:
An 11-year-old boy presents to the immediate care clinic with his parent for evaluation of a rash. The rash has been present for the past week, and the patient has been intermittently “picking at it.” There are similar lesions on the patient's left arm. The patient reports that the rash is itchy. He has no significant past medical history and vaccinations are up-to-date. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 108/70 mm Hg, pulse is 99/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. The patient is well-appearing and in no acute distress. Skin examination demonstrates a facial rash, depicted in the image below, as well as vesicles on an erythematous base over the left forearm. Nikolsky sign is negative. There is no mucous membrane involvement. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 


Reproduced from: wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with features consistent with uncomplicated, non-bullous impetigo. This condition typically occurs in warm, humid months, and presents as a vesicular rash on the nares, mouth, face, and extremities. The lesions coalesce to form characteristic “honey crusted lesions.” When vesicles are present, Nikolsky sign is negative. Patients are typically well-appearing without constitutional signs and symptoms, although they may have regional lymphadenopathy.        

Impetigo is a common pediatric skin infection that is most often caused by Staph species. Staph scalded skin syndrome (SSSS) is also seen in pediatric patients and is most often caused by Staphylococcus sp. While impetigo usually results from direct bacterial invasion of the skin or minor skin trauma, SSSS is caused by hematogenous spread of staphylococcal exotoxins from colonized areas to distal sites. Exam findings and historical elements can be used to distinguish between these conditions, as detailed in the chart above.    

Option Analysis

✅ Non-bullous impetigo:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Bullous impetigo:
Incorrect: Infants or neonates with Bullous impetigo typically have a rash in intertriginous areas that are made up of vesicles that enlarge and evolve into flaccid bullae filled with clear, yellow fluid that often turns cloudy. These patients will often have a fever, diarrhea, or other constitutional symptoms.  
❌ Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome:
Incorrect: Patients with Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS) are typically young children who present with a characteristic desquamating rash, fever, and irritability. This patient has evidence of a localized rash consistent with impetigo.  
❌ Stevens-Johnson syndrome :
Incorrect: Stevens-Johnson syndrome is a rare disease in the pediatric population. Patients present with constitutional symptoms and a desquamating rash involving the mucous membranes after exposure to an offending agent (e.g., phenytoin, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole).  
❌ Herpes simplex virus-1 (HSV-1):
Incorrect: While herpes simplex virus (e.g., cold sores or herpes labialis) and impetigo may both initially present with vesicular lesions, impetigo tends to form “honey crust” lesions following rupture. Moreover, HSV-1 typically occurs on mucous membranes, is painful, and is unlikely to involve the nares or the extremities.

questions.text: An 8-month-old-girl presents to the pediatrician with her parent for evaluation of a rash and fever. The parent reports that the rash has been present for the past 2-3 days and appears to be in “different stages of healing.” He reports associated tactile fevers at home, as well as diarrhea. The patient was born full-term, is otherwise healthy, and does not take any daily medication. Vaccinations are up-to-date, and the patient has not had any recent sick contacts. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), blood pressure is 97/54 mm Hg, pulse is 110/min, respiratory rate is 30/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient is in the 50th percentile for length, weight, and head circumference. She is well-appearing and in no acute distress. Skin examination demonstrates flaccid bullae over the trunk with surrounding areas of ruptured bullae forming thin, brown crusts. Nikolsky sign is negative. There is no mucous membrane involvement. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This infant presents for evaluation of bullous lesions over the trunk with associated constitutional symptoms, consistent with bullous impetigo. Bullous lesions with a surrounding area of coalesced lesions with a thin brown crust and a negative Nikolsky sign are consistent with this condition. Primary treatment for bullous impetigo involves administration of an oral first-generation cephalosporin, dicloxacillin, or amoxicillin-clavulanic acid. Coverage for methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA) should be considered if there are high rates of local prevalence.        

Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS) and impetigo are common pediatric skin infections that are most often caused by Staphylococcus aureus. Exam findings and historical elements can typically be used to distinguish between these diseases. Treatment is tailored to the underlying condition, as detailed in the chart above.        

Option Analysis

✅ Oral cephalexin:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Topical mupirocin:
Incorrect: Topical mupirocin is an appropriate treatment for the nares in patients with bullous impetigo who are suspected of Staphylococcus aureus colonization; however, it is not appropriate as monotherapy for impetigo.  
❌ Intravenous nafcillin:
Incorrect: Intravenous nafcillin is the most appropriate treatment for patients with staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome. This condition presents in neonates or infants with fever, irritability/poor feeding, and a desquamating rash (Nikolsky positive). The patient in this vignette has localized bullae and is well-appearing, making bullous impetigo more likely. 
❌ Topical retapamulin:
Incorrect: Topical retapamulin is an appropriate treatment for patients with uncomplicated, limited, non-bullous impetigo. This patient has bullous impetigo, requiring oral antibiotic therapy.  
❌ Discharge home with dermatology follow-up:
Incorrect: Discharge home with dermatology follow-up is inappropriate. This patient has bullous impetigo and should be treated with oral antibiotics.

questions.text:
A 9-month-old girl presents to the emergency department for evaluation of fever, rash, and irritability. The rash started as generalized redness and progressively worsened. For the past few days, she has been refusing to eat and has decreased urinary output. There is no history of travel or exposure to sick contacts. Birth, family, and surgical histories are non-contributory. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 180/min, respirations are 32/min, blood pressure is 70/36 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. On physical examination, there are bullae on the body and findings on both hands as pictured below. The skin over the bullae peels off easily with gentle pressure. Cardiopulmonary exam is unremarkable except for tachycardia. Abdominal exam is normal. Labs are shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management?


 Reproduced from Wikipedia . Licensed under CC BY 4.0        

 Laboratory value      Result     
 Serum chemistries           
 Hemoglobin      14 g/dL     
 Hematocrit      41 %     
 Leukocyte count      17,100 /mm3     
 Platelet count      460,000/mm3     
 Neutrophils, segmented      70%     
 Lymphocytes      24%
questions.solution:
This infant with fever and a rash with bullae, desquamation of the skin, and positive Nikolsky sign has staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS). The patient is unstable with hypotension and tachycardia and requires emergent administration of intravenous fluids.    

SSSS is caused by Staphylococcus aureus producing exfoliative toxins which result in fever, erythema, and destruction of proteins in the skin. Lesions may be severe with partial-thickness burns, leading to high insensible losses due to capillary leakage and a damaged skin barrier. This can cause dehydration and shock, as seen in this case.        

Patients presenting with SSSS are typically neonates, infants, or young children with the sudden onset of symptoms including irritability, fatigue, and poor feeding. Physical examination demonstrates generalized erythroderma that evolves into diffuse, flaccid bullae. The bullae rupture, leaving areas of moist, erythematous, denuded skin. Other findings include perioral and perinasal crusting and desquamation, with sparing of the mucosa, and positive Nikolsky sign (i.e., applying pressure to bullae causes the upper skin layer to pull away from the underlying layers revealing a raw red base). A skin biopsy or culture of the lesional sites can confirm the diagnosis of SSSS; however, a diagnosis can be made based on history and physical exam findings alone.        

In children like this one with suspected bacterial infection who present with fever and rash, an Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, Exposure (ABCDE) assessment should be performed initially. If the patient is unstable, the first step is to stabilize the airway, breathing, and circulation. For unstable patients with signs of dehydration and shock including tachycardia and hypotension, emergent administration of intravenous fluids is needed to maintain systemic circulation. Continuous vital sign monitoring should be established, and oxygen should be provided as needed. Once the patient is stabilized, treatment should focus on treating the underlying bacterial infection with intravenous antibiotics.    

Option Analysis

❌ Intravenous nafcillin :
Incorrect: While intravenous nafcillin is ultimately the treatment of choice for staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (this patient's diagnosis), this patient is unstable with hypotension and tachycardia; therefore, the priority is emergent administration of intravenous fluids.  
✅ Intravenous fluids :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Blood cultures:
Incorrect: While blood cultures can sometimes help diagnose the etiology of shock, they are typically negative in children with staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome like this one. Priority should be given to stabilizing any patient who is in shock.  
❌ Skin biopsy  :
Incorrect: Skin biopsy can help confirm the diagnosis of staphylococcal scaled skin syndrome. However, obtaining a skin biopsy is not a priority for this patient who is in shock. Intravenous fluids should be given to help stabilize the patient. 
❌ Intravenous dopamine infusion  :
Incorrect: Intravenous dopamine infusion is used for patients with shock refractory to fluid resuscitation, but intravenous fluids must be given first.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a two-day history of fever and chills. The patient underwent an uncomplicated laparoscopic cholecystectomy for acute cholecystitis ten days ago. She reports pain at the incision site with purulent discharge and surrounding redness. Past medical history is significant for rheumatoid arthritis. Medications include methotrexate. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. BMI is 31 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), blood pressure is 119/76 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical examination, one of the surgical wounds is tender with purulent drainage, dehiscence, and surrounding erythema. A tender fluctuant mass is palpated. Laboratory evaluation is significant for leukocytosis with left shift and an elevated CRP. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Bed-side point of care ultrasound of the surgical site

questions.solution:
