This patient presents with peri-incisional pain, erythema, purulent drainage, dehiscence, and a tender fluctuant mass in the setting of SSI predisposing factors (e.g. immunosuppressive medication, obesity). These findings, along with clinical and laboratory signs of systemic infection (e.g. fever, tachycardia, leukocytosis, elevated CRP) are suggestive of a deep surgical site infection with abscess formation. The best next step in management is to obtain a bed-side ultrasound for diagnosis and to guide management.
 

Surgical site infections can be subdivided into three types based on the depth of the infection. Superficial incisional SSI refers to an infection limited to the skin and subcutaneous tissue and presents within 30 days following surgical intervention with peri-incisional pain, warmth, erythema, and purulent discharge. Superficial SSI is diagnosed clinically and further evaluated via wound culture and blood culture if systemic signs present. Point of care ultrasound may be performed to rule out an associated abscess or to guide drainage. Antibiotics should be provided if peri-incisional signs of infection extend more than five centimeters from the wound edge, if there is failure to improve after bedside wound opening, if implanted material is present, if the patient is immunocompromised, or if systemic signs of infection are present.

Deep incisional SSI is an infection that extends into the peri-incisional muscles and fascial layers. Signs and symptoms include peri-incisional signs of infection (e.g. pain, erythema, warmth, purulent drainage) with additional deeper signs of infection. These include wound dehiscence or a fluctuant mass indicating abscess. Diagnosis involves clinical examination, deep wound and blood cultures, and bed-side ultrasound of the surgical site to assess for abscess formation. Unlike superficial SSIs, management of deep incisional SSIs always includes empiric systemic antibiotic therapy followed by tailored antibiotic therapy based on culture results, bedside wound opening, and possible surgical re-exploration.

Organ/space SSI typically occurs with surgeries that involve implants (due to the increased risk of bacterial colonization) or bowel anastomosis (from bacterial leak). An organ space SSI usually lacks peri-incisional signs of infection but presents with systemic signs of infection, such as fever or hypotension and pain/tenderness where the operation was performed. It is diagnosed by the identification of an abscess or fluid collection in the affected organ/space on CT or MRI or with a positive culture from a previously installed surgical drain. Management includes systemic antibiotic therapy followed by tailored antibiotic therapy based on culture results, image-guided percutaneous drain placement of the affected organ/space, and possible surgical re-exploration and removal of implanted foreign devices.  

Option Analysis

✅ Bed-side point of care ultrasound of the surgical site:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Bed-side incision and drainage:
Incorrect: This patient presents with signs and symptoms suggestive of a deep surgical site infection with abscess formation. A bed-side point of care ultrasound should be performed to confirm the presence of an abscess prior to incision and drainage.  
❌ IV antibiotics and surgical re-exploration:
Incorrect: This patient presents with signs and symptoms suggestive of a deep surgical site infection with abscess formation. Although IV antibiotics and surgical exploration may be appropriate management, a bed-side ultrasound is initially required for diagnosis.  
❌ IV antibiotics and observation:
Incorrect: IV antibiotics alone are not sufficient to treat a suspected deep surgical site infection with abscess formation. Ultrasound-guided drainage or surgical exploration may be required if the presence of an abscess is confirmed.  
❌ Topical antibiotic and observation:
Incorrect: Topical antibiotics are not sufficient for treatment of a suspected deep surgical site infection with abscess formation.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman undergoes a total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy for ovarian cancer. Past medical history includes diabetes mellitus type 2 and dyslipidemia. On postoperative day 2, the patient develops severe pain at the surgical site with associated fever and fatigue. Temperature is 39.2°C (102.6°F), blood pressure is 97/69 mmHg, pulse is 112/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Examination of the wound reveals purulent, cloudy-gray discharge from the wound and palpable crepitus of the surrounding skin. Serum blood glucose is 350 mg/dL. IV Wound and blood cultures are sent and IV fluids are started. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Administer IV antibiotics and schedule urgent surgical re-exploration and debridement
Administer IV antibiotics and transfer to the intensive care unit for monitoring
Obtain a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis
Order consult for image-guided percutaneous drainage
Administer IV antibiotics and perform bed-side incision and drainage

questions.solution:
This patient presents with severe peri-incisional pain, fever, and fatigue on post-op day 2. Vitals are significant for systemic signs of infection, including fever, hypotension, and tachycardia. Physical examination is significant for “dishwater drainage” (cloudy-gray discharge) and subcutaneous crepitus on palpation. Together, these findings are suggestive of a necrotizing surgical site infection, which should be treated with IV antibiotics and emergency surgical debridement.
 

Necrotizing SSI is a deep surgical site infection complicated by necrotizing fasciitis. It is commonly caused by Strep. Pyogenes or Clostridium species, but it can also be polymicrobial. It presents more commonly in patients with diabetes and within 24-48 hours following surgery. It is a surgical emergency that requires urgent surgical exploration and debridement and IV broad-spectrum antibiotics, as the infection progresses rapidly.

In general, treatment of SSI depends on the type of and depth of infection. Superficial incisional SSIs are managed with bedside wound opening, wound care by secondary intention, and tailored antibiotic therapy in certain cases. Antibiotics are indicated if one of the following is present: peri-incisional signs of infection > 5 cm from wound edge, peri-incisional signs of infection not improved after wound opening, immunocompromised state, systemic signs of infection, or implanted material.

Deep incisional SSI are managed with empiric broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy followed by tailored antibiotic therapy based on culture results, bedside wound opening and drainage of abscesses confirmed by point of care ultrasound, and possible surgical re-exploration.

Organ/space SSI are managed with empiric broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy followed by tailored antibiotic therapy based on culture results, image-guided percutaneous drain placement in the affected organ/space, and possible surgical re-exploration and removal of implanted foreign devices.  

Option Analysis

✅ Administer IV antibiotics and schedule urgent surgical re-exploration and debridement:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administer IV antibiotics and transfer to the intensive care unit for monitoring:
Incorrect: Although IV antibiotics are required in the management of suspected necrotizing SSI, surgical debridement is required to control the source of infection and decrease the risk of morbidity and mortality.  
❌ Obtain a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis is helpful for detecting the presence of gas in soft tissue and confirming the diagnosis of necrotizing SSI; however, it should not delay surgical intervention due to risk of rapid dissemination of the infection.  
❌ Order consult for image-guided percutaneous drainage:
Incorrect: Image-guided percutaneous drainage would be appropriate for the management of patients with organ/space SSI. It is not indicated for the management of patients with suspected necrotizing surgical site infection.  
❌ Administer IV antibiotics and perform bed-side incision and drainage:
Incorrect: Although IV antibiotics are required in the management of suspected necrotizing SSI, early surgical debridement allows for better exploration, irrigation, and removal of necrotic material compared to bed-side incision and drainage. Emergency surgical exploration is essential in the management of necrotizing SSI.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of left leg pain and redness, chills, and fever that have developed over the past 3 days. The patient has a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and Crohn’s disease. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), blood pressure is 122/60 mmHg, pulse is 117/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. The left lower extremity from the knee to the foot is moderately tender to palpation, erythematous, indurated, firm, and warm. No crepitus is palpated, and there is no evidence of necrosis. The patient states that the leg has looked the same for the past 2 days. The patient is started on IV fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics, and blood cultures are drawn. The LRINEC is calculated from blood work and is 6, which is consistent with a moderate likelihood of NSTI. Which of the following is the next best step in management?

choices.text: CT of the left lower extremity
Surgical consultation for emergent exploration and debridement
MRI of the left lower extremity
Ultrasonography of the left lower extremity

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and Crohn disease presents for evaluation of fevers, and pain, erythema, and warmth of the left lower extremity. The patient does not have crepitus or rapidly progressing physical exam findings; therefore the next best step in management is to perform a CT, and use the findings of the CT scan in conjunction with the LRINEC score to guide management.    

Initial work-up for patients with suspected NSTI includes obtaining cbc, cmp, lactic acid, blood cultures, inflammatory markers (e.g. crp/esr), and CK levels. In patients without crepitus or rapidly progressing findings on physical examination, blood cultures should be obtained and empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics should be started along with IV fluids. CT imaging should be performed next. The Laboratory Risk Indicator for Necrotizing Fasciitis (LRINEC) score should be calculated. It is based on the results of the white cell count, hemoglobin, sodium, glucose, creatinine, and C-reactive protein, and it is used to determine the likelihood of NSTI in patients with suspected NSTI. Together the imaging results and the LRINEC score can be used to help determine the likelihood of NSTI and guide management.  

Option Analysis

✅ CT of the left lower extremity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Surgical consultation for emergent exploration and debridement:
Incorrect: Given that this patient does not have crepitus or rapidly progressing physical exam findings on the exam which would necessitate an emergent surgical consultant, CT imaging should be performed and the LRINEC should be calculated to determine the likelihood of NSTI.  
❌ MRI of the left lower extremity:
Incorrect: MRI is highly sensitive for NSTI, but it is time-consuming. Given the rapid progression of necrotizing soft tissue infections obtaining a CT scan is the best next step.  
❌ Continued antibiotics and serial examinations:
Incorrect:  Observation and serial examinations to assess for worsening would be appropriate management for a patient who, based on imaging and LRINEC score, likely has a non-necrotizing soft tissue infection.  
❌ Ultrasonography of the left lower extremity:
Incorrect:  This patient has clinical examination findings and history concerning a necrotizing soft tissue infection. An ultrasound examination is unlikely to provide any additional information at this time. CT imaging in conjunction with the LRINEC score should be used to guide management.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of pain, swelling, and erythema over his left lower extremity, as well as associated fever and chills for the past three days. An insect bite preceded the symptoms. Medical history is notable for hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia. Temperature is 38.3°C (101°F), blood pressure is 104/66 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical examination reveals a 4 cm x 4 cm area of induration, fluctuance, and erythema over the posterior left calf. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: MRI of the left lower extremity
X-ray of the left tibia and fibula
CT-angiography of the left lower extremity

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of a suspected skin abscess over the left lower calf. Given the associated systemic signs (fever, tachycardia, low-normal blood pressure), the next best step in management is to perform soft tissue ultrasonography to characterize the extent and depth of the abscess.

A skin abscess is a common skin/soft tissue infection that occurs when a collection of pus accumulates, usually in the dermis or subcutaneous space. An abscess can result from a disruption in the skin barrier or prior skin infection, which allows the bacteria to get into the subcutaneous space. The most common cause of a skin abscess is bacteria, especially Staphylococcus aureus (either methicillin-susceptible or methicillin-resistant). When it comes to presentation, a skin abscess can present with or without systemic symptoms.

The diagnosis of a skin abscess is largely clinical. Patients without systemic symptoms (e.g. fevers, hypotension) can be treated with simple incision and drainage, followed by monitoring for recurrence. Patients with large abscesses, systemic signs or symptoms, associated cellulitis, or significant laboratory abnormalities (e.g. markedly elevated leukocytosis) require formal soft tissue ultrasonography, cultures (e.g. purulent material, blood), and empiric antibiotics. These tests provide insight into the depth of infection and causative organism, which can guide incision, drainage, and antimicrobial therapy.   

Option Analysis

✅ Soft tissue ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ MRI of the left lower extremity:
Incorrect: An MRI is utilized for the evaluation of osteomyelitis. This patient's presentation is more consistent with abscess formation with systemic signs of infection, making ultrasound the next best step in diagnosis.  
❌ X-ray of the left tibia and fibula:
Incorrect: An X-ray may be used to identify evidence of gas gangrene or osteomyelitis. However, this patient's presentation is more consistent with a skin abscess with systemic signs of infection, making ultrasound the next best step in diagnosis.  
❌ Deep venous ultrasonography:
Incorrect: Deep venous ultrasonography is used to evaluate for the presence of deep vein thrombosis, not skin or soft tissue abscesses, which is likely in this patient with an indurate, erythematous, fluctuant mass.  
❌ CT-angiography of the left lower extremity:
Incorrect: CT-angiography would be a useful study for the evaluation of arterial thrombosis or peripheral vascular disease, not an abscess.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old man presents to the primary care office for a rash on his chest and back which has been present for three days. The rash is slightly itchy. He does not have fever, chills, or other associated symptoms. Several people who went on a recent vacation with him have had a similar rash. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and blood pressure is 124/82 mmHg. Examination of the trunk reveals a diffuse, papular rash over the hair follicles as seen below. Occasional pustules are noted and a culture is taken from the fluid within a pustule. The culture grows Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Which of the following would be the greatest risk factor for this patient’s infection?


Image by Lsupellmel is licensed under CC0 1.0 Universal Public Domain Dedication.  Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a diffuse, itchy, papulopustular rash located on the trunk, with Pseudomonas aeruginosa growth on culture, and has “hot tub” folliculitis caused by exposure to contaminated water, usually from a hot tub or swimming pool.  It is common for other individuals who were exposed to the contaminated water to also develop an infection.  

Folliculitis is most commonly caused by a superficial infection of hair follicles, which leads to a rash made up of itchy or painful red papules and pustules in the affected area. Bacterial folliculitis is usually caused by normal skin flora such as Staphylococcus aureus, and it is important to consider risk factors for MRSA such as working in a hospital setting or living in close quarters with large numbers of people. Fungal, viral, parasitic, and non-infectious etiologies of folliculitis occur as well. Patient activities that increase the risk of folliculitis include shaving and waxing, attempting to “pop” a pimple, wearing tight-fitting clothing, frequent sweating, and using a hot tub or swimming pool. Other risk factors include long-term antibiotic use, overuse of topical corticosteroids, and immunocompromised states such as HIV infection and diabetes.  

Option Analysis

✅ Hot tub use :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Work in a hospital:
Incorrect: Working in a hospital is a risk factor for folliculitis caused by MRSA.  Although healthcare workers have increased exposure to pseudomonas, it does not typically lead to folliculitis.
❌ Adolescent age:
Incorrect:  Some forms of folliculitis are more common in certain age groups such as Malassezia (pityrosporum) folliculitis, a fungal folliculitis, which is more common in adolescents due to the increased activity of sebaceous glands. This patient has “hot tub” folliculitis caused by pseudomonas which can affect individuals of all ages
❌ HIV infection:
Incorrect: Patients living with HIV infection are at increased risk of folliculitis caused by Staphylococcus aureus.  Patients with a low CD4 count are also prone to eosinophilic folliculitis, a clinically similar process to bacterial folliculitis but with eosinophilia and elevated IgE levels. They are not at increased risk of developing “hot tub” folliculitis.
❌ Recent shaving of the area:
Incorrect: Shaving or waxing is a risk factor for folliculitis, which may be inflammatory from ingrown hairs or infectious from normal skin flora bacteria; however, folliculitis caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa is highly associated with recent exposure to contaminated water in a swimming pool or hot tub and not shaving.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents to the primary care office for a painful red area on her left forearm. It has been present for 5 days and is getting worse. She frequently shaves her forearms but has never had an infection before.  She has a history of type II diabetes and does not regularly take her medication. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 132/82 mmHg. Examination of the forearm reveals a 3.5 cm cluster of pustular lesions with surrounding erythema. There is fluctuance and tenderness to palpation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a cluster of tender, fluctuant pustules on the forearm that can be diagnosed as a carbuncle. Shaving and diabetes are both risk factors for hair follicle infections including folliculitis, furuncles, and carbuncles.    

A hair follicle infection that is limited to the superficial dermis will appear as a superficially inflamed papule or pustule around a hair follicle and is diagnosed as folliculitis.  When the infection goes deeper and creates a painful pocket of pus in the subcutaneous space with overlying erythema of the skin, it is referred to as a furuncle. When a cluster of several furuncles connects through the subcutaneous space, it is diagnosed as a carbuncle which is a deeper, more severe infection with fluctuance, and possibly surrounding cellulitis. Patients diagnosed with a carbuncle should have a culture of the purulent fluid to guide antibiotic selection. A complete blood count should be done if systemic symptoms are present. Also if folliculitis or a furuncle fails to improve with empiric treatment, a culture of the purulent fluid is warranted.

Option Analysis

✅ Carbuncle:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Furuncle:
Incorrect: A furuncle is a single pustular lesion under the skin caused by an infected hair follicle. This patient has a cluster of furuncles which would lead to the diagnosis of a carbuncle.
❌ Folliculitis:
Incorrect: When a hair follicle infection stays confined to the superficial structures of the dermis, it is diagnosed as folliculitis. This patient has multiple, deeper infections that have coalesced into a single structure that is referred to as a carbuncle.
❌ Cystic acne:
Incorrect: Cystic acne is more superficial and usually contains smaller lesions than a carbuncle. Cystic acne is also more likely to occur on the upper arm than the forearm.
❌ Hidradenitis suppurativa:
Incorrect: Subcutaneous hair follicle infections are characteristic of hidradenitis suppurativa, however; hidradenitis occurs in a chronic, recurring pattern and in locations where there are increased sweat glands or where skin touches skin such as the axilla, groin, buttocks, and breasts. This patient’s isolated forearm infection would not be consistent with a diagnosis of hidradenitis suppurativa.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of severe pain in his right leg. He first noticed redness in his right leg yesterday, which is now swollen with severe, excruciating pain. This morning, he had a fever and chills, which prompted him to seek urgent care at the emergnecy department (ED). Past medical history is significant for morbid obesity (body mass index > 35 kg/m2) and type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM). He has been prescribed insulin for his T2DM, but he has not been taking it consistently during the past several months. His most recent HbA1c was 9.2%. Temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), heart rate is 126/min, his blood pressure is 92/50 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 18/min. Physical examination of the right leg reveals erythema, edema, and palpable crepitus extending from the distal thigh to the mid-calf. Laboratory studies are pending. Computed tomography (CT) with IV contrast of the lower extremities shows extensive soft tissue edema of the right lower extremity with air tracking along the fascial plane of the superficial posterior compartment in the right lower leg. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents to the emergency department with hemodynamic instability and signs of skin/soft tissue infection and sepsis (e.g., fever, tachycardia, hypotension) in the setting of uncontrolled diabetes. Given the presence of erythema and crepitus, along with pathognomonic findings of air tracking along a fascial plane on CT, necrotizing fasciitis is the most likely diagnosis. Intravenous fluids and intravenous antibiotics should be given. Definitive management consists of urgent operative debridement of all necrosed tissue and subsequent fluid resuscitation in an intensive care unit (ICU) setting.        

Necrotizing fasciitis is an infection of the deep soft tissues that results in progressive destruction of the muscle fascia and overlying subcutaneous fat. Infection typically spreads along the muscle fascia due to its poor blood supply; muscle tissue is frequently spared because of its generous blood supply. Risk factors include major trauma, immunosuppression (e.g., diabetes, cirrhosis, HIV), and obesity.        

Clinical manifestations of necrotizing infection include severe pain, fever, and findings of erythema, edema, crepitus, and bullae or necrosis. Treatment of necrotizing fasciitis consists of early and aggressive surgical exploration and debridement of necrotic tissue, together with broad-spectrum empiric antibiotic therapy and hemodynamic support. Administration of antibiotic therapy without debridement is associated with a mortality rate approaching 100 percent.   

Option Analysis

❌ Oral antibiotics :
Incorrect: This patient with a skin/soft tissue infection presents with sepsis; therefore, expeditious fluid resuscitation and intravenous antibiotics are necessary, and he should be taken to the operating room for debridement. 
❌ Antifungal medication :
Incorrect: While this patient’s uncontrolled diabetes increases his risk of a fungal infection, given findings of hemodynamic instability, palpable crepitus and the CT showing air tracking along the fascial plane, necrotizing fasciitis can be diagnosed. He should be treated with intravenous fluids and antibiotics and urgent operative debridement for definitive care.  
✅ Operative debridement  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Image-guided drain placement :
Incorrect: In patients with abscesses that cannot easily be superficially accessed, image-guided drain placement may be an option for source control. This patient does not have evidence of an abscess. Clinical and CT findings are consistent with sepsis from necrotizing fasciitis requiring intravenous fluids, antibiotics, and operative debridement.  
❌ Topical antibiotics  :
Incorrect: In patients with superficial cellulitis or impetigo, topical antibiotics are typically effective. However, this patient with life-threatening necrotizing fasciitis needs intravenous fluids and antibiotics, and urgent operative debridement of all necrotic tissue.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presents to the emergency department after returning from a recent hiking trip. He was hiking through a densely wooded area of Long Island, NY. He did not have consistent access to clean water. The last several days of his trip, he noticed severe pain and swelling of the chin. He shaved every other day while on his trip. He has no significant past medical history and takes no medication. Physical examination reveals localized pain, erythema, edema, and tenderness of the chin with a cluster of tender pus-filled bumps. Gram stain of fluid expressed from one of the bumps shows gram positive cocci. Wound culture is pending. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 29-year-old patient presents to the emergency department after a week of hiking and poor hygiene with a skin infection on his chin. Given that he has been shaving with dirty water and now has focal erythema and tenderness with a cluster of boils that grow out gram-positive cocci (e.g. Staph aureus), folliculitis is the most likely diagnosis.       

Folliculitis is a superficial infection of hair follicles with pustules that develop around the hair follicles. Patients who frequently remove hair through shaving or waxing are at an increased risk, as are patients with diabetes and poor hygiene. Physical examination typically reveals erythema, edema, and tenderness around hair follicles with or without a single or cluster of boils.    

Option Analysis

❌ Herpes Zoster :
Incorrect: Patients with herpes zoster have pain and a vesicular rash in a dermatomal pattern. This patient with focal erythema, tenderness, and pus-filled bumps on the chin after shaving with dirty water is more likely to have folliculitis. 
❌ Hidradenitis suppurativa :
Incorrect: While a wound culture in patients with hidradenitis suppurativa (HS) could show Staph Aureus, with gram-negative cocci on gram stain, HS is a chronic condition with painful, inflamed nodules or abscesses that form in the subcutaneous tissues of hairy areas or skin folds. This patient with focal erythema, tenderness, and pus-filled bumps on the chin after shaving with dirty water is more likely to have folliculitis.  
✅ Folliculitis  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lyme Disease :
Incorrect: The classic rash of lyme disease is an erythematous bull’s eye rash (erythema migrans). This patient with focal erythema, tenderness, and pus-filled bumps after shaving with dirty water is more likely to have folliculitis. 
❌ Candida intertrigo :
Incorrect: Patients with Candida intertrigo present with an erythematous rash with macerated plaques and erosions with peripheral scales in areas of the skin that are closely opposed (e.g., skin folds, axillae).

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents for follow-up evaluation after an elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy performed 14 days ago. The patient has been complaining of pain and warmth at the incision site for the past three days. He has not had fevers or chills. Past medical history is significant for well-controlled diabetes mellitus type 2 and seasonal rhinitis. Medications include metformin and glucocorticoid nasal spray. The patient has a 25-pack year smoking history and currently smokes. His most recent HbA1C is 6.1%. BMI is 23 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Temperature is 37.1 °C (98.8°F), blood pressure is 125/78 mmHg, pulse is 96/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical examination, one of the surgical wounds appears tender with purulent drainage and surrounding erythema. Which of the following factors confers an increased risk for developing this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with peri-incisional pain, warmth, erythema, and purulent discharge from the surgical wound; which is highly suggestive of a surgical site infection.

Surgical site infection (SSI) is an infection related to a surgical procedure that typically occurs near the surgical site between days 4 and 30 following surgery. It is most often caused by skin flora, including streptococcal species, Staphylococcus aureus, and coagulase-negative staphylococci. It can also be caused by pathogens, such as anaerobic gut bacteria, encountered during bowel surgery. Patients typically present with pain or tenderness at the surgical site and peri-incisional signs of infection, including warmth, erythema, or purulent discharge. Patients can also develop systemic signs of infection (e.g. fever, hypotension, tachycardia), wound dehiscence, and a tender fluctuant mass under the skin suggestive of an abscess. SSI gets subdivided into three types depending on the depth of infection: superficial, deep, and organ-space.

The risk of surgical site infection is based on the surgical classification of wound contamination. The wound can be classified as clean, clean-contaminated, contaminated, or dirty based on factors like location of surgery, trauma history, or breaks in sterile technique. Patient factors also play a role in increasing the risk of SSI, including current smoking, uncontrolled diabetes, and immunosuppression.

Smoking is considered a primary risk factor for developing a surgical site infection due to the vasoconstrictive effects of nicotine and poor tissue perfusion, alteration in nutrient transportation, and immune response. Therefore, it is advisable for patients to stop smoking 4-6 weeks before an elective surgery.
   

Option Analysis

✅ Current smoking status:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ History of diabetes mellitus:
Incorrect: A history of uncontrolled diabetes mellitus is associated with an increased risk for surgical site infection (SSI) due to immunosuppression and impaired wound healing. However, this patient's diabetes mellitus is controlled and thus would not appreciably increase the risk of SSI.  
❌ Glucocorticoids usage:
Incorrect: Nasal glucocorticoids have limited systemic absorption and thus do not significantly increase the risk of SSI.  
❌ Laparoscopic surgical approach:
Incorrect: An open surgical approach is associated with an increased risk of SSI. This patient underwent laparoscopic surgery.  
❌ Body mass index:
Incorrect: Obesity is associated with an increased risk of developing a surgical site infection. This patient has a normal BMI.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the primary care office for evaluation of five days of pain and tenderness in his upper back. He is not able to see the area well, but any time something touches it, he feels pain. He regularly has his chest and back waxed but has never had infections of the skin before.  He does not have any chronic medical conditions.  Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 68/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 118/78 mmHg. Examination of the upper back reveals a single tender, fluctuant, pustular lesion surrounding a hair follicle. There is erythema directly over the lesion but none surrounding it.  Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient who regularly waxes his back has developed an infection of a hair follicle.  Because the infection has caused a fluctuant pocket of pus to form in the subcutaneous tissue, it can be diagnosed as a furuncle and treated with incision and drainage.   

Management of hair follicle infections including folliculitis, furuncles, and carbuncles is guided by the extent of the infection. Cases of simple folliculitis will often resolve spontaneously or with a short course of topical antibiotics. Cessation of hair removal should be encouraged if the patient was previously shaving or waxing the affected area. Furuncles are typically managed initially with incision and drainage. If they do not resolve with incision and drainage or are associated with surrounding cellulitis, they may require oral antibiotics. A culture of the purulent material should be performed to help guide appropriate antibiotic therapy if a repeat incision and drainage is needed. Carbuncles represent deeper, more extensive infections and should be treated initially with incision and drainage; cultures and systemic antibiotics may be warranted at the onset of treatment, especially if there is a large area of abscess, surrounding cellulitis, or systemic symptoms; or if the patient is immunocompromised or has an indwelling medical device such as a prosthetic joint or pacemaker.

Option Analysis

✅ Incision and drainage:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Topical antibiotics:
Incorrect: Topical antibiotics are a reasonable treatment for folliculitis; however, this patient has formed a furuncle that needs to be drained.
❌ Systemic antibiotics:
Incorrect: Systemic antibiotics may be warranted in the management of a furuncle that has not responded to incision and drainage, or when overlying cellulitis or systemic symptoms are present.  This patient has not had drainage of the lesion yet and does not have other complicating factors, making incision and drainage the best option at this time.
❌ Benzoyl peroxide wash daily:
Incorrect: Benzoyl peroxide wash can be used in the management of superficial folliculitis or to reduce the number of bacterial colonies present on the skin in cases of recurrent furuncles or carbuncles. This patient has a furuncle, which requires incision and drainage for management, and it is his first infection, therefore benzoyl peroxide washes are not warranted at this time.
❌ Observation with reassessment in 48 hours:
Incorrect: Simple cases of folliculitis will often resolve spontaneously, making observation a reasonable option if the infection has remained in the superficial dermis; however, this patient has formed a furuncle in the subcutaneous space, which needs to be drained.

Three days ago, the patient had injured himself while working on their property in the woods. The patient has a history of uncontrolled diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia and coronary artery disease. The patient takes insulin, metformin, lisinopril, atorvastatin, and aspirin. Temperature is 39°C (102°F), blood pressure is 99/60 mmHg, pulse is 106/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. The patient appears ill, is oriented only to self. Physical examination of the left lower leg reveals warmth and rapidly spreading diffuse significant erythema surrounding a 4 cm burn with exposed subcutaneous fat and foul smelling grayish discharge. There is significant tenderness over the areas of erythema. Initial blood work is shown below and a culture of the discharge is sent. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

questions.solution:
This patient who developed a third degree burn and poorly controlled diabetes, who has deteriorated with signs and symptoms consistent with systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) likely has developed a necrotizing soft tissue infection. The patient is noted to have SIRS, criteria as well as leukocytosis, acute kidney injury, and associated metabolic derangements. Together these findings are concerning for a necrotizing soft tissue infection. In this patient with significant cardiovascular disease and the location on the medial leg above the medial malleolus, it is most likely secondary to an infected chronic leg ulcer.

Patients with open wounds and a history of fever, pain and risk factors like diabetes or immunocompromised disease are more likely to suffer from infectious soft tissue injuries. Burns are considered precipitating factors, as well as the existence of immunosuppressive co-morbid states (cancer, diabetes mellitus, vascular insufficiencies, organ transplantation or alcohol abuse) are precipitating factors for necrotitis soft tissue infections. Loping severe infections from common organisms as well as from organisms that are not usually virulent to those with an intact immune system. This is due in part to the immunologic dysfunction in severely burned patients. Burn wound sepsis can also lead to multiorgan dysfunction and death. Physical examination may reveal edema, erythema, tenderness, warmth, a palpable fluid collection, purulent drainage, crepitus or tissue necrosis. Laboratory findings will often demonstrate evidence of leukocytosis, metabolic derangements, and elevated inflammatory markers.

Severe burns cause serious, wide-ranging systemic effects secondary to the inflammatory and complex metabolic changes that can be life-threatening. During this inflammatory response, there is fluid loss and generalized edema that can lead to shock.

Infection is also a major concern. Burns damage the skin’s protective barrier, meaning bacteria and other foreign invaders can sneak in. Burns also weaken the immune system, so the body is less able to fight off threats.  

Option Analysis

✅ Necrotizing soft tissue infection:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Grade 2 burn:
Incorrect: Partial thickness, or grade 2, burns involve the dermis and are characterized by blisters, erythematous changes, and severe tenderness. This patient has evidence of exposed fatty tissue which would be considered a grade 3 burn.  
❌ Grade 1 burn:
Incorrect: Superficial, or grade 1, burns are superficial and limited to the epidermis with mild erythema. This patient has evidence of exposed fatty tissue which would be considered a grade 3 burn.  
❌ Cellulitis:
Incorrect: Cellulitis can cause warmth swelling and erythema and may cause sepsis. However, given the extensive and rapidly expanding erythema and septic shock in this patient with poorly controlled diabetes and a likely prior burn injury, this patient more than likely has a necrotizing soft tissue infection.  
❌ Hemorrhagic shock:
Incorrect: A combination of hypovolemic and distributive shock, accompanied by cardiogenic shock, and not hemorrhagic shock, can be seen in patients with severe burns. This patient, however, has likely developed septic shock secondary to a necrotizing soft tissue infection at the site of a prior burn.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with pain and discharge from her left armpit. She states that for the past week, she has had pain when raising her left arm above her head. She noticed several raised areas of redness that were tender to touch. Yesterday, she had discharge from the left armpit while taking a shower. Today, she began feeling feverish. She has had four similar episodes in the past three years in her armpits and groin. Vital signs are unremarkable. Body mass index (BMI) is 37 kg/m2. Physical examination is significant for several areas of tender nodules, fluctuance, erythema, and induration in the left axilla. There is one area with purulence. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This 24-year-old patient presents to the emergency department with an acute infection on top of a chronic disease of the left armpit. Given the history of chronic symptoms in the armpits and groin and physical examination findings of multiple tender erythematous nodules in the armpit with drainage, this patient can be diagnosed with hidradenitis suppurativa (HS). Imaging and laboratory studies are not necessary to make a diagnosis that can be made clinically.        

HS is a chronic condition where painful, inflamed nodules or abscesses form in the subcutaneous tissues of hairy areas or skin folds where there is constant rubbing. Patients usually report painful lumps around the axilla, groin, and inframammary areas. Risk factors include obesity and cigarette smoking. Examination typically shows multiple tender, erythematous nodules sometimes with visible sinus tracts and drainage.       

Treatment of HS consists of topical therapies, oral therapies, biologic therapies, surgery, and laser and light interventions. Disease severity, patient tolerance of specific agents, comorbidities, and treatment cost and availability guide treatment selection.       

Option Analysis

❌ KOH Testing :
Incorrect: A KOH test showing branching hyphae can confirm the diagnosis of a fungal infection. Fungal infections typically present with plaques and pruritus, which are absent in this patient.  
❌ Computed tomography  :
Incorrect: Computed tomography (CT) can be used to diagnose an abscess or a necrotizing soft tissue infection, but it is not required to make the diagnosis of hidradenitis suppurativa. Diagnosis of hidradenitis suppurativa can be made clinically. CT is used as part of operative planning to determine the presence of underlying abscesses or fistulous tracts.  
✅ No further testing is needed :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ ELISA assay for Lyme :
Incorrect: An ELISA assay is used to detect Borrelia antibodies in patients with suspected Lyme disease. This patient’s presentation and findings are not consistent with Lyme disease and are more consistent with hidradenitis suppurativa.  
❌ Skin culture   :
Incorrect: A skin culture is typically avoided, even in patients with superficial skin infections, as they are easily contaminated. Instead, a culture of the deep wound pocket or purulence should be collected. However, skin culture is not needed to make the diagnosis of hidradenitis suppurativa, which can be made clinically.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of worsening right foot pain and swelling over 1 day. The patient is unable to ambulate on the right foot due to pain. The patient has a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus managed with insulin, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and a chronic diabetic foot ulcer over the plantar aspect of the foot. Temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), blood pressure is 110/60 mmHg, pulse is 105/min, respiratory rate is 19/min, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. The patient appears uncomfortable. Examination of the right foot demonstrates erythema, edema, and induration over the entire foot and foul-smelling discharge from an ulcer present over the plantar aspect of the foot. The patient is started on IV fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics. Labs are ordered and pending. Radiograph of the right foot is shown below. Which of the following examination findings is most likely to be present?  



Reproduced from: Wikipedia

choices.text: Pain consistent with physical exam findings
Erythema with sharp margins over the right foot
Increased sensation of pain in the right foot

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of diabetes mellitus and a diabetic foot ulcer presents for evaluation of rapidly progressing pain, swelling, foul-smelling discharge, and erythema of the right foot. The foot radiograph shows evidence of subcutaneous gas which can be felt as crepitus (popping or crackling sensation) on physical examination.    

Crepitus and subcutaneous gas indicate necrotizing fasciitis. Necrotizing soft tissue infections (NSTIs), are rapidly progressing infections that can result in necrosis of the epidermis, dermis, subcutaneous tissues, fascia, and muscle. They can be a limb and life-threatening complication of diabetic foot ulcers. Necrotizing fasciitis is associated with the highest mortality rate because of how quickly it can spread throughout the body, and it is considered a surgical emergency.      

Patients  with NSTIs can present with fever, rapidly progressing pain, erythema, edema, induration, firmness, crepitus, and areas of necrosis which can appear as dark or gray boggy tissue with bullae. Foul-smelling wound discharge may be seen. In the early stages, the pain is often out of proportion to what is observed on physical examination. Risk factors for NSTI include diabetes, immunosuppression, history of a known open wound, history of recent trauma or surgery, and injection drug use.    

Option Analysis

✅ Crepitus in the right foot:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Pain consistent with physical exam findings:
Incorrect: The pain in necrotizing fasciitis is typically severe and it may be out of proportion to the physical exam findings.    
❌ Necrotic inguinal lymph nodes:
Incorrect:  Necrotic inguinal lymph nodes are commonly found in patients with Granuloma inguinale (donovanosis)--a genital ulcerative disease caused by the intracellular gram-negative bacterium Klebsiella granulomatis. This finding is not seen in patients with necrotizing soft tissue infections.   
❌ Erythema with sharp margins over the right foot:
Incorrect: The erythema seen in patients with NSTIs typically does not have sharp margins. Sharp margins are seen with cellulitis.  
❌ Increased sensation of pain in the right foot:
Incorrect:  With necrotizing fasciitis there is typically diminished sensation to pain in the involved area, due to thrombosis of small blood vessels and destruction of superficial nerves in the subcutaneous tissue.

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of injection drug use presents for evaluation of fever, pain, erythema, and induration of the left foot. This patient's clinical examination findings are concerning for a necrotizing soft tissue infection; however no crepitus is palpated and the patient has moderate and not severe pain which makes the diagnosis in question. The next step in evaluation is to use the CT findings and LRINEC score to identify the likelihood of NSTI. If, as seen in this patient, the LRINEC is high (>8) or the CT shows findings consistent with NSTI (edema and inflammatory changes in the subcutaneous tissue), then the diagnosis of NSTI can be made clinically and an emergent surgical consult should be called.  

Initial bloodwork for patients with suspected NSTI should include cbc, cmp, lactic acid, blood cultures, inflammatory markers (e.g. crp/esr), and CK levels. Patients without evidence of crepitus and without rapidly progressing disease on physical examination should have blood cultures drawn, IV antibiotics administered, imaging performed, and the LRINEC should be calculated. Imaging results and the LRINEC score can be used to diagnose NSTI, possible NSTI, or non-necrotizing infections. Patients with crepitus or rapidly progressing physical exam findings require immediate surgical consultation for operative debridement.  





Option Analysis

✅ Emergent surgical consultation for debridement:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Admission to the hospital for continued IV antibiotics:
Incorrect: This patient has CT evidence consistent with NSTI and a high LRINEC score and can be diagnosed clinically with an NSTI. The next step in management is emergent surgical consultation for debridement.  
❌ Discharge on cephalexin:
Incorrect: This patient has CT evidence consistent with NSTI and a high LRINEC score and can be diagnosed clinically with an NSTI. The next step in management is emergent surgical consultation for debridement.  
❌ Infectious disease consultation:
Incorrect:  This patient has CT evidence consistent with NSTI and a high LRINEC score and can be diagnosed clinically with an NSTI. The next step in management is emergent surgical consultation for debridement.  
❌ Ultrasonography of the left lower extremity:
Incorrect:  This patient has CT evidence consistent with NSTI and a high LRINEC score and can be diagnosed clinically with an NSTI. The next step in management is emergent surgical consultation for debridement. An ultrasound is not necessary.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a skin lesion over the left lower extremity for the past week. The patient has no significant past medical history and does not take any medications daily. The patient has not had fevers or chills. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 122/60 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates evidence of a tender erythematous nodule with spontaneous drainage of purulent material on the left lower leg. The rest of the physical exam is within normal limits. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present on examination of the left lower extremity?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of an uncomplicated skin abscess of the lower extremity. Skin abscesses are commonly associated with fluctuance, which refers to a wave-like or boggy sensation with palpation that suggests the presence of fluid accumulation underneath the epidermis.

A skin abscess is a common skin/soft tissue infection that occurs when a collection of pus accumulates, usually in the dermis or subcutaneous space. An abscess can result from a disruption in the skin barrier or prior skin infection, which allows the bacteria to get into the subcutaneous space. The most common cause of a skin abscess is bacteria, especially Staphylococcus aureus (either methicillin-susceptible or methicillin-resistant).

Patients with skin abscesses commonly present with small, tender, erythematous nodules with or without spontaneous drainage of purulent fluid. Fluctuance, induration, and regional lymphadenopathy may be noted on examination. Individuals with small abscesses are typically well-appearing. However, with larger abscesses, patients can develop concomitant cellulitis, fevers, chills, and systemic signs of sepsis.

Option Analysis

✅ Fluctuance:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Crepitus:
Incorrect: Crepitus is a physical examination finding suggestive of gas in the soft tissues and necrotizing soft tissue infection. This patient's well appearance and normal vital signs are not consistent with this diagnosis.  
❌ Multiple bullae:
Incorrect: Bullae are fluid filled blisters. They can be caused by hemorrhage, necrotizing soft tissue infection, and other infectious and inflammatory causes. They are not usually seen with a skin abscess.  
❌ Multiple petechiae:
Incorrect: Petechiae are pinpoint red spots suggestive of capillary hemorrhage. Petechiae are not typically present in patients with abscess formation.  
❌ Palpable cord:
Incorrect: A palpable cord can rarely be felt in patients with deep vein thrombosis. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with skin abscess formation.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents to the clinic for increasing redness and pain at a surgery site on the right leg. He had a skin excision performed six days ago to treat basal cell carcinoma. He first noticed the redness about three days ago, and since then, it has been spreading. Past medical history is significant for chronic renal disease, with a baseline creatinine of 2.5. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 134/78 mmHg, pulse is 79/min, and respiratory rate is 15/min. There is bright red erythema surrounding the excision site with purulent drainage and tenderness to light palpation on physical examination. Bacterial cultures of the wound fluid grow methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). Which of the following antibiotics should be used to treat this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
The treatment of choice for this patient’s abscess is doxycycline. Doxycycline is a tetracycline antibiotic that inhibits the 30S subunit of bacterial ribosomes, thereby preventing the attachment of aminoacyl-tRNA. It is unique among the tetracyclines since fecally eliminated, whereas the other agents are renally eliminated. Thus, doxycycline can be safely administered to patients with renal failure. Moreover, doxycycline (along with tigecycline and minocycline) has methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus coverage, whereas other tetracyclines do not.  

Option Analysis

❌ Tetracycline:
Incorrect: Tetracycline is renally excreted and should not be administered to patients with chronic renal disease. Moreover, tetracycline does not have methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus coverage.  
❌ Minocycline:
Incorrect: Minocycline provides coverage against methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. However, the medication is renally excreted and should not be administered to patients with chronic renal disease.  
❌ Cephalexin:
Incorrect: Cephalexin is a first-generation cephalosporin that does not treat methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus infection.  
✅ Doxycycline:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Cefpodoxime:
Incorrect: Cefpodoxime is a third-generation cephalosporin that does not have methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus coverage. However, it can treat severe gram-negative infections resistant to other β-lactam antibiotics. Other 3rd generation cephalosporins include ceftriaxone, cefotaxime, and ceftazidime.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man is brought by ambulance to the emergency department after his wife found him unresponsive upon returning from a trip to the grocery store. The wife states that he had been complaining of left leg pain, chills, and fatigue for 1 day. The patient has a past medical history of type 2 diabetes treated with insulin, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and obesity. The patient is responsive only to pain. Temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), blood pressure is 95/60 mmHg, pulse is 117/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 93% on room air. The patient appears acutely ill. The left lower extremity is shown below. It is erythematous, indurated, warm, and firm to the touch. Crepitus is felt on palpation. The patient is started on IV fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics. Labs are ordered and pending. Which of the following is the best next step in management?  


Reproduced from wikipedia

choices.text: CT of the left lower extremity
Radiography of the left lower extremity
Ultrasonography of the left lower extremity

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus presents for evaluation of rapidly progressing pain in the left lower extremity, chills, and fatigue and is found to be in septic shock. The patient has evidence of warmth, swelling, induration, and crepitus on exam. Crepitus indicates the destruction of subcutaneous tissues by gas-forming organisms. Crepitus which can feel like tiny pops of air or crunch under the skin indicates destruction of subcutaneous tissues by gas-forming organisms and is an indication of necrotizing fasciitis. Necrotizing fasciitis is the most aggressive form of necrotizing soft tissue infection (NSTI) and is considered a surgical emergency. An emergent surgical consult should be called for exploration, debridement, and wound cultures. Debridement with removal of the infected and necrotic tissue is the only effective method of source control.    

Necrotizing soft tissue infections, or NSTIs, refer to rapidly progressing infections resulting in necrosis of the epidermis, dermis, subcutaneous tissues, fascia, and muscle. NSTIs can occur anywhere in the body and can rapidly lead to limb loss, systemic toxicity, and death without surgical source control. Of the various types, necrotizing fasciitis is associated with the highest mortality rate because of how quickly it can spread throughout the body. Patients often present with rapidly progressing pain, erythema, edema, induration, evidence of necrosis, foul-smelling wound discharge, and crepitus.  

Due to the rapidly progressing nature of NSTIs, patients may be hemodynamically unstable requiring appropriate resuscitative measures including intravenous fluids, empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics, and vasopressor support if they are unresponsive to fluids. Emergent surgical consultation should be called for confirmation of the diagnosis by visualization in the operating room and debridement and to obtain wound cultures.



Option Analysis

✅ Surgical consultation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ CT of the left lower extremity:
Incorrect: This patient is unstable and has clinical examination findings, including crepitus, that indicate necrotizing fasciitis which is a surgical emergency requiring immediate surgical consultation. The diagnosis can be made clinically without imaging and it can be confirmed by visualization in the operating room.  
❌ Radiography of the left lower extremity:
Incorrect:  This patient is unstable and has clinical examination findings, including crepitus, that indicate necrotizing fasciitis which is a surgical emergency requiring immediate surgical consultation. The diagnosis can be made clinically without imaging and it can be confirmed by visualization in the operating room.  
❌ Infectious disease consultation:
Incorrect:  This patient is unstable and has clinical examination findings consistent with a necrotizing soft tissue infection. The patient requires broad-spectrum antibiotics at this time and emergent surgical consultation for operative debridement and wound cultures. Antibiotics can be tailored and infectious diseases consulted when wound culture results return  
❌ Ultrasonography of the left lower extremity:
Incorrect:  This patient is unstable and has clinical examination findings, including crepitus, that indicate necrotizing fasciitis which is a surgical emergency requiring immediate surgical consultation. The diagnosis can be made clinically without imaging and it can be confirmed by visualization in the operating room.

questions.text: A 47-year-old presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a painful, erythematous nodule on the right arm. Temperature is 38.3°C (101°F), blood pressure is 130/76 mmHg, pulse is 112/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Examination reveals a large, tender area of fluctuance and induration with associated erythematous changes. An incision and drainage is performed without complication following formal ultrasonography, which confirmed abscess formation. The patient is admitted to the hospital and started on IV vancomycin. On day three of hospitalization, both the cellulitic skin changes and the patient’s pain level have improved. Culture shows Streptococcus pyogenes growth from the aspirated fluid. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of a complicated skin abscess with systemic signs of infection. Given that this patient has responded well to initial treatment, it is appropriate to tailor antibiotic therapy and switch from intravenous to oral antibiotics that cover for Streptococcus pyogenes.

Management of a simple skin abscess includes incision and drainage, followed by monitoring for recurrence or worsening symptoms in 24-48 hours. However, patients like this one with large abscesses, systemic symptoms, associated cellulitis, or significant laboratory derrangements (e.g. markedly elevated leukocytosis) require formal soft tissue ultrasonography and cultures. Treatment for these cases includes intravenous antibiotics in addition to incision and drainage. Patients with clinical improvement after 24-48 hours can be switched from IV to oral antibiotics, with choice of agent guided by culture data. In contrast, patients with an inadequate response require repeat ultrasound to evaluate for any persistent abscess, followed by potential repeat incision and drainage, and tailoring of antibiotic therapy based on culture growth and susceptibilities.  

Option Analysis

✅ Switch to oral cephalexin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Repeat incision and drainage:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of clinical improvement following the initial incision and drainage and empiric antibiotics. Repeat incision and drainage is not indicated.  
❌ Continue current management:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of clinical improvement following the initial incision and drainage and intravenous antibiotics. Additionally, culture data is now available. Antibiotic therapy should be tailored and deescalated.  
❌ Consult infectious disease:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of clinical improvement following the initial incision and drainage and intravenous antibiotics. Additionally, culture data is now available to guide antibiotic deescalation. Infectious disease consultation is not required.  
❌ Switch to IV daptomycin:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of clinical improvement following the initial incision and drainage and intravenous vancomycin. Culture data shows growth of Streptococcus pyogenes. Daptomycin is not warranted.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents to the clinic for increasing redness and pain at a surgery site on the left arm. He had a skin excision performed about one week ago to treat squamous cell carcinoma. The redness developed two days later and, since then, has been spreading. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, and dyspepsia. Current medications include calcium carbonate, metformin, hydrochlorothiazide, lisinopril, and aspirin. Temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), blood pressure is 109/74 mmHg, pulse is 81/min, and respiratory rate is 15/min. There is bright red erythema surrounding the excision site with purulent drainage and tenderness to light palpation on physical examination. A bacterial culture of the excision site grows methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus. The patient is started on a 7-day course of doxycycline. Which of the following medications should not be taken concurrently with doxycycline?
questions.solution:
This patient should avoid concurrently consuming doxycycline and calcium carbonate. This precaution should be taken since the divalent calcium ions can inhibit the absorption of tetracyclines in the gut and decrease the drug’s efficacy. Tetracyclines should not be taken with milk, antacids, or iron-containing preparations.

Moreover, tetracyclines can accumulate in the teeth and bones, causing discoloration of the teeth and inhibition of bone growth. As a result, they are contraindicated in pregnancy, women who are breastfeeding, and children less than 8-years-old.  

Option Analysis

✅ Calcium carbonate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Metformin:
Incorrect: There is no interaction between doxycycline and metformin. Metformin can cause lactic acidosis and should be used with caution in patients with renal failure.  
❌ Hydrochlorothiazide:
Incorrect: There is no interaction between doxycycline and hydrochlorothiazide. Hydrochlorothiazide is a sulfa derivative, so it should not be given to patients with sulfa allergies.  
❌ Lisinopril:
Incorrect: There is no interaction between doxycycline and lisinopril. There is a high risk of acute kidney injury and hyperkalemia when taken together. Lisinopril should not be taken with aliskiren, a direct renin inhibitor.  
❌ Aspirin:
Incorrect: There is no interaction between doxycycline and aspirin. Aspirin should not be given to children, especially in viral infection, as it may lead to Reye syndrome.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man presents to the clinic with a three-day history of fever, chills, and discharge from a surgical wound. The patient was hospitalized two weeks ago and underwent a right total hip arthroplasty. The patient smokes two packs of cigarettes daily and does not consume alcohol or use recreational drugs. Family history is noncontributory. Temperature is 38.3°C (100.94°F), pulse 100/min, respirations 23/min, blood pressure 125/85 mmHg, and SpO2 98% on room air. Physical examination shows an open wound with purulent drainage at the right hip surgical site. The purulent drainage is swabbed and sent for culture. Twenty-four hours later, wound cultures begin growing methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. The patient is initiated on an antibiotic that disrupts cell membranes of gram-positive cocci by creating transmembrane channels. Which laboratory values must be monitored during this patient’s treatment?

choices.text: C. difficile toxin PCR in stool

questions.solution:
This patient with skin and soft tissue infection from methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA) was likely started on daptomycin. While vancomycin is the most commonly used parenteral antibiotic for MRSA, daptomycin is also frequently used. Other antibiotics with MRSA coverage include linezolid, ceftaroline, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, doxycycline, and clindamycin.

Daptomycin disrupts the cell membrane integrity of gram-positive cocci (including MRSA) by creating transmembrane channels. It is generally used as second-line therapy for patients whose MRSA cultures demonstrate high resistance to vancomycin. Of note, daptomycin is inactivated by the lungs' surfactant; thus, daptomycin cannot be used to treat pneumonia due to MRSA.

Daptomycin can cause profound adverse effects involving muscular tissue. These can include myopathy and rhabdomyolysis. Rhabdomyolysis manifests as elevated creatinine kinase, elevated serum creatinine, and often a urinalysis indicative of acute tubular injury (e.g., muddy casts, blood (+) without RBC). Monitoring creatine kinase is necessary while patients are on daptomycin therapy.  

Option Analysis

✅ Serum creatine kinase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lactate dehydrogenase:
Incorrect: Elevated lactate dehydrogenase can indicate many things, such as hemolysis. Hemolysis can occur in patients with G6PD deficiency who take dapsone. Dapsone inhibits folate synthesis and does not inhibit cell membrane integrity.  
❌ Liver function tests:
Incorrect: Hepatotoxicity is very rarely associated with daptomycin use. Elevations of aspartate aminotransferase (AST) may be from muscle breakdown rather than hepatotoxicity.  
❌ Complete blood counts:
Incorrect: Bone marrow suppression can manifest as anemia, thrombocytopenia, and leukopenia and is associated with chloramphenicol. Chloramphenicol binds to the 50S subunit of ribosomes and does not cause transmembrane channels.  
❌ C. difficile toxin PCR in stool:
Incorrect: C. difficile infections are primarily associated with clindamycin and long-term broad-spectrum antibiotic use. C. difficile toxin should not be routinely monitored for antibiotic therapy and is not commonly associated with daptomycin use.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy comes to the emergency department due to wounds on the thighs and palms of the hands after a motor vehicle accident. Past medical history is unremarkable. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse 80/min, respirations 20/min, blood pressure 105/75 mmHg, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 99% on room air. Physical examination shows several abrasions from ankle to mid-thigh bilaterally and abrasions on both palms. The patient is treated with a topical ointment containing an antibiotic that binds to phospholipids on cell membranes and disrupts the membrane integrity. Which of the following agents did this patient most likely receive?
questions.solution:
This patient sustained multiple abrasions after a motor vehicle accident and is being treated with a topical antibiotic agent that inhibits bacterial cell membrane integrity. Polymyxin B is an antibiotic used topically in treating partial thickness burns and superficial skin infections. It is nearly identical to polymyxin E (also known as colistin) but differs slightly in a side chain and, thus, its activation pathway.

Polymyxins are bactericidal agents that bind to lipopolysaccharides and phospholipids in the outer cell membrane of gram-negative bacilli. The binding of these agents disrupts the membrane integrity, causing bacterial contents leakage and cell death. The spectrum of activity of polymyxins is limited to gram-negative bacteria. Polymyxin B is frequently mixed with bacitracin and neomycin in over-the-counter antibiotic ointments, as this combination has a much broader spectrum of activity.

Systemic use of polymyxins is rare these days and is reserved for treating severe infections with multidrug-resistant bacteria, as they are associated with systemic toxicity. Adverse effects from systemic use include nephrotoxicity, neurotoxicity, and even respiratory failure.  

Option Analysis

❌ Gentamicin:
Incorrect: Gentamicin can be used in the treatment of superficial dermatologic infections. It inhibits bacterial protein synthesis and does not disrupt cell membrane integrity.  
❌ Nafcillin:
Incorrect: Nafcillin is indicated in the treatment of staphylococcal skin and soft tissue infections. It inhibits cell wall synthesis by inhibiting transpeptidases, not by disrupting phospholipid integrity.  
❌ Daptomycin:
Incorrect: Daptomycin is generally used to treat gram-positive organisms (including MRSA) resistant to vancomycin, though it cannot be used to treat MRSA pneumonia. It disrupts cell membrane integrity by creating transmembrane channels. It is used intravenously, not topically.  
✅ Polymyxin B:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Oxacillin:
Incorrect: Oxacillin is penicillinase-resistant penicillin that is used in the treatment of superficial skin infections. It inhibits cell wall synthesis by inhibiting transpeptidases, not by disrupting phospholipid integrity.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man presents to the emergency department with flank pain. He says he developed malaise three days ago. Then two days ago, he noticed a burning sensation along his left flank, extending from his mid-back to under his armpit. And then he developed a rash. He has not had any recent trauma and has not traveled anywhere in the past year. He has a past medical history of hypertension that is well-controlled with lisinopril. He is noticeably distressed and wearing loose-fitting clothing because any contact with his left flank is painful. Which of the following physical examination findings would be most consistent with the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 71-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe burning pain in a dermatomal distribution (acute neuritis) followed by development of a rash. These symptoms were preceded by malaise. The most likely diagnosis is herpes zoster infection. The rash associated with herpes zoster is a vesicular rash in a dermatomal distribution.       

Herpes zoster, also known as shingles, results from the reactivation of latent varicella-zoster virus (VZV) that has gained access to the sensory ganglia. Herpes zoster is characterized by a painful and unilateral vesicular eruption, which usually occurs in a single or two contiguous dermatomes. Most patients describe the pain as a deep burning, throbbing, or stabbing sensation, and the pain typically precedes the development of the rash. Patients may also have a prodrome of headache, fever, or malaise.        

Option Analysis

❌ Crepitus :
Incorrect: Crepitus is most often associated with necrotizing infections like fasciitis. This patient with prodrome and burning pain preceding the development of a rash most likely has a vesicular rash in a dermatomal pattern from herpes zoster. 
❌ Fluctuance :
Incorrect: Fluctuance is a tense area of skin with a “wave-like” or “boggy” feeling upon palpation and is present when there is an accumulation of fluid or pus in the underlying tissue. This is commonly associated with abscesses. This patient with prodrome and burning pain preceding the development of a rash most likely has a vesicular rash in a dermatomal pattern from herpes zoster. 
✅ Vesicular rash in a dermatomal distribution :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Erythematous Rash with honey-colored crust :
Incorrect: This examination finding is usually associated with impetigo, which is a superficial soft tissue infection found most often in children caused by Group A Streptococcus or Staphylococcus Aureus. This patient with prodrome and burning pain preceding the development of a rash most likely has a maculopapular rash in a dermatomal pattern from herpes zoster. 
❌ Sharply demarcated erythema   :
Incorrect: Sharply demarcated erythema is associated with erysipelas. Erysipelas is a non-purulent superficial soft tissue infection associated with Group A Streptococcus. Patients typically have erythema that is not in a dermatomal distribution. This patient with prodrome and burning pain preceding the development of a rash most likely has a maculopapular rash in a dermatomal pattern from herpes zoster.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man presents to the primary care office for evaluation of a skin lesion on his back. The lesion has been present for nine months without significant change. It was slightly itchy and inflamed after a backpacking trip he took last month, but it has since returned to baseline. The patient has a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination is notable for the lesion pictured below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 


Image by Assafn is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 4.0 International license. Reproduced from WikiCommons
questions.solution:
This patient’s raised, waxy, brown lesion with a “stuck-on” appearance is classic for seborrheic keratosis. These lesions are typically asymptomatic but may become itchy or inflamed due to friction. Seborrheic keratosis is a benign skin lesion that does not require intervention unless it causes discomfort or the patient desires removal. However, the abrupt appearance of multiple seborrheic keratoses, known as the sign of Leser-Trelat, is a rare paraneoplastic phenomenon associated with internal malignancy, and patients should be evaluated further.

Most benign skin lesions can be diagnosed clinically based on a thorough history and physical examination. Benign lesions are usually symmetrical in shape, color, and structure, with a size < 6 mm. They are typically stable over time with little to no change in appearance and without spontaneous bleeding.  

Lesion location and features of a patient’s history can aid in determining the diagnosis. For example, actinic keratoses are common in sun-exposed areas and often are seen in the context of repeated sun exposure. Patients with pyogenic granuloma commonly have a history of pregnancy or treatment with retinoids, chemotherapy, antiretrovirals, or immunosuppressive medication. Sebaceous hyperplasia is associated with hormonal changes, such as menopause, or the use of immunosuppressive therapy or antiretroviral medications. Lentigo often occurs in patients with a history of fair skin, sun damage, phototherapy, or radiation therapy; keloids and dermatofibromas occur in an area of prior skin trauma or inflammation. Lastly, patients with acrochordon (skin tags) may have a history of obesity, type 2 diabetes mellitus, or hormonal imbalances.   

Option Analysis

✅ Seborrheic keratosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Melanocytic nevus:
Incorrect: A melanocytic nevus (commonly known as a mole) is a flesh-colored, pink, tan, or brown papule that’s dome-shaped or pedunculated and typically soft or rubbery in texture. The pictured lesion has a dull, waxy surface with a “stuck on” appearance, which is classic for seborrheic keratosis.  
❌ Actinic keratosis:
Incorrect: Actinic keratosis presents as a scaly macule, papule, or plaque with a rough texture either with or without erythema. The pictured waxy, brown lesion is not consistent with the appearance of an actinic keratosis and is more suggestive of seborrheic keratosis.  
❌ Malignant melanoma:
Incorrect: A lesion suspicious for malignant melanoma will typically have concerning features from the ABCDE assessment (asymmetry; irregular borders; varying colors; diameter usually > 6 mm; and evolving in size, shape, or color). The pictured lesion lacks these features and has a dull, waxy surface with a “stuck on” appearance that is classic for seborrheic keratosis. 
❌ Pyogenic granuloma:
Incorrect: A pyogenic granuloma typically looks like a red, pedunculated, friable papule on the skin surface. The pictured waxy, brown lesion is not consistent with the appearance of a pyogenic granuloma and is suggestive of seborrheic keratosis.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents to the primary care office for evaluation of a “lump” on her left arm. She first noticed the painless mass approximately two months ago, and it has grown slowly since that time. There has been no trauma to the area, and she has not had similar symptoms previously. She is not bothered by the mass but would like to know what it is. Vital signs are within normal range. Physical examination reveals a 3 cm soft, non-tender subcutaneous nodule on the posterior aspect of the left upper arm as pictured below. The mass is rubbery in texture and mobile. Which of the following is the best way to diagnose this lesion? 


Image by Jmarchn is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 Unported license. Reproduced from WikiCommons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with classic findings of a lipoma, including the painless nature of the mass, location on the upper extremity, slow growth, rubbery texture, and mobile nature. Lipomas are subcutaneous skin lesions. The diagnosis of a lipoma can be made based on a clinical assessment alone in most cases; ultrasound imaging and biopsy are helpful when concerning features are present.        

The ABCDE assessment (asymmetry; irregular borders; varying colors; diameter usually > than 6 mm; and evolving in size, shape, or color) helps to identify whether a skin lesion is likely to be malignant. Dermatoscopy and biopsy can aid in the diagnosis of lesions on the skin surface, such as melanocytic nevi (flesh-colored, pink, tan or brown papule with soft or rubbery texture) and keratinic lesions (e.g. lentigo, seborrheic keratosis, sebaceous hyperplasia, actinic keratosis, and epidermoid cyst), that have concerning features from the ABCDE assessment. Vascular lesions, such as cherry angiomas (blanching red spot on the skin) and pyogenic granulomas (red growth on the skin surface with recurrent bleeding), can be diagnosed clinically.
