Fibrous skin lesions are benign growths, such as keloids, acrochordons, and dermatofibromas, on the skin surface. These can be identified by appearance with the help of history. Keloids are associated with prior skin trauma, and dermatofibromas are linked to skin trauma or inflammation. Acrochordons (skin tags) are typically found on areas of friction near the neck, axilla, or groin in patients with obesity, type 2 diabetes mellitus, or hormonal imbalances.   

Option Analysis

✅ Clinical assessment  :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Dermatoscopy:
Incorrect: Dermatoscopy involves using a skin surface microscope to help differentiate benign lesions from dysplastic and malignant lesions. This lesion is below the skin surface; therefore, dermatoscopy would not be helpful.  
❌ Excisional biopsy:
Incorrect: Excisional biopsy may be needed when the diagnosis of a subcutaneous mass is unclear. This mass has classic features and findings of a benign lipoma, and the diagnosis can be made clinically.  
❌ Fine needle aspiration:
Incorrect: Fine needle aspiration collects cells or fluid from a mass to determine whether it is benign or malignant, but it is not necessary in the diagnosis of a classic lipoma.  
❌ Ultrasound:
Incorrect: Ultrasound can be used to aid in the diagnosis of a soft tissue mass when the clinical picture is unclear. This mass has classic findings of a lipoma and can be diagnosed clinically.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man comes to the office to evaluate rough skin over his forehead and the back of his hands. The patient has tried applying different emollients without improvement. He has been working on a farm for the last 40 years. Past medical history is significant for hypercholesterolemia. He does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates erythematous papules with a gritty texture and central scale over the left temple and similar lesions over the dorsum of his hands, as seen in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of action of the medication that can be used to manage this patient’s condition?
 

Reproduced from: wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with actinic keratoses. These lesions typically manifest as rough, scaly papules on sun-exposed areas and can progress to cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma. Topical 5-fluorouracil cream is the first-line therapy for the treatment of actinic keratoses.

5-fluorouracil (5-FU) is a pyrimidine analog that interferes with the folic acid cycle. It undergoes metabolization to its active form 5-FdUMP and forms a complex with tetrahydrofolate. This complex  inhibits thymidylate synthase, which usually binds to dUMP and converts it to dTMP. Inhibition of thymidylate synthase results in decreased synthesis of thymidine. Other active metabolites of 5-fluorouracil can also be incorporated into DNA and RNA, resulting in inhibition of DNA and RNA synthesis.

5-fluorouracil is used to treat solid tumors, including colorectal and pancreatic cancer, and is also indicated for head and neck cancer, breast cancer, ovarian cancer, bladder cancer, and hepatocellular cancer. It can be applied topically for the treatment of basal cell carcinoma.

Side effects include bone marrow suppression, megaloblastic anemia, gastrointestinal disturbances (e.g. diarrhea), mucositis, alopecia, CNS toxicity, photosensitivity, and palmar-plantar erythrodysesthesia.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Hyper-stabilization of microtubules  :
Incorrect: Paclitaxel is a microtubule inhibitor that hyper-stabilizes polymerized microtubules in the M phase. The mitotic spindle cannot break down. Paclitaxel is indicated in the management of ovarian cancer, not actinic keratosis.  
✅ Inhibition of thymidylate synthase  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inhibition of topoisomerase II  :
Incorrect: Etoposide is a topoisomerase II inhibitor that increases DNA degradation by arresting the cell cycle in the G2 and S phases. It is used to manage solid tumors (testicular and small cell lung cancer), but not actinic keratosis.  
❌ Induces free radical formation  :
Incorrect: Bleomycin and anthracyclines (e.g., doxorubicin, daunorubicin) generate free radicals. Bleomycin is typically used in the treatment of testicular cancer and Hodgkin lymphoma. Anthracyclines are used for a wide range of non-hematological and hematological malignancies.  
❌ Inhibition of the proteasome  :
Incorrect: Bortezomib and carfilzomib are proteasome inhibitors. They are used to treat multiple myeloma and mantle cell lymphoma.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents to the oncology clinic for a follow-up. The patient was diagnosed with metastatic melanoma two months ago and was started on nivolumab. Repeat computed tomography (CT) and positron emission tomography (PET) imaging performed last week showed the progression of the metastatic lesions. Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination is unremarkable. After a long discussion with the oncologist, the decision is made to start ipilimumab; which of the following is the mechanism of action of this medication?

choices.text: Inhibition of cytotoxic T-lymphocyte associated protein-4 (CTLA-4)
Inhibition of DNA repair by topoisomerases

questions.solution:
This patient has metastatic melanoma; the prognosis of metastatic melanoma has improved with immunotherapy but is still limited. After diagnosis, patients need thorough evaluation for metastatic lesions as patients are at high risk for unrecognized lesions.

Upon diagnosis, patients are assessed for mutations in the BRAF gene (e.g. V600E) and may sometimes receive medications targeted toward these mutations. The other most common regimen is programmed death receptor inhibitors (PD-1), which include nivolumab and pembrolizumab with or without a CTLA-4 inhibitor, such as ipilimumab. CTLA-4 is an immune checkpoint molecule that competes with CD28 (a T-cell stimulating agent) and binds to CD80 (B7) and CD86 on antigen-presenting cells to downregulate them.

The PD-1 and CTLA-4 combination regimen can cause severe diarrhea and is not always well-tolerated by patients. PD-1 inhibitors, like other immunotherapeutic agents, can lead to autoimmune phenomena since they inhibit T-cells' proper functioning.   

Option Analysis

✅ Inhibition of cytotoxic T-lymphocyte associated protein-4 (CTLA-4) :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Inhibition of DNA repair by topoisomerases :
Incorrect: Topoisomerase inhibitors prevent DNA repair by binding to topoisomerase enzymes.  Examples include etoposide and irinotecan. 
❌ Intercalation of DNA strands :
Incorrect: Medications such as doxorubicin can insert between DNA strands, preventing DNA replication. 
❌ Inhibition of programmed death-1 (PD-1) ligand :
Incorrect: Some cancer cells express the PD-1 ligand (PDL1), which binds to the PD-1 receptor on T-cells, evading destruction by T-cells. Atezolizumab is a common inhibitor of the PD-1 ligand. 
❌ Inhibition of programmed death-1 (PD-1) receptor :
Incorrect: Some cancer cells express the PD-1 ligand (PDL1), which binds to the PD-1 receptor on T-cells, evading destruction by T-cells. Nivolumab and pembrolizumab are the most common inhibitors of the PD-1 receptor.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old man presents to the primary care office for evaluation of itchy skin lesions on his right hand. The lesions have been present for nine months and are slowly growing. The patient’s past medical history includes hypercholesterolemia for which he takes rosuvastatin. He is currently retired after working as a roofer outside for 40 years. Vital signs are within the normal range. Physical examination is notable for multiple erythematous macules as seen in the image below. The lesions have a rough, scaly sandpaper texture on palpation. Which of the following is the best next step in management? 


WikiCommons
questions.solution:
This patient’s rough, scaly skin lesions in a sun-exposed area of the body are classic for actinic keratoses. The patient’s work in roofing with repeated sun exposure likely contributed to the development of this condition. Because actinic keratoses are premalignant lesions, they should be treated either with liquid cryotherapy, topical fluorouracil, surgical procedures, or some combination of these therapies. In general, cryosurgery and surgical procedures are used to treat isolated lesions, whereas field-directed therapies, such as topical fluorouracil, are used to treat areas with multiple AKs. Cryotherapy is also used to treat hypertrophic or hyperkeratotic lesions. For this patient with multiple lesions, topical 5-fluorouracil is a reasonable approach. 

With the exception of actinic keratosis (a premalignant lesion), the need to remove or treat benign skin lesions is based largely on patient preference. Medical management with topical agents (e.g. isotretinoin, 5-fluorouracil, imiquimod, diclofenac) is an option for superficial lesions like actinic keratosis or lentigo (bleaching is also an option in lentigo). Cryotherapy can remove isolated lesions on the skin surface, such as actinic keratoses, lentigo, seborrheic keratoses, sebaceous hyperplasia, cherry angiomas, pyogenic granulomas, small keloids, and acrochordons. Surgical excision is required to remove lesions under the skin surface, such as lipomas, while laser therapy is useful for vascular lesions and pigmented lesions. Lesions that cannot be definitively identified as benign on clinical evaluation alone benefit from a method of removal that preserves the integrity and structure of the cells for examination by a pathologist, such as a shave biopsy, punch biopsy, incisional, or excisional biopsy.       

Option Analysis

✅ Topical fluorouracil  :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Biopsy:
Incorrect: A biopsy is not typically performed to diagnose or treat AK. However, a biopsy is indicated if the diagnosis is uncertain or to rule out cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma if the lesions have suspicious features. 
❌ Reassurance and observation:
Incorrect: This patient is presenting with findings of actinic keratoses, which are pre-malignant lesions. The lesions should be treated promptly to prevent evolution into squamous cell carcinoma.  
❌ Mohs surgery :
Incorrect: Mohs surgery is used to remove high-risk skin cancers. It allows the skin to be examined for any remaining malignant cells as thin slices of the skin are removed. This patient has actinic keratoses, which are pre-malignant lesions, and the use topical fluorouracil is appropriate.  
❌ Surgical excision:
Incorrect: Surgical excision is an option in the management of an isolated actinic keratosis, particularly if there are features concerning for squamous cell carcinoma. However, this patient has several flat lesions over a large area, so a topical treatment would be preferred.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman comes to the dermatology clinic because of an enlarging lesion on the nose, which she first noticed 6-months ago. The patient has also experienced increased confusion and forgetfulness. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals the findings below. An excisional biopsy is obtained and confirms the diagnosis of nodular melanoma. On additional evaluation, the patient is found to have multiple metastatic lesions in the brain. The patient is prescribed a medication that acts by blocking the action of ribonucleotide reductase. Which of the following adverse effects is most likely associated with this medication?
 

Image reproduced from DermNetNZ

choices.text: Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion

questions.solution:
This patient has metastatic melanoma. Treatment for melanoma is based on staging and localization of the disease. Localized melanoma that has not spread to lymph nodes is treated surgically. For thicker, but still localized lesions, surgical resection and adjuvant therapy is recommended (e.g. alpha interferon). For metastatic disease, treatment with hydroxyurea, vemurafenib, and radiation therapy may be used.

Hydroxyurea is an antineoplastic drug that inhibits ribonucleotide reductase, which is an enzyme that converts ribonucleotides to deoxyribonucleotides used in DNA synthesis. Thus, inhibition of ribonucleotide reductase impairs DNA synthesis and cellular division.

Hydroxyurea is used mainly to treat chronic myelogenous leukemia and other chronic myeloproliferative disorders (e.g. polycythemia vera). In addition, it is used to treat head and neck cancers and malignant melanoma.

Aside from its use as an anticancer agent, hydroxyurea is also used in patients with sickle cell anemia to reduce the frequency of acute pain crises and need for blood transfusion. These effects are achieved by stimulating the production of fetal hemoglobin (HbF) and increasing water content in erythrocytes.

Macrocytosis is usually seen in patients taking hydroxyurea. While not related to vitamin B12 or folate deficiency, the administration of folate alongside hydroxyurea can help mitigate this side effect. Other adverse effects include severe myelosuppression and gastrointestinal toxicity (e.g., nausea, mucositis).  

Option Analysis

❌ Peripheral neuropathy:
Incorrect: Peripheral neuropathy is commonly associated with the use of vincristine, which inhibits microtubules assembly. Hydroxyurea is not known to cause peripheral neuropathy.  
❌ Ototoxicity:
Incorrect: Platinum-containing chemotherapeutic agents (e.g. cisplatin) can cause ototoxicity. These agents induce their cytotoxic effect by crosslinking DNA, as opposed to inhibiting ribonucleotide reductase.  
✅ Macrocytosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Central nervous system toxicity:
Incorrect: Nitrosoureas are alkylating agents that crosslink DNA. They can cross the blood-brain barrier, hence making them effective in the treatment of brain tumors. However, they are associated with central nervous system toxicity (e.g., ataxia, confusion).  
❌ Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion:
Incorrect: Cyclophosphamide is an alkylating agent that crosslinks DNA. It is associated with significant side effects including syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH), hemorrhagic cystitis, and bladder cancer.

questions.text:
A 5-hour-old male infant is evaluated in the nursery for a skin lesion present at birth. He was born at term to a 32-year-old woman who had consistent prenatal care. The lesion is located next to the umbilicus and is shown below. The parents are worried that it might affect their child cosmetically. They would like to know what is the most appropriate treatment and prognosis for their child’s condition.  


Retrieved from: Wikipedia  

Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the doctor at this time?

choices.text: Excisional surgery therapy now, as this lesion carries a high risk for complications
Observation, as this lesion is likely to regress without treatment
Oral propranolol now, as this lesion carries high-risk potential
Topical imiquimod now, as this lesion carries a high risk for disfiguration
Intralesional corticosteroids now, as this lesion is deep and unlikely to regress without treatment

questions.solution:
This asymptomatic newborn has a strawberry hemangioma, a benign tumor of vascular endothelium. They are the most common tumors of childhood. These tumors are characterized by an early growth phase followed by involution in the first few years of life.  

The approach to treatment is individualized and based upon the size of the lesion, location, morphology, potential or current complications, scarring or disfigurement potential, patient’s age, and the rate of growth or involution. The potential risk of treatment should be carefully weighed against the benefits. Hemangiomas are further classified into low-risk/uncomplicated hemangiomas and high-risk/complicated hemangiomas.  

 
  •  Low-risk/uncomplicated hemangiomas are located in away from cosmetically sensitive locations, as seen here. These are treated with observation, as they are likely to involute after the first year of life. Topical therapies such as topical beta-blockers, and less commonly corticosteroids and imiquimod, can be used for the treatment of low-risk/uncomplicated hemangiomas as an alternative to observation, especially if there is ulceration. 
 
  •  High-risk/complicated hemangiomas include large hemangiomas with a risk of scarring or disfigurement (e.g. facial hemangiomas), life-threatening hemangiomas (e.g. airway hemangiomas), lesions with functional risks (e.g. periocular hemangiomas), and hemangiomas with ulceration that are unresponsive to standard wound care. In general, these are treated with oral propranolol (first line) or other surgical modalities.  

Option Analysis

❌ Excisional surgery therapy now, as this lesion carries a high risk for complications:
Incorrect: Surgical excision is typically reserved for involuted lesions with residual scars, hemangiomas that failed to involute by age 4, pedunculated cutaneous hemangiomas, and small periorbital hemangiomas. This patient’s lesion is low risk/uncomplicated (see main explanation).  
✅ Observation, as this lesion is likely to regress without treatment  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Oral propranolol now, as this lesion carries high-risk potential:
Incorrect: Oral propranolol is the first-line treatment for hemangiomas with the potential to impair function or disfigurement if there are no contraindications (i.e. heart condition). This patient’s lesion is low risk and uncomplicated (see main explanation).    
❌ Topical imiquimod now, as this lesion carries a high risk for disfiguration  :
Incorrect: Topical imiquimod is sometimes used for small, localized hemangiomas, especially when ulceration is present. However, it has been less commonly used since the introduction of topical beta-blockers. This patient’s lesion is low risk and without ulceration.  
❌ Intralesional corticosteroids now, as this lesion is deep and unlikely to regress without treatment:
Incorrect: The use of intralesional corticosteroids (e.g. triamcinolone acetonide) is reserved for small, localized, deep hemangiomas. Deep hemangiomas are present below the skin and appear as blue discoloration of the skin. This patient’s lesion is superficial.

questions.text: A 6-week-old girl is brought to the pediatric clinic for evaluation of a skin lesion on the left cheek. The parent reports that the area appeared slightly discolored at birth and has grown rapidly over the past month. The lesion does not seem to cause discomfort, and the infant feeds and sleeps normally. There is no history of trauma, fever, or recent illness. The infant was born full term via spontaneous vaginal delivery without complications. Immunizations are up-to-date. On examination, the infant is alert and well-appearing. A 3 cm soft, compressible, raised reddish-blue lesion is noted on the left cheek. The overlying skin is intact and warm to the touch. There is no surrounding erythema or tenderness. The remainder of the physical examination is normal. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present on physical examination?

choices.text: Bruit on auscultation of the mass
Movement of the mass with tongue protrusion

questions.solution:
This 6-week-old infant presents with features typical of an infantile hemangioma: a soft, compressible, raised reddish-blue lesion that appeared shortly after birth and has grown rapidly during the first weeks of life. Infantile hemangiomas are benign vascular tumors of infancy. Although usually low-flow lesions, a bruit may occasionally be heard over larger or more superficial hemangiomas due to increased vascularity.

A focused history and physical examination is critical when evaluating pediatric head and neck masses, as it provides early insight into the probable cause, whether malignant, infectious, or developmental. Important historical features include age of onset, growth rate, systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, weight loss, or night sweats), and exposure history (e.g., animal contact, recent infections, or radiation). Physical findings such as location (midline versus lateral), consistency (soft, firm, or fluctuant), mobility, and skin changes (discoloration, warmth, or tenderness) help narrow the differential diagnosis. For example, a rapidly enlarging firm lateral mass with systemic symptoms may suggest malignancy, while a soft, fluctuant, erythematous lesion suggests infection. A midline, non-tender mass that enlarges slowly and moves with tongue protrusion is more consistent with a thyroglossal duct cyst.
   

Option Analysis

❌ Mass transillumination:
Incorrect: Transillumination is a feature of fluid-filled masses, such as cysts. Hemangiomas are vascular and solid and typically do not transilluminate.
✅ Bruit on auscultation of the mass:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Skin dimpling over the lesion:
Incorrect: Skin dimpling is characteristic of dermoid cysts, which are often subcutaneous with overlying skin tethering. Dermoid cysts are not vascular and do not typically grow rapidly after birth.
❌ Movement of the mass with tongue protrusion:
Incorrect: This finding is typical of a thyroglossal duct cyst, usually located in the midline neck. The described lesion is on the cheek and vascular in appearance, making a thyroglossal duct cyst unlikely.
❌ Purulent drainage from the mass:
Incorrect: Purulent drainage suggests an abscess or infected lymph node. Infantile hemangiomas are usually non-tender, non-draining, and not associated with signs of infection unless secondarily infected, which is not suggested here.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to her dermatologist with concerns regarding a mole on her left arm. She works as a surfing instructor and spends prolonged hours in direct sunlight daily. She often forgets to wear protective clothing and sunscreen. She has a history of intermittent sunburns, especially during family vacations in tropical regions. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals several pigmented lesions on her arms and face. On her left arm, there is an irregularly shaped, elevated lesion, with varying shades of red and black. The lesion measures approximately 5 mm in diameter. The surrounding skin shows signs of chronic sun damage. Which of the following features is most indicative of the need for further evaluation of the lesion?

choices.text: Varying shades of red and black
Presence of chronic sun damage to the surrounding skin

questions.solution:
This patient, with a history of significant sun exposure and prior sunburns, presents with a skin lesion that has irregular borders and varying shades of red and black. These features raise suspicion for melanoma–warranting further investigation with a biopsy.    

Melanoma refers to a malignant tumor arising from melanocytes that often presents with unique clinical characteristics that distinguish it from benign skin lesions. A number of factors determine whether or not a lesion is suspicious for melanoma and should be biopsied. Clinically, the ABCDE criteria can serve as a guide for identifying suspicious lesions that may need to be biopsied: Asymmetry, Border irregularity, Color variegation, Diameter over 6mm, and Evolution (change in size, color, or shape of a pre-existing lesion or report of a new growing lesion). Patient-reported symptoms such as itching, bleeding, or sensory changes in the lesion should heighten the suspicion of malignancy. Additionally, when a lesion looks conspicuously different (“ugly duckling” sign) from surrounding nevi (nevus phenotype), then a biopsy should be performed. The Glasgow Seven-point Checklist seen below can also help determine when lesions should be biopsied.    

During a skin exam, trained physicians may use a dermatoscope which magnifies skin lesions and can detect features that may be suspicious for malignancy but are not visible to the naked eye. For example, a dermatoscope can reveal subsurface skin structures within the epidermis, dermoepidermal junction, and papillary dermis. Visualizing these structures can increase the diagnostic accuracy of skin exams.





Option Analysis

❌ Occupation with frequent sun exposure:
Incorrect: While frequent sun exposure increases the risk of skin cancer, the appearance and features of the lesion are more pertinent to the diagnosis and evaluation of suspected melanoma.
❌ Lesion diameter of 5 mm:
Incorrect: Lesions greater than 6 mm should be biopsied. This lesion is small and based on size would not need to be biopsied. However the irregular shape and varying colors of the lesion warrant biopsy.
❌ Location on the left arm:
Incorrect: The location alone is not a significant factor in predicting malignancy. Morphological features of the lesion, such as irregular borders and varying colors, are more concerning features for a melanoma that necessitate biopsy.
✅ Varying shades of red and black:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Presence of chronic sun damage to the surrounding skin:
Incorrect: Chronic sun damage is a common finding in individuals with prolonged sun exposure but is not directly suggestive of malignancy. Specific features of the mole itself, such as irregularity and color variation, are more important indicators of potential malignancy.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old woman presents to the dermatology clinic with concerns about a lesion on her right upper arm that her partner noticed 2 weeks ago. She has not had any itching or bleeding at the site. Past medical history includes hypertension managed with lisinopril. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg, pulse is 72/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the lesion seen below is present on the lateral aspect of the right upper arm. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
 

Taken from STATdx
questions.solution:
A number of factors taken together can help identify lesions that are suspicious for melanoma that should be evaluated with excisional biopsy.

Excisional biopsy involves the removal of the entire lesion along with a small rim of surrounding normal skin. This approach provides an accurate measurement of the thickness (Breslow depth) of the melanoma, which is crucial for staging and subsequent management.

For large lesions in facial, mucosal, or acral locations that are suspicious of melanoma, an incisional biopsy can be considered, where only a representative portion of the lesion is removed. However, care must be taken to ensure the most raised or thickest part of the lesion is biopsied to allow for the most accurate measure of the Breslow depth. Histopathology findings consistent with melanoma include atypical melanocytes with hyperchromatic nuclei, or other abnormal nuclei or nucleoli characteristics, in addition to asymmetric, poorly circumscribed nests of melanocytes.  

Option Analysis

✅ Excisional biopsy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Observation and follow-up in 1 year:
Incorrect: The lesion is suspicious for malignant melanoma given its asymmetry, irregular border, and color variegation. Observation is inappropriate for a lesion that is suggestive of melanoma due to the rapid progression and high potential for metastasis. Delay in diagnosis can result in a worse prognosis.  
❌ Shave biopsy:
Incorrect: The lesion is suspicious for malignant melanoma given its asymmetry, irregular border, and color variegation. A shave biopsy involves removing only a portion of a lesion, which can be insufficient for assessing the full depth of a suspected melanoma. This can lead to inappropriate staging and can compromise optimal management.  
❌ Liquid nitrogen cryotherapy:
Incorrect: The lesion is suspicious for malignant melanoma given its asymmetry, irregular border, and color variegation. Liquid nitrogen cryotherapy is primarily used for benign skin lesions like molluscum contagiosum, and squamous cell carcinoma (SSC) in-situ. It is not appropriate for use with suspected melanoma, as it does not provide tissue for histopathological analysis.  
❌ Mohs micrographic excision:
Incorrect: The lesion is suspicious for malignant melanoma given its asymmetry, irregular border, and color variegation. While Mohs micrographic surgery is a precise method for treating certain skin cancers like basal and squamous cell carcinomas located in cosmetically sensitive areas, it is not typically used for initial diagnosis or treatment of melanoma due to concerns about potentially missing invasive components of the tumor.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presents to the dermatology office for evaluation of a new skin lesion on the right calf. Twelve years ago, the patient had a cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC) removed from the same area with curettage and electrodesiccation. The lesion is not painful or pruritic. On physical exam, there is a well-defined 0.8 cm diameter lesion on the right calf. A punch biopsy is performed and shows a well-differentiated cSCC that is 1 mm in thickness without invasion beyond the subcutaneous fat. The patient is otherwise healthy aside from bilateral hip osteoarthritis for which he occasionally takes naproxen. Which of the following is the best treatment for this patient’s lesion?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a recurrent cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC) of the right calf. The lesion has features that are low risk for recurrence. His initial lesion 12 years ago was treated with curettage and electrodessication. However, since this is a recurrent lesion, curettage, and electrodessication are contraindicated. Instead, he should undergo surgical excision.         

For low-risk primary cSCC, the National Comprehensive Cancer Network guidelines recommend a standard excision with 4 to 6 mm clinical margins of uninvolved skin to a depth of the mid- or deep subcutaneous adipose tissue. For incompletely excised cSCC, further excision with circumferential histologic margin control or Mohs micrographic surgery is recommended.        

Recurrent and high-risk lesions should be treated with surgical excision. Mohs surgery, which is a specialized tissue-sparing procedure that involves histologic assessment of 100 percent of the excised tumor margins, has also been used for the treatment of tumors without high-risk features.   

Option Analysis

❌ Curettage and electrodessication  :
Incorrect: This can be used for small, superficial, well-defined cSCCs that are located in noncritical, low-risk sites. Recurrent lesions, such as in this patient, are a contraindication to this treatment.  
❌ Radiation therapy :
Incorrect: Radiation therapy is indicated in patients with low-risk cSCC who cannot undergo surgery. This patient does not have a contraindication for surgery so this would not be the preferred treatment.  
✅ Surgical excision  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Photodynamic therapy :
Incorrect: Photodynamic therapy is based upon the ability of porphyrins to produce cytotoxicity in the presence of oxygen after stimulation by light of an appropriate wavelength. It is currently not approved for invasive cSCC but is approved for squamous cell carcinoma in situ.  
❌ Cryosurgery  :
Incorrect: Cryosurgery destroys malignant cells by freezing and thawing. Since cryosurgery does not permit histologic confirmation of the adequacy of treatment margins, it may be used for small, well-defined, low-risk invasive cSCC. Recurrent lesions are a contraindication for cryosurgery.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician’s office for evaluation of a new skin lesion on the face. The patient first noticed some redness on her left cheek three months ago, but it did not bother her at the time. She was out to lunch with a friend this past week who encouraged the patient to have the lesion evaluated. The patient has been experiencing burning pain around the lesion. She spends half the year at the beach and the other half gardening at her primary residence. Past medical history is notable for hypercholesterolemia, for which she takes atorvastatin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical exam reveals a fleshy, granulomatous papule with central ulceration as seen in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
 
Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents to the office with a concerning skin lesion on her cheek in the setting of significant sun exposure and new onset neuralgia. Physical exam reveals a granulomatous papule with central ulceration, which is suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma.

Cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC) is a malignant tumor arising from epidermal keratinocytes. In individuals with lightly pigmented skin, it typically develops in areas of photodamaged skin and can present as papules, plaques, or nodules that can be smooth, hyperkeratotic, or ulcerated. Cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma lesions may be scaly and they may bleed. A skin biopsy is required to confirm the diagnosis. Pathology will reveal atypical squamous cells infiltrating the dermis.  

Option Analysis

❌ Basal cell carcinoma:
Incorrect: Lesions of basal cell carcinoma are typically pink or flesh-colored papules with a pearly or translucent quality, and telangiectatic vessels. The papules are often described as having  rolled borders. This lesion is more consistent with squamous cell carcinoma.  
❌ Melanoma:
Incorrect: Melanomas are lesions that typically meet the ABCDE criteria: asymmetry, border irregularity, color variegation, diameter >6 mm, evolution over time. This lesion is more consistent with squamous cell carcinoma.  
✅ Squamous cell carcinoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Skin tag:
Incorrect: Skin tags (Acrochordons or fibroepithelial polyps), are benign lesions that typically appear as pink, red, or white pedunculated lesions on a narrow stalk. This lesion is more consistent with squamous cell carcinoma.  
❌ Common warts:
Incorrect: Common warts (verruca vulgaris) are benign lesions caused by human papillomavirus (HPV) infection of keratinocytes. They typically appear as small cauliflower-like papules with a rough, papillomatous and hyperkeratotic surface. They typically appear on the hands and feet of children and young adults.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to her dermatologist because she is concerned about her risk of developing melanoma since her mother passed away from metastatic melanoma at the age of 75. The patient is on hormone replacement therapy for perimenopausal symptoms. She enjoys outdoor activities and spends several hours outside gardening a few times per week. Her diet consists of dairy, seafood, and red meat. She smokes a half-pack of cigarettes daily and consumes 1-2 alcoholic beverages daily. Vitals are within normal limits. The dermatologist identifies several atypical moles on skin examination. Which of the following is the most effective method for her to reduce her risk of developing melanoma?

choices.text: Avoid sun exposure during peak hours

questions.solution:
Skin cancer is one of the most common cancers in the United States. The incidence of melanoma is increasing. The most effective methods for preventing melanoma include decreasing exposure to UV rays from sunlight by limiting time outdoors during peak hours, wearing sun-protective clothing, and using broad-spectrum waterproof sunscreen with an SPF of 30 or higher.  Also, patients should avoid artificial UV rays like those used in tanning beds.    

People who are over 50 years of age are at increased risk of developing melanoma; as are people who are sun-sensitive (ie., red or blonde hair, light eye color, light skin pigmentation, freckling). Other risk factors include a nevi count greater than 50 with or without large, atypical nevi. Additionally, personal or family history of skin cancer, immunosuppression, and treatment with chronic immunosuppressive therapies increase the risk of melanoma. Lastly, there is an increased risk of melanomas in patients with certain genetic disorders, such as xeroderma pigmentosum or albinism.  

Patients who are at increased risk for developing melanoma should be counseled about preventative measures, self-examination, and regular dermatologic evaluation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Avoid sun exposure during peak hours:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Quit cigarette smoking:
Incorrect: Although skin changes may be related to smoking, smoking has not been found to be an independent risk factor for the development of melanoma.
❌ Reduce alcohol consumption:
Incorrect: There has not been a conclusive study linking increased alcohol consumption with the development of melanoma. 
❌ Consume more vegetables:
Incorrect: Studies addressing the role of dietary factors (eg, antioxidants, retinoids, vitamin C, and vitamin E) have not shown a consistent impact of diet on the incidence of melanoma.
❌ Stop hormonal therapy:
Incorrect: There has been conflicting evidence on whether or not hormonal therapy increases the risk of developing melanoma in women. Sun exposure is a more significant risk factor that can be mitigated to reduce the risk of developing melanoma.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man presents to the dermatology clinic with concerns about a pigmented lesion on his left upper arm. He mentions that he first noticed the lesion about 6 months ago, but in the past two months, it appears to have grown and darkened in color. He works as a construction worker and often spends prolonged periods outdoors without sun protection. Past medical history is significant for hypertension controlled with hydrochlorothiazide. Family history is noncontributory. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), blood pressure is 130/85 mm Hg, pulse is 72/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Skin examination reveals a 1.5 cm asymmetric lesion with an irregular border and with a number of variable colors. An excisional biopsy of the lesion reveals atypical melanocytes with hyperchromatic nuclei with a Breslow thickness of 0.7 mm, without ulceration, along with inadequate margins. There is no evidence of regional lymphadenopathy on examination. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Wide local excision with 1 cm margin and follow-up in 6 months
CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis
Sentinel lymph node ultrasound and biopsy
Wide local excision with 2 cm margin and adjuvant immunotherapy

questions.solution:
This patient's biopsy reveals melanoma with a Breslow thickness of 0.7 mm without ulceration indicating early-stage melanoma. The Breslow thickness, which measures the depth of invasion of the melanoma, is an essential prognostic factor. For melanomas with a Breslow thickness of ≤0.8 mm and inadequate margins, the recommended treatment is to remove the rest of the lesion with wide local excision (WLE) with a margin of 0.5 to 1 cm, along with continued surveillance every six months.

For melanomas ≤0.8 mm without ulceration, wide local excision is the primary intervention, with margins dictated by lesion thickness. Post-excision, biannual then annual surveillance is standard. However, for melanomas >0.8 mm or for those with ulceration, TNM staging is indicated to assess for metastasis using modalities like CT and PET scans. In the absence of distant metastases, treatment involves wide local excision, possibly paired with sentinel lymph node biopsy. If positive, a complete lymphadenectomy is indicated and immunotherapy may be provided. For metastatic disease, BRAF V600 mutation testing may be performed to guide the potential use of immunotherapy. In patients with extensive metastatic stage 4 melanoma treatment involves palliative care.  

Option Analysis

✅ Wide local excision with 1 cm margin and follow-up in 6 months:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis:
Incorrect: While metastatic workup is important in high-risk melanomas, in a patient with a Breslow thickness < or equal to 0.8 mm and no ulceration, the chance of distant metastasis is minimal, therefore it is not indicated.  
❌ BRAF V600 status test:
Incorrect: This mutation is seen in about half of melanomas and denotes susceptibility to BRAF inhibitors. During the initial management of a low-risk melanoma with a Breslow thickness <0.8 mm, this test is not required. It should be done for metastatic cases to make decisions regarding targeted therapies.  
❌ Sentinel lymph node ultrasound and biopsy:
Incorrect: While sentinel lymph node biopsy can be valuable in evaluating the potential spread of melanoma to regional lymph nodes, it is indicated primarily for melanomas with a Breslow thickness of >0.8 mm or for those with ulceration. In this patient with a Breslow thickness of 0.7 mm and no ulceration, wide local excision without sentinel lymph node biopsies is the appropriate treatment.  
❌ Wide local excision with 2 cm margin and adjuvant immunotherapy:
Incorrect: For a melanoma with Breslow thickness ≤0.8 mm and inadequate margins, the recommended treatment is to remove the rest of the lesion with wide local excision with a margin of 0.5 to 1 cm. A 2 cm margin is not necessary. Adjuvant immunotherapy is recommended for patients with metastatic or locoregional disease who meet criteria. For this patient surgical excision alone may be curable.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman presents to the primary care office for evaluation of a skin lesion on her left ear. The lesion has been slowly enlarging over the last four months and bleeds easily when she touches it. She has never had a lesion like this in the past. She has a history of multiple blistering sunburns as a child and has used tanning beds in the past. She has no significant past medical history and does not take daily medications. Pulse is 78/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 128/80 mmHg. Examination of the skin reveals an 18 mm, pearly pink raised nodular lesion with well-defined borders at the apex of the left auricle. A shave biopsy reveals nests of basaloid epithelial cells containing large nuclei with peripheral palisading and clefting from adjacent tumor stroma. Which of the following factors indicates that this lesion has a high risk for recurrence?
questions.solution:
This patient’s skin lesion can be diagnosed as a basal cell carcinoma with a high risk of recurrence based on lesion being located on the head. The patient’s history of multiple blistering sunburns as a child as well as prior tanning bed use likely contributed to her risk of developing basal cell carcinoma.

Patients presenting with signs or symptoms suggestive of basal cell carcinoma (BCC) should have a biopsy to confirm the diagnosis. Biopsy can be a punch, shave, incisional, or excisional biopsy. Islands or nests of basaloid epithelial cells containing large nuclei with peripheral palisading and clefting from adjacent tumor stroma are classic findings of nodular type basal cell carcinoma.

After histologic identification, BCC is then further differentiated as being low risk for recurrence or high risk for recurrence based on patient factors and tumor characteristics. Tumors are considered to be low risk for recurrence if they are primary lesions, less than 20 mm in size with well-defined borders; with nodular, superficial, or other non-aggressive growth pattern; and located on the trunk or extremities (other than the hands or feet). BCC is characterized as high risk for recurrence if the lesion is a recurrent lesion; if it is ≥ 20 mm in diameter; located on the head, neck, hands, feet, or genitalia; or if the borders are ill-defined. Perineural invasion is a sign of a lesion being high risk for recurrence as well as if the histopathology shows micronodular, morpheaform, sclerosing, infiltrating, basosquamous, or carcinosarcomatous patterns of growth. A BCC that occurs in a patient who is immunocompromised is also considered to be high risk for recurrence.  

Option Analysis

✅ Location on the head:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Size of the tumor:
Incorrect: Tumor size greater than or equal to 20 mm is associated with high risk for recurrence. This patient’s lesion is less than 20 mm, but the location on the ear makes it high risk.  
❌ Well-defined borders:
Incorrect: The presence of well-defined borders in the absence of other high risk features is a characteristic of basal cell cancer with low risk of recurrence.  
❌ Nodular growth pattern:
Incorrect: A nodular growth pattern, as seen in this patient, is associated with a low risk of recurrence; however, given the location on the ear, this lesion would be classified as high risk for recurrence.  
❌ Primary lesion:
Incorrect: A primary lesion, as seen in this patient, is associated with a lower risk of recurrence. Recurrent lesions are considered high risk for recurrence. Given the location of this lesion on the patient’s ear, it would be considered high risk for recurrence.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old woman presents to the primary care office for evaluation of a lesion on her nose. She states she previously had a small basal cell carcinoma in the area that was treated with cryotherapy. The skin was smooth for several years until she noticed a new lesion growing about seven months ago. She works in construction and spends long days outdoors throughout the summer. Past medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and she does not take daily medications. Pulse is 74/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 124/82 mmHg. Examination reveals a lesion on the left side of the nose as seen below. Biopsy shows aggregates of basal cells with large, hyperchromatic nuclei and minimal cytoplasm. Peripheral palisading and retraction clefts are noted. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?  


Image reproduced from Open i
questions.solution:
This patient with a recurrent basal cell carcinoma on the face should have Mohs surgery for removal of the lesion. Mohs surgery involves removing one layer of skin at a time and examining it microscopically for the presence of cancerous cells until disease-free tissue is reached. The high level of precision of this procedure makes it a good option for lesions on the face and other cosmetically-sensitive areas and when there is not enough soft tissue surrounding a lesion for adequate closure after an excision.

The treatment approach in basal cell carcinoma is dependent on the location of the lesion as well as the risk for recurrence. Surgical excision is the preferred method of removal in most cases of BCC; however, curettage and electrodesiccation is an option for small, low-risk for recurrence lesions. 5-Fluorouracil, imiquimod, cryotherapy, photodynamic therapy, and radiation therapy are options for low-risk lesions when patients cannot tolerate surgery. Patients with BCC with a high-risk for recurrence who are not surgical candidates should be offered local radiation therapy, or systemic therapies like chemotherapy or immunotherapy.  

Option Analysis

✅ Mohs surgery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Wide local excision:
Incorrect: Wide local excision is the best approach for lesions that are not in cosmetically sensitive areas and have sufficient surrounding skin for adequate closure. This patient would have significant disfigurement from a wide local excision on the nose; therefore, Mohs surgery is the best option.  
❌ Repeat cryotherapy:
Incorrect: This patient has a recurrent lesion on the face, making it high-risk for recurrence; therefore, it should be surgically removed.  
❌ Curettage and electrodesiccation:
Incorrect: Curettage and electrodesiccation is a treatment option for small BCC lesions with low risk of recurrence. This patient with a recurrent lesion is at high risk of recurrence; therefore, it should be surgically removed.  
❌ Radiation therapy:
Incorrect: Radiation therapy can be offered to patients with BCC and lesions that are high-risk for recurrence if patients are unable to undergo surgery. This patient does not have any noted contraindications to surgery; therefore, removal of the lesion is the best approach at this time.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man presents to the surgery office for evaluation of a new skin lesion. The patient first noticed the lesion on his right arm about two weeks ago. There is no associated pain or pruritus. He worked as a lifeguard growing up and never wore sunscreen. His medical history includes hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and a prior basal cell carcinoma of the scalp which was removed two years ago. A full body skin exam is performed, and the right arm lesion is biopsied. The biopsy shows dysplastic keratinocytes involving the full thickness of the epidermis that penetrate the epidermal basement membrane to involve the dermis. Which of the following would most likely be seen on physical exam given the biopsy findings?

choices.text: Indurated, hyperkeratotic plaque with a 2mm area of ulceration
Large ulcer with granulation tissue at the base

questions.solution:
Cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma: Image courtesy of Wikimedia Commons       

This patient presents to the office with an asymptomatic lesion on the right arm in the setting of a significant history of sun exposure. Biopsy results show dysplastic keratinocytes penetrating the basement membrane, which indicates that the lesion is invasive cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC). cSCC lesions are typically indurated or firm hyperkeratotic papules, plaques, or nodules, with or without ulceration.         

Cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma is the second most common form of skin cancer after basal cell carcinoma. cSCC can develop on any cutaneous surface including the head, neck, trunk, extremities, oral mucosa, periungual skin, and anogenital areas. In individuals with lightly pigmented skin cSCC most commonly arises in sites frequently exposed to the sun. Non-sun-exposed areas represent the most common location for cSCC in individuals with darkly pigmented skin. cSCC can also develop in areas of chronic scarring or burns. The most important risk factors for developing cSCC include ultraviolet light exposure, chronic immunosuppression, and a history of actinic keratosis.        

Patients with presumed cSCC should have a full body skin exam followed by a dermatoscopy of suspicious lesions. A lymph node exam should be performed at the lymph node basins of any suspicious lesion as well.    

Option Analysis

❌ Pigmented lesion with irregular borders :
Incorrect: This describes a melanoma. While the patient has risk factors for melanoma, the pathology results indicate cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma. Pathology for melanoma varies but typically involves atypical melanocytes spreading radially and/or penetrating the basement membrane.   
❌ Well-circumscribed pearly papule :
Incorrect: This describes a basal cell carcinoma. Pathology for basal cell carcinoma usually contains irregular basaloid cells.  
✅ Indurated, hyperkeratotic plaque with a 2mm area of ulceration :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Tan papule that appears “stuck on” :
Incorrect: This finding is consistent with seborrheic keratosis. Commonly described as “stuck on” lesions, they are a non-cancerous growth of keratinocytes.  
❌ Large ulcer with granulation tissue at the base  :
Incorrect: This describes a venous or arterial ulcer, both of which are usually found in the distal extremities of patients with peripheral vascular disease. This patient does not have a history of peripheral arterial disease and pathology is consistent with cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the primary care office for evaluation of a new lesion on his right hand. The lesion is within a prior scar from a ganglion cyst removed 15 years ago. Past medical history is significant for liver transplantation as a baby for biliary atresia and current medications include chronic immunosuppressants. On physical exam, the right-hand lesion is approximately 2 cm at its widest point and is a firm, irregular plaque with no areas of ulceration. Dermatoscopy shows several structureless areas. A punch biopsy is performed in the office and the subsequent pathology report confirms a mucin-producing cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma. The patient returns to the office for a discussion of treatment options. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents to the office with a 2 cm plaque on the right hand located in a chronic scar. Dermatoscopy indicates cellular atypia and biopsy shows that the lesion is a mucin-producing cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC). Given these findings and the patient’s chronic immunosuppression, this lesion is at high risk for recurrence and requires surgical management.         

Surgical excision is the preferred treatment for lesions that have features that place them at high and very high risk for recurrence. Excisions can include standard excision with wide 1 cm margins, Mohs micrographic surgery, and excision with adjuvant external beam radiotherapy. For patients with high or very high risk of recurrence who are not surgical candidates, treatment options include primary radiation therapy, chemotherapy, immunotherapy (e.g. anti-PD-1 antibodies), radiation therapy, and oral retinoids.        
A table outlining features that place lesions at high risk and very high risk for recurrence is shown below.  



Option Analysis

❌ Programmed cell death protein 1 (PD-1) therapy :
Incorrect: In patients who have high-risk cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma, surgery is preferred. However, if surgery is contraindicated, anti-PD-1 antibodies have shown efficacy in the treatment of locally advanced and metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in phase 1/2 trials.  
❌ Radiation therapy  :
Incorrect: The use of radiation therapy as primary therapy is typically reserved for older patients who are not surgical candidates because of comorbidities and for those who are not willing to undergo surgery. 
✅ Surgical excision :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Chemotherapy :
Incorrect: Conventional chemotherapy can be used in patients who are not surgical candidates. Surgery is the preferred treatment in this young patient with no contraindications to surgery. 
❌ Hand amputation   :
Incorrect: Amputation is not an appropriate treatment for cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma. Other bone or soft tissue tumors however may require amputation as a last resort.

questions.text: A 49-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for a routine check-up. The patient has a past medical history of squamous cell carcinoma treated with surgical excision 8 years ago. He is taking amlodipine for hypertension. He is concerned about his risk of developing melanoma because his maternal uncle passed away from metastatic melanoma at 68. He enjoys outdoor activities and spends several hours outside hiking per week. He is a Black man of African descent. Vitals are within normal limits. He has dark skin pigmentation, dark hair, and dark eyes. There is a small, symmetric nevus present on his right arm. Which of the following features in this patient’s history should prompt an annual skin examination to reduce his risk of developing melanoma?
questions.solution:
Skin cancer is one of the most common cancers in the United States, and the incidence of melanoma is increasing. Patients at increased risk for developing melanoma include those who are over 50 years old, and patients with sun sensitivity (ie. red or blonde hair, light eye color, light skin pigmentation, freckling). Nevi count greater than 50 with or without large atypical nevi, and family history of melanoma in one or more first-degree relatives or in more than one second-degree relative from the same side of the lineage are also risk factors. Immunosuppression and chronic immunosuppressive therapy place patients at increased risk for melanoma. A personal history of skin cancer (melanoma or nonmelanoma) as seen in this patient, is a risk factor for the development of melanoma. Patients who have had basal cell or squamous cell skin carcinomas have an increased risk of developing melanoma, as well as an increased risk of dying from it.    

Patients with any risk factor that places them at high risk should undergo regular dermatologic skin screening. Melanoma screening involves an annual comprehensive skin examination by a trained clinician skilled in melanoma identification. Patients should also be educated about melanoma risk factors and advised to inform their clinician if self-examination reveals any changes in moles or potentially concerning skin lesions.  



Option Analysis

❌ Current medication use:
Incorrect: Chronic use of medications that suppress the immune system (e.g. tacrolimus), can increase the risk of developing melanoma. Amlodipine has not been shown to increase the risk of developing skin cancers.
❌ Family history of malignant melanoma:
Incorrect: A family history of melanoma in one or more first-degree relatives or in more than one second-degree relative of the same lineage is considered a risk factor for developing melanoma. The history of melanoma in one maternal uncle does not increase his risk.
✅ Personal history of skin cancer:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Skin tone:
Incorrect: Patients who have sun-sensitive skin are at increased risk of developing melanoma. This includes patients with red or blonde hair, light eye color, light skin pigmentation, and freckling. However, this patient’s dark skin tone does not place him at increased risk.
❌ Presence of nevus:
Incorrect: A total nevi count above 50 and/or the presence of large (atypical/dysplastic) nevi would place a patient at high risk for developing melanoma. This patient has a single, small, symmetrical nevus and therefore not at increased risk from the presence of this nevus.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presents to the dermatology clinic concerned about a lesion on his upper back. He reports spending significant time outdoors due to his profession as a lifeguard, and he often forgets to reapply sunscreen after swimming. He recalls several instances of sunburns during his youth. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), blood pressure is 128/82 mm Hg, pulse is 76/min, respiratory rate is 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical examination reveals a number of pigmented lesions across the sun-exposed skin. The patient is fair-skinned. On his upper back, there is an asymmetrical raised lesion with irregular borders and a uniform dark color. Which of the following features is most indicative of the need for further evaluation of the lesion?

choices.text: Uniformity of the color of the lesion

questions.solution:
This patient, with significant sun exposure history and previous instances of sunburns, presents with a skin lesion that is asymmetrical with irregular borders. These features raise suspicion for melanoma, and further investigation with a biopsy is needed. Risk factors for melanoma include personal or family history of cutaneous malignancy, immunosuppression, fair skin, a tendency to sunburn, chronic sun exposure, and history of previous sunburns.

Melanoma is a malignant tumor arising from melanocytes that often presents with unique clinical characteristics that distinguish it from benign skin lesions. A number of factors taken together guide the decision of whether or not to biopsy a lesion in question. Clinically, the ABCDE criteria can serve as a guide for identifying suspicious lesions that need to be biopsied: Asymmetry, Border irregularity, Color variegation, Diameter over 6mm, and Evolution (change in size, color, or shape of a pre-existing lesion or report of a new growing lesion). Patient-reported symptoms such as itching, bleeding, or sensory changes in the lesion should heighten the suspicion of malignancy. Additionally, when a lesion looks conspicuously different (“ugly duckling” sign) from surrounding nevi (nevus phenotype) on the patient, then biopsy should be performed. Patients also may have systemic signs of malignancy including fatigue, bone pain, and unintentional weight loss.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Border irregularity of the lesion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Patient’s occupation as a lifeguard:
Incorrect: While a lifeguard's profession increases the risk of sun exposure and potential skin malignancies, it is not part of the determination for further evaluation. The appearance and features of the lesion itself are more pertinent to the diagnosis and evaluation of suspected melanoma.  
❌ Location on the upper back:
Incorrect: While the upper back is a frequent site for melanomas, location alone is not an indication for further evaluation of lesions that are suspicious for melanoma as melanomas like acral lentiginous melanoma can appear on less sun-exposed areas, like the palms and soles.  
❌ Uniformity of the color of the lesion:
Incorrect: Uniformity of color is generally reassuring and less suspicious for melanoma. Melanomas often display a variety of colors within one lesion, including black, brown, tan, red, blue, or white. Therefore, the consistent coloration of a lesion does not typically warrant immediate concern, but other characteristics of this lesion like asymmetry and irregular borders raise suspicion for melanoma.  
❌ Raised appearance of the lesion:
Incorrect: Raised appearance can be seen in both benign and malignant lesions. In this patient asymmetry and border irregularity raise suspicion for melanoma.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents to the primary care office for evaluation of a skin lesion on his cheek that has been present for the last six months. The lesion is painless and has not changed since he first noticed it, but it bleeds easily if he scratches it or it rubs on something. He has worked as a roofer for the last 30 years with frequent and prolonged sun exposure. Pulse is 62/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 118/78 mmHg. Examination of the right cheek reveals a 1.7 mm raised, symmetrical, pearly pink skin lesion with smooth borders and overlying telangiectasias. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with a smooth, pearly pink skin lesion with overlying telangiectasias that bleeds easily and has not changed notably in six months most likely has basal cell carcinoma. Basal cell carcinomas are common in sun-exposed areas of the skin, such as the face; and this patient’s work as a roofer likely contributed to his risk given the high amount of UV light exposure.

Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is a malignant skin lesion, which typically does not metastasize but can cause significant morbidity due to local tissue destruction. The primary risk factor for basal cell carcinoma is UV light exposure with high intensity of sun exposure. A history of early childhood or adolescent burns; tanning bed use; and prolonged sun exposure, such as with working outdoors, all increase the risk. Other risk factors include patient-specific factors, such as being sun sensitive with fair skin, light-colored eyes, and red hair; being immunosuppressed; exposure to ionizing radiation; and genetic predisposition.

Basal cell carcinoma commonly presents on sun-exposed areas of the skin, such as the head and neck. The appearance can vary, but the most common type is the nodular type; which presents with a pink or flesh-colored “pearly” papular lesion with smooth edges, a raised or “rolled” border, and occasionally a central ulceration. If left untreated, these lesions may enlarge and develop a fungating appearance with erosion into the skin surface.  

Option Analysis

✅ Basal cell carcinoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Melanoma:
Incorrect: Classic features of melanoma include notable changes to an existing lesion over time, asymmetry, irregular borders, more than one color, and size larger than 6mm. This patient’s lesion is symmetrical with smooth borders; a single color; and has classic features of a basal cell carcinoma, such as a pearly appearance.  
❌ Actinic keratosis:
Incorrect: An actinic keratosis is a premalignant lesion with a dry, rough, or scaly appearance. This patient’s lesion is smooth and pearly, which is more characteristic of a basal cell carcinoma.  
❌ Seborrheic keratosis:
Incorrect: A seborrheic keratosis is a benign lesion with a dry, rough, “stuck-on” appearance. The color can vary, but they are often shades of brown. This patient’s lesion is smooth, pearly, and pink in color with telangiectasias, which is more characteristic of a basal cell carcinoma.
❌ Keratosis pilaris:
Incorrect: Keratosis pilaris is a benign skin condition characterized by clusters of flesh-colored small papules surrounded by dry skin, usually on the cheeks, upper arms, thighs, or buttocks. It is more common in younger patients. This patient’s age and the presence of a single lesion makes basal cell carcinoma much more likely.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents to his primary care physician's office for evaluation of a dark brown skin lesion on his left upper extremity as seen in the image below. He states that he has had this lesion for several years, but his partner thought that it appeared different and suggested that he have it evaluated. The patient has a significant history of sun exposure. He was a swimmer and lifeguard throughout his childhood and into his young adulthood. He rarely used sunscreen and had several bad burns in his youth. He has a history of basal cell carcinoma on his face that was removed. His only medication is lisinopril for high blood pressure. Vital signs are within normal limits. Which of the following physical examination findings would prompt a further diagnostic evaluation of this lesion?
questions.solution:
This man presents to the primary care office with a concerning skin lesion in the setting of a significant history of sun exposure and prior burns. The patient’s wife believes that the lesion is evolving over time. Given his age and risk factors, he is at high risk for melanoma. The finding of a lesion with a diameter of 9 mm is concerning for melanoma and should prompt further evaluation with a biopsy.

Melanoma is the most serious form of skin cancer and the fifth most common cancer in males and females in the United States. When patients present with concerning lesions they should be questioned about whether, and how the lesion has changed over time, when it was first noticed, and whether the patient has a personal or family history of melanoma or other skin cancers. Additional questions should focus on the patient’s history of sun exposure, tanning bed use, severe sun burns, and immunosuppression.

Physical examination should evaluate for concerning findings which are included in the ABCDE criteria: asymmetry, border irregularity, color variation, diameter > 6 mm, and evolution over time. If any of these criteria are met, further diagnosis should be pursued. It is also important to include a thorough examination of the adjacent lymph node basins when malignancy is suspected.  

Option Analysis

❌ Uniform color:
Incorrect: Uniform color without any color variation would be more suggestive of a nevus, opposed to a melanoma, which can exhibit various color shades. Uniform color would not be an indication for further workups.  
❌ Well circumscribed borders:
Incorrect: In general, lesions or masses that are well-circumscribed are typically benign. Lesions that have irregular borders are typically more worrisome for melanoma. A lesion having well-circumscribed borders would not prompt further evaluation.  
✅ Diameter of 9 mm:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Symmetrical lesion:
Incorrect: Symmetrical lesions are most likely benign and would not require further workup. Asymmetrical lesions are more worrisome for melanoma and would prompt further diagnostic evaluation.  
❌ Soft, rubbery, mobile mass:
Incorrect: This description matches that of a lipoma. While an ultrasound can confirm the diagnosis, it is usually unnecessary.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man presents to his primary care physician's office for evaluation of a new skin lesion on the abdomen. The patient noticed the lesion while showering 3 weeks ago. He has no significant past medical history. Physical exam shows a 3 mm dome-shaped, red lesion on the abdomen that does not blanch with pressure as seen in the image below. Which of the following additional findings would be most consistent with the likely diagnosis?
 
Wikipedia

choices.text: Increase in size of the lesion after weight loss
Multiple similar lesions that have appeared over time

questions.solution:
This man presents to the office for evaluation of a new skin lesion on his abdomen that appears as a 3 mm dome-shaped, red lesion on the abdomen that does not blanch with pressure. This description is typical of a cherry angioma. The finding of multiple similar lesions that have appeared over time would be consistent with the diagnosis, as cherry angiomas typically increase in number and size as patients age.

Cherry angiomas (Campbell de Morgan spots) are made up of mature capillary proliferations that are common in middle-aged and older adult patients. They are benign vascular tumors. They tend to be less conspicuous in patients with darkly pigmented skin and are most common on the trunk. They may bleed significantly with trauma.

Cherry angiomas appear as dome shaped red to dark red lesions that are typically 0.1 to 0.4 cm in diameter, and they do not blanch with pressure. Diagnosis is based on clinical appearance. Examination with a dermatoscope will show characteristic red, purple, or blue-black lagoons. They do not need to be treated unless patients are bothered by them.  

Option Analysis

❌ Associated pruritus:
Incorrect: Cutaneous warts are caused by infection with the human papillomavirus, or HPV. They typically appear on the fingers of children or young adults and may cause mild pain or pruritus. Cherry angiomas as seen in this patient do not typically cause pruritus.  
❌ Increase in size of the lesion after weight loss:
Incorrect: Lipomas are fatty tumors that typically reside in the subcutaneous space. They are soft, rubbery, round, mobile masses located on the head, neck, shoulders, and back. They can become more prominent after weight loss due to a reduction in subcutaneous fat levels.  
✅ Multiple similar lesions that have appeared over time:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Associated purulence:
Incorrect: Epidermoid or sebaceous cysts can have purulent discharge if they become infected. Cherry angiomas do not typically develop a purulent discharge.  
❌ Associated pain:
Incorrect: Painful tumors of the skin typically present as dermal or subcutaneous nodules. They can originate from many sources including eccrine glands, fibrous tissue, infiltration of benign (endometrium) or malignant (metastatic neoplasm) tissue, muscle, nerve, or vascular structures. Cherry angiomas are not typically associated with pain.

questions.text: An 82-year-old woman was brought to the emergency department from a nursing home for evaluation of altered mental status and fever for the past three days. Medical history includes well-controlled type II diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and a right middle cerebral artery stroke that occurred five years ago. The patient has limited mobility and is largely bedbound. Temperature is 38.7°C (102°F), blood pressure is 179/98 mmHg, and pulse is 83/min. Physical examination reveals a 10 x 10 x 3 cm wound in the gluteal region as shown in the image below. Which of the following best describes the underlying cause of this patient’s physical examination findings?

choices.text: Prolonged pressure over the affected region

questions.solution:
This patient has an area of soft tissue necrosis and surrounding erythema in the gluteal region. These findings combined with a history of immobility are most suggestive of a pressure-induced soft tissue injury.   

Pressure-induced soft tissue injury (also termed pressure ulcers or bed sores) describes damage to the skin and underlying soft tissues caused by prolonged pressure. Pressure injuries most commonly develop over bony prominences, such as the sacrum, greater trochanter, scapula, and occiput. Prolonged pressure decreases blood flow to the affected skin and soft tissues, leading to hypoxia, ischemia, and necrosis.  

Patients often have a history of risk factors such as immobility, malnutrition, neurological diseases (e.g., stroke, neuropathy), diabetes mellitus, or perfusion disorders (e.g., heart failure, peripheral vascular disease). Affected patients typically experience pain at the site of injury.  

It is important to assess the wound bed and depth since they are the most important factors in determining the grade of the injury which will determine the treatment. The soft tissue surrounding the wound should be checked for skin color and edema, which can identify the presence of infection. There may be signs of wound healing, such as granulation tissue and epithelialization.  

Option Analysis

❌ Infection with spore-forming gram-positive bacteria  :
Incorrect: Bacillus anthracis is a spore-forming gram-positive rod. The pathogen can cause cutaneous anthrax, which manifests with areas of tissue necrosis termed eschars. A pressure-induced soft tissue injury and not anthrax is more likely the cause of this bed bound patient’s lesion.  
❌ Infection with flea-borne gram-negative bacteria  :
Incorrect: Yersinia pestis is a gram-negative bacillus transmitted by fleas. The pathogen is responsible for the historical bubonic plague. Clinically, infection with Yersinia pestis leads to swollen and painful lymph nodes, but it can also lead to cutaneous manifestations (e.g., eschars, pustules). It is more likely that this bed bound patient has a pressure-induced ulcer.  
❌ Neoplastic proliferation of malignant cells  :
Incorrect: This patient has a history of prior stroke and immobility. Physical examination reveals tissue necrosis in the left gluteal region. These findings favor a pressure ulcer over a neoplastic process.  
✅ Prolonged pressure over the affected region  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Chronic hyperglycemia  :
Incorrect: In general, diabetes mellitus and hyperglycemia can increase a patient’s risk of developing pressure ulcers and infection, and patients with peripheral neuropathy from poorly controlled diabetes can develop diabetic foot ulcers. In this bed bound patient with well-controlled diabetes, prolonged sacral pressure would be the primary underlying cause of the decubitus ulcer. Prolonged pressure causes tissue hypoxia, ischemia, and necrosis.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a burn injury. According to paramedics, the patient was involved in a house fire with delayed extrication. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 107/63 mmHg, pulse is 115/min, and oxygen saturation is 78% on room air. Physical examination reveals partial-thickness burns over the chest, back, arms, and legs. The patient is ill-appearing and unable to provide a history. The patient has evidence of soot about the nares and mouth and lip swelling. The patient is provided with intravenous fluids and a nonrebreather face mask is applied. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of partial-thickness burns and evidence of inhalation injury on examination. Given the patient's ill appearance, evidence of hypoxia, and concerns for impending respiratory failure the best next step in management is rapid sequence intubation.

Burns injuries caused by heat, friction, radiation, electricity, or chemical exposure can result in irreversible tissue destruction. Extensive tissue destruction, particularly burns larger than 40% of the total body surface area (TBSA) can cause fluid loss and evidence of shock. Burns are classified based on the depth of injury into first-, second-, third-, and fourth-degree burns, as well as burns accompanied by smoke inhalation, or inhalation injuries.

Acute management of patient's presenting with burn injuries includes assessment of the airway, breathing, and circulation. With specific regards to the airway, patients with evidence of significant edema, hypoxia, or other evidence of inhalation injury (e.g. soot around the nose or mouth) should undergo rapid sequence intubation. Delays in performing this procedure may result in airway compromise secondary to rapidly progressing edema. Additional management considerations include obtaining intravenous access, administering intravenous fluids, and addressing any associated bleeding or unstable traumatic injuries.  

Option Analysis

✅ Rapid sequence intubation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Arterial blood gas analysis:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of hypoxemia, tongue and lip swelling, as well as concern for inhalation injury. This patient should receive rapid sequence intubation for acute airway stabilization.  
❌ Chest x-ray:
Incorrect: A chest x-ray may provide useful information including associated trauma or evidence of airway edema. However, this patient's acute airway instability should be addressed first via rapid sequence intubation.  
❌ Escharotomy:
Incorrect: An escharotomy should be performed for patients presenting with circumferential full-thickness burns and evidence of ischemia. This patient has evidence of partial-thickness burns.  
❌ Hi-flow nasal cannula:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of hypoxemia, tongue and lip swelling, as well as concern for inhalation injury. The patient should receive rapid sequence intubation for acute airway stabilization.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a burn. The patient was opening the lid of his grill and was exposed to a large flame. The patient is currently experiencing pain to the lips, mouth, and nose. He has no other medical history and does not take any medications. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 127/63 mmHg, pulse is 112/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination reveals a singed mustache as well as wheezing during inspiration and expiration. The patient is coughing up sputum with specks of carbonaceous material. An arterial blood gas and chest radiograph are obtained, both of which are unremarkable. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with evidence of inhalation injury including singed facial hair, carbonaceous sputum, and wheezing on examination. The best next step in management is admission for bronchoscopy and airway monitoring. Bronchoscopy is used to diagnose inhalation injury in patients with history and physical findings, like singed facial hair, that are suggestive. Bronchoscopy can also be used to clear secretions.

Burns injuries caused by heat, friction, radiation, electricity, or chemical exposure can result in irreversible tissue destruction. Extensive tissue destruction, particularly burns larger than 40% of the total body surface area (TBSA) can cause fluid loss and evidence of shock. Burns are classified based on the depth of injury into first-, second-, third-, and fourth-degree burns, as well as burns accompanied by smoke inhalation, or inhalation injuries.

Stable patients presenting with a burn injury should undergo a thorough history and physical examination to better characterize the type of burn present.
