The mechanism of exposure may reveal the type of injury.  For example, patients with prolonged extrication, facial burns, or prolonged smoke exposure may be at increased risk of inhalation injury. In contrast, patients with thermal burns will typically have exposure to heated water, fire, or chemicals.

Patients with concerns for inhalation injury should undergo a thorough evaluation to better characterize the extent of injury. The face should be closely examined for evidence of singed facial hair, oropharyngeal edema, voice changes, as well as evidence of wheezing or respiratory distress. Patients with suspected inhalation injury should have an arterial blood gas and carboxyhemoglobin level, as well as a chest radiograph. However, ABG and chest radiographs may be normal early after the injury. Serial chest radiographs may be obtained.

Management of inhalation injury in a stable patient  includes administering high-flow oxygen to maintain oxygen saturations above 90%. If the patient develops drooling, wheezing, or stridor, or is unable to maintain oxygen saturations higher than 90%, they should be intubated.  

Option Analysis

✅ Admit for bronchoscopy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Discharge with primary care follow-up:
Incorrect: Discharge with primary care follow-up is not appropriate management for this patient. This patient has evidence of inhalation injury and should be admitted for further monitoring and workup.  
❌ Administer piperacillin-tazobactam:
Incorrect: Administration of empiric antibiotics is not indicated in the management of acute inhalation injury.  
❌ Perform surgical escharotomy:
Incorrect: An escharotomy should be performed for patients presenting with circumferential full-thickness burns and evidence of ischemia. No such findings are present in this patient.  
❌ Consult gastroenterology for endoscopy:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation is not consistent with acute upper gastrointestinal hemorrhage, which typically manifests with melena or hematemesis. This patient’s presentation is concerning for an inhalation injury and can be evaluated further via bronchoscopy.

questions.text: A 77-year-old woman was brought to the emergency department from a nursing home for evaluation of pain and increased irritability for three days. Medical history is notable for type II diabetes mellitus, Alzheimer dementia, and a left middle cerebral artery stroke that occurred nine-years ago. The patient has limited mobility and is largely bedbound. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 129/73 mmHg, and pulse is 83/min. Physical examination reveals the findings seen below in the sacral region. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient’s cutaneous findings?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a lesion demonstrating partial loss of the dermis without exposure to subcutaneous fat, muscle, or bone. These findings are consistent with a stage II pressure ulcer, which can be managed conservatively with cushioned dressings.  

Pressure ulcer management depends on its staging. Stage I (intact skin with non-blanchable erythema and no signs of necrosis) and stage II wounds (shallow, open ulcer with partial thickness loss of dermis) require local management. Treatment involves keeping the wound moist with medicated gauze and decreasing pressure and friction with cushioned dressings. If the patient is bed or wheelchair-bound, pressure on affected areas can be reduced by frequent repositioning on specialized support surfaces such as foam wedges, cushioned seating, or water beds.  

Stage III (full-thickness loss of skin and exposure to subcutaneous fat) and stage IV (exposure of underlying muscle, tendon, or bone) require more invasive therapies. Deeper wounds tend to have more fibrinous exudate and necrotic tissue, which requires chemical or surgical debridement to prevent infection. Once the wound bed is clean, a negative pressure wound dressing can be applied to reduce bacterial growth and promote granulation tissue formation. Stage IV wounds heal poorly on their own and may require an autologous tissue graft.  
 

Option Analysis

❌ Surgical debridement:
Incorrect: Surgical debridement may be indicated for the management of stage III and IV pressure ulcers or to help stage wounds that cannot be visualized due to the presence of eschar. Stage III and Stage IV pressure ulcers are characterized by full-thickness skin loss and exposure of the underlying tissue (e.g., adipose, muscle, bone). This patient’s pressure ulcer is a shallow lesion with partial thickness loss extending to the dermis. It is most consistent with a stage II pressure ulcer, which does not require surgical intervention.  
✅ Cushioned dressings   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Skin biopsy  :
Incorrect: Biopsy is not typically indicated in the management of pressure ulcers.  
❌ Intravenous antibiotics   :
Incorrect: Local antibiotic ointments may be indicated if there is concern for concurrent cellulitis in patients with pressure ulcers. Systemic antibiotics would not be necessary in this case given the lack of severe localized infection (e.g. osteomyelitis) or systemic infection (e.g. sepsis)  
❌ Negative pressure dressing:
Incorrect: Negative pressure dressings help reduce bacterial growth and improve granulation tissue formation. They are used in the management of stage III and IV pressure ulcers. In contrast, this patient has a stage II pressure ulcer. Negative pressure dressings are not used in the management of stage II pressure ulcers.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a painful burn to the right hand. The patient was moving a pot of boiling hot water off the stove when he accidentally spilled the water onto his right hand. The patient has no medical history and does not take any medications. Temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F), blood pressure is 166/73 mmHg, pulse is 96/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination reveals a 3 cm circular area of erythema, warmth, blistering, and blanching on the dorsum of the right hand not extending to joints or fingers. Pain is elicited with palpation of the dorsum of the right hand. Which of the following correctly describes this patient's injury pattern?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of a painful burn injury to the right hand with evidence of redness, warmth, blanching, and blistering. These findings are consistent with a partial-thickness (second-degree burn).

Burns injuries caused by heat, friction, radiation, electricity, or chemical exposure can result in irreversible tissue destruction. Extensive tissue destruction, particularly burns larger than 40% of the total body surface area (TBSA) can cause fluid loss and evidence of shock. Burns are classified based on the depth of injury into first-, second-, third-, and fourth-degree burns, as well as burns accompanied by smoke inhalation, or inhalation injuries.

The evaluation of a patient presenting with a burn injury begins with understanding the mechanism of exposure. Patients with inhalation injury will typically have prolonged exposure to smoke or heat (e.g. fire in an enclosed space). These patients will typically develop facial burns, wheezing, stridor, and carbonaceous sputum. Alternatively, patients may have a history of direct thermal injury, like the patient in this case. Further characterization of a thermal burn based on the depth of injury is paramount for determining appropriate management.
 

Once the burn has been characterized as a second-, third-, or fourth-degree burn, the TBSA should be calculated using one of the accepted methods to help determine the appropriate treatment. Then a decision should be made if the patient can be treated as an outpatient or inpatient, or should be transferred to a dedicated burn center.  

Option Analysis

✅ Partial thickness burn:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ First-degree burn:
Incorrect: First-degree burns, also known as superficial burns, present with pain and redness, with the injury extending to the epidermis only. Blistering is not typically present in first-degree burns.  
❌ Third-degree burn:
Incorrect: Third-degree burns extend into the subcutaneous fat and typically present with little to no pain. These burns do not blanch with pressure.  
❌ Fourth-degree burn:
Incorrect: Fourth-degree burns extend to the muscle, bone, and tendon. These burn injuries typically present with a fully charred injury, with little to no pain.  
❌ Full-thickness burn:
Incorrect: Full-thickness burns are also known as third-degree burns. They extend into the subcutaneous fat, present with little to no pain, and do not blanch with pressure.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presents to the emergency department for burns sustained to his thighs and palms of the hands while playing with matches in a garage. The patient weighs 48 kg and has a height of 135 cm. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse 80/min, respirations 20/min, and blood pressure 105/75 mmHg. Physical examination reveals bilateral circumferential wounds from ankle to mid-thigh and burns on both palms. The patient is admitted to the burn unit and initiated on intravenous fluids and a topical antibiotic ointment containing bacitracin. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of bacitracin?

choices.text: Binds to transpeptidases and inhibits cross-linking of peptidoglycan in bacterial cell wall
Inhibits peptidoglycan cell wall formation by binding to the D-Ala-D-Ala portion of cell wall precursors
Blocks peptidyl transferase at 50s ribosomal subunit
Inhibits transport of peptidoglycan proteins across the cell membrane

questions.solution:
This patient has sustained partial thickness burns on the hands and legs and is being treated with an antibiotic ointment containing bacitracin. Bacitracin is an antibiotic agent active against gram-positive cocci, including Staphylococcus aureus, Staphylococcus epidermidis, and Streptococcus pyogenes. It inhibits bactoprenol phosphate, a transmembrane transporter embedded within the bacterial cell membrane. Bactoprenol phosphate promotes the transport of N-acetyl-muramic acid and N-acetyl mucopeptides that form components of the bacterial cell wall. Bacitracin inhibits the transport of these mucopeptides and inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis.

Bacitracin is commonly used for topical application in partial thickness burns, particularly those that involve the face and the perineum, and for photokeratitis. Topical agents are used cautiously in patients with impaired renal function and neurotoxic or nephrotoxic adverse effects.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Inhibits dihydropteroate synthase:
Incorrect: Sulfamethoxazole inhibits dihydropteroate synthase, an enzyme that is involved in folate synthesis. It is bacteriostatic when combined with trimethoprim. However, it is not used topically in the treatment of burns.  
❌ Binds to transpeptidases and inhibits cross-linking of peptidoglycan in bacterial cell wall:
Incorrect: Penicillin and modified penicillins are beta-lactam antibiotics that bind to transpeptidases and inhibit cross-linking within the cell wall.  
❌ Inhibits peptidoglycan cell wall formation by binding to the D-Ala-D-Ala portion of cell wall precursors:
Incorrect: Vancomycin directly binds to D-Ala D-Ala portions of the cell wall. It is a systemic agent in treating MRSA (+) skin and soft tissue infections. In the absence of a previous episode of MRSA or lack of clinical improvement in 48 hours, IV vancomycin is not likely indicated.  
❌ Blocks peptidyl transferase at 50s ribosomal subunit:
Incorrect: Chloramphenicol is an antimicrobial agent that targets the 50s ribosomal subunit. Its use is limited due to the hematologic toxicity associated with its use. Gentamicin (which targets the initiation complex of the 30s subunit) can be used topically.  
✅ Inhibits transport of peptidoglycan proteins across the cell membrane:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the office for evaluation of a wound that has been present on his right ankle for two months. He has had swelling of both legs and wounds at the same spot in the past, but they resolved without treatment. This time, his wound started as a small area of erythema, but over the ensuing weeks, it has widened in diameter and occasionally crusts over. The patient has not had fevers or chills. His past medical history is notable for poorly controlled insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (IDDM) with a recent Hemoglobin A1c of 8.2. His BMI is 36 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. He has not experienced any cramping pain while walking or leg pain in the middle of the night. He can walk several blocks without pain in his lower extremities. Vital signs are within normal limits. On exam, there is a 4cm ulcer on the medial malleolus of his right lower extremity that has granulation tissue at the base. There is clear drainage from the wound. There is surrounding reddish-brown skin discoloration but no signs of infection. Both legs have bilateral 2+ pitting edema to the mid-calves and multiple reddish-brownish spots. Dorsalis pedis and posterior tibialis pulses are 2+ bilaterally.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient’s symptoms, risk factors, and physical exam (i.e. bilateral lower extremity edema and medial malleolar ulcer with granulation tissue) are consistent with a venous ulcer. Venous ulcers are typically located between the knee and the ankle, with the medial and lateral malleolus being the most common sites. Patients generally describe a dull ache at the site of the ulcer and increased swelling of the involved extremity that improves with elevation. A history of recurrence of an ulcer in the same area is highly suggestive of a venous ulcer.

Venous ulcers are generally shallow and irregular with a wound bed lined with beefy red granulation tissue. Sometimes, a layer of superficial fibrinous gelatinous material is present, with a granulated wound bed underneath. The skin surrounding the ulcer can be eczematous, presenting with scaling, weeping and crusting that can be intensely pruritic. The leg is usually edematous, firm and warm with reddish-brown hyperpigmentation from hemosiderin deposits from chronic venous insufficiency. Dilated tortuous superficial veins may be visible on the surface.

Treatment of venous ulcers typically involves static compression therapy with hosiery or bandages, control of risk factors such as diabetes, and an exercise program. There isn’t an optimal dressing for venous ulcers, but wounds should be kept clean and dry.  

Option Analysis

❌ Arterial insufficiency ulcer:
Incorrect: Arterial insufficiency ulcers are typically punched-out, pale, gray, or yellow ulcers with dry bases often located at the distal ends of digits like the toes. Patients usually report claudication or rest pain of the affected extremity and have a history of peripheral arterial disease, atherosclerosis, or smoking. This patient does not have a physical exam or history consistent with an ulcer due to arterial insufficiency.  
❌ Diabetic ulcer:
Incorrect: Diabetic ulcers commonly occur in locations that experience repeated trauma, such as the plantar metatarsal heads and dorsal interphalangeal joints caused by pressure during ambulation. While this patient has diabetes, his ulcer is not characteristic of a diabetic ulcer.  
✅ Venous ulcer:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Pyoderma gangrenosum:
Incorrect: Pyoderma gangrenosum (PG) is an uncommon neutrophilic dermatosis that presents as an inflammatory papule or pustule that progresses to a painful ulcer with a violaceous undermined border and a purulent base. It is often associated with underlying systemic diseases including Inflammatory bowel disease, hematologic disorders, and inflammatory arthritis.  
❌ Pressure ulcer:
Incorrect: Typically, patients with pressure ulcers have a history of immobility, like being bed- or wheelchair-bound, and poor nutrition. They are typically found in areas of high pressure, such as the sacrum or ischium. This patient has an ulcer in a non-pressure area and does not have risk factors for pressure ulcers.

questions.text: A 73-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after family members noticed a new skin lesion. The patient has been nonverbal and mostly bed bound since suffering a right middle cerebral artery stroke two years ago. The patient’s daughter is his primary caregiver, and she states that she first noticed the lesion on the patient’s buttocks the day prior to admission. Additional past medical history is notable for type II diabetes mellitus and left hip fracture status-post-internal fixation. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 137/82 mmHg, and pulse is 90/min. Physical examination reveals an area of skin necrosis overlying the sacrum. Which of the following findings would lead to classifying the patient’s lesion as a stage III pressure ulcer?

choices.text: Shallow ulcer with partial erosion of the dermis
Full-thickness skin loss with exposure of subcutaneous fat
Full thickness skin loss with exposure of underlying muscle
Lesion with internal debris and eschar where depth cannot be measured

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a new skin lesion over the sacrum that is concerning for a pressure-induced skin injury, also known as a pressure ulcer. Stage III pressure ulcers are characterized by full thickness skin loss with exposure of underlying subcutaneous fat.   

Pressure ulcers are classified into four categories based on the depth of involvement, which is determined via physical examination.  

Stage I injuries present as intact skin with non-blanchable erythema and no necrosis. Stage II wounds have a shallow, open ulcer with partial thickness loss of the dermis. Stage III pressure injuries include full-thickness loss of skin and exposure to subcutaneous fat. Finally, stage IV injuries are characterized by full-thickness skin loss as well as exposure of the underlying muscle, tendon, or bone.  

Some pressure ulcers contain so much internal debris and eschars that their depth cannot be accurately assessed. These ulcers are considered unstageable. Surgical debridement should be performed to expose the wound bed and allow for better wound staging.  


Option Analysis

❌ Intact and erythematous skin   :
Incorrect: A stage I pressure ulcer is characterized by intact skin, nonblanchable erythema, and no necrosis. A stage III pressure ulcer is characterized by full-thickness skin loss with associated exposure to subcutaneous fat.  
❌ Shallow ulcer with partial erosion of the dermis  :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes a stage II pressure ulcer. A stage III pressure ulcer is characterized by full-thickness skin loss with associated exposure of subcutaneous fat.  
✅ Full-thickness skin loss with exposure of subcutaneous fat  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Full thickness skin loss with exposure of underlying muscle   :
Incorrect: A stage IV pressure ulcer is characterized by full thickness skin loss with exposure of underlying muscle, tendons, and bone.  
❌ Lesion with internal debris and eschar where depth cannot be measured  :
Incorrect: Some pressure ulcers contain so much internal debris and eschars that their depth cannot be characterized. In these cases, surgical debridement should be performed to expose the wound bed to allow for better wound staging.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents for evaluation of burn injuries. The patient was cooking in the kitchen when she accidentally spilled hot grease over her upper body. The patient has no other medical history and does not take any medications. Temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F), blood pressure is 127/53 mmHg, pulse is 103/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination reveals partial-thickness burns to the chest, left arm, and lower left face. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Admit for intravenous fluids and pain/wound management

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of partial-thickness burns to the chest, arm, as well as lower face.  Based on these physical examination findings, the next best step in management is to admit the patient for intravenous fluids, wound management, and pain control.

Burns injuries caused by heat, friction, radiation, electricity, or chemical exposure can result in irreversible tissue destruction. Extensive tissue destruction, particularly burns larger than 40% of the total body surface area (TBSA) can cause fluid loss and evidence of shock. Burns are classified based on the depth of injury into first-, second-, third-, and fourth-degree burns, as well as burns accompanied by smoke inhalation, or inhalation injuries.

Management of thermal burns depends on the type of burn and degree of injury present. First-degree or superficial burns can be managed with irrigation with cool tap water and soap as well as analgesia (e.g., aloe vera, over-the-counter analgesia).

Patients with second-degree or partial-thickness burns should be managed based on the location of injury and extent of burn per the rule of nines or another accepted method for determining TBSA. Patients with second-degree burns and TBSA greater than 10% as well as patients with burns to the face, hands, perineum, feet, or over joints should be admitted to the hospital for further management.

All patients with third-degree (full-thickness) burns and fourth-degree burns should also be admitted for further management.

Patients requiring admission should have basic labs obtained to screen for underlying metabolic abnormalities and receive fluid resuscitation as calculated using the Parkland formula (4 ml/kg * %total body surface area burn * weight). Patients with partial-thickness burns may need debridement and skin grafting. Patients with circumferential burns and evidence of compartment syndrome should be considered for escharotomy. Pain management and high protein nutrition should also be ordered for all patients with burns.   

Option Analysis

✅ Admit for intravenous fluids and pain/wound management:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Admit for bronchoscopy:
Incorrect: Stable patients with history and physical exam findings consistent with inhalation injury should be admitted for bronchoscopy and further monitoring due to the high risk of airway compromise. This patient does not have evidence of inhalation injury.  
❌ Discharge with primary care follow-up:
Incorrect: Discharge with primary care follow-up would not be appropriate. This patient has evidence of partial thickness burns to a total body surface area greater than 10%, and she should be admitted to the hospital for further management.  
❌ Admit for hyperbaric therapy:
Incorrect: Hyperbaric therapy is indicated for patients with severe carbon monoxide injury. Hyperbaric therapy can also be used for complex wound healing. However, It is not indicated in the acute management of partial-thickness burns.  
❌ Escharotomy:
Incorrect: An escharotomy should be performed for patients presenting with circumferential full-thickness burns and evidence of ischemia. This patient has evidence of partial-thickness burns.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department after sustaining a burn injury to the right medial ankle. The patient reports that he was riding his motorcycle without shoes and his foot accidentally came into contact with the muffler. The patient has no past medical history and does not take any medication. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 177/90 mmHg, pulse is 101/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination reveals a 10 cm circular area above the medial malleolus with erythema and visible subcutaneous fat that is not painful to touch. Which of the following best describes this injury?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of a direct thermal burn from contact with a hot muffler.  Based on examination which shows erythema and exposed subcutaneous fatty tissue, this patient’s burn is considered a grade 3 (full-thickness) thermal burn.

Chemical, electrical, thermal, and radiation exposure can result in burn injuries which are categorized by depth of exposure (e.g. burn grades). Burns are graded 1-4, grade 1 burns are superficial and limited to the epidermis with overlying erythematous changes, and they are painful; Grade 2 burns, or partial thickness burns affect the epidermis and dermis. They appear red, moist, with associated blistering, and they are painful; Grade 3 full-thickness burns affect the epidermis, dermis, and subcutaneous tissue, forming an eschar. They appear white/brown with a dry, leathery appearance and are not painful. Grade 4 burns extend to bone and appear as dark, charred tissue and they are not painful. In addition to assessing the grade of burn injuries, it is also necessary to determine the surface area impacted, in order to calculate the fluid resuscitation needed with use of the Parkland formula.  

Option Analysis

❌ Grade 1 thermal burn:
Incorrect: Superficial, or grade 1, burns are superficial and limited to the epidermis with mild erythema. This patient has evidence of exposed fatty tissue which would be considered a grade 3 burn. This patient has a thermal grade 3 burn from direct contact with the hot muffler.  
❌ Grade 1 chemical burn:
Incorrect: Chemical burns typically result from skin contact with strong acids, drain cleaners, paint thinner, gasoline and other substances. This patient’s clinical history is consistent with a Grade 3 thermal burn from contact with a hot muffler.  
❌ Grade 2 thermal burn:
Incorrect: Partial thickness, or grade 2, burns involve the dermis and are characterized by blisters, erythematous changes, and severe tenderness. This patient has evidence of exposed fatty tissue which would be considered a grade 3 burn. This patient has a grade 3 thermal burn from direct contact with the hot muffler.  
✅ Grade 3 thermal burn:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Grade 4 thermal burn:
Incorrect: Grade 4 burns involve the bone. These burns often appear black or charred. This patient has evidence of exposed fatty tissue but not bone, which would be considered a grade 3 burn. This patient has a grade 3 thermal burn from direct contact with the hot muffler.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents to the emergency department from a rehabilitation facility for evaluation of a wound on her left heel. She was hospitalized and received IV antibiotics for the same issue three weeks ago. Her symptoms resolved and she was discharged to rehab. However, she was brought back to the ED today because the wound care nurse felt that her left heel was re-infected. She has not had fevers or chills. She takes insulin for IDDM and rivaroxaban for atrial fibrillation. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 115/min and irregular, blood pressure is 110/72 mmHg, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 100% on room air. Labs are pending. Physical exam is notable for a pressure ulcer on her left heel that has subcutaneous fat present and tunnels 3 cm in all directions. There is surrounding erythema and induration but no purulence. What is the stage of this ulcer, and what is the most appropriate treatment?

choices.text: Stage 2 → bedside debridement and moist dressings
Stage 3 → operative debridement, moist dressings, and consider skin grafting
Stage 3 → bedside debridement and moist dressings
Stage 4 → bedside debridement to properly stage

questions.solution:
This patient has a Stage 3 pressure ulcer on the bony prominence of her left heel. Stage 3 ulcers require operative debridement, moist dressings, and planning for future wound coverage, which may include skin grafting.

Pressure-induced skin and soft tissue injuries are localized areas of damage to the skin and underlying tissue that usually occur over bony prominences as a result of pressure or pressure in combination with shear forces (eg, sacrum, calcaneus, ischium). Lesions are typically related to immobility but can also result from poorly fitting casts or other medical equipment or devices. The management of pressure-induced skin and soft tissue injuries begins with a clinical assessment of the wound and a comprehensive assessment of the patient's general medical condition and risk factors to identify reversible conditions that can be managed.

Signs and symptoms of pressure ulcers can include pain, infection, subcutaneous tracking, and there may rarely be underlying malignancy. Several staging systems have been developed to describe the extent of pressure-induced injury to the skin. The most commonly used system is the National Pressure Injury Advisory Panel (NPIAP) (see table above). Staging the pressure injury helps guide treatment.

In general, treatment of pressure injuries should address the following: pain control, treatment of infection if present, redistribution of pressure, optimization of nutrition, and local wound care. Stage 1 ulcers require local wound care. Stage 2 ulcers require bedside debridement, and Stage 3 and 4 ulcers require operative debridement and potential wound coverage.  

Option Analysis

❌ Stage 2 → bedside debridement and moist dressings:
Incorrect: Stage 2 pressure ulcers have partial-thickness skin loss with exposed dermis. The wound bed is viable, pink or red, moist, and may also present as an intact or ruptured serum-filled blister. There is no fat showing typically. While bedside debridement and moist dressings is appropriate management for stage 2 ulcers, this patient has exposed fat, making her ulcer Stage 3.  
❌ Stage 2 → cover for protection:
Incorrect: Management of stage 2 ulcers requires debridement of infected and necrotic tissue with subsequent moist dressing coverage. Moreover, this case depicts a Stage 3 ulcer as fat is showing.
✅ Stage 3 → operative debridement, moist dressings, and consider skin grafting:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Stage 3 → bedside debridement and moist dressings:
Incorrect: While this patient does have a Stage 3 ulcer, the management of stage 3 ulcers is operative debridement and potential skin coverage with either synthetic or autologous grafts. Bedside debridement is inappropriate for Stage 3 ulcers.  
❌ Stage 4 → bedside debridement to properly stage:
Incorrect: Stage 4 ulcers involve full-thickness skin and tissue loss with exposure of bone, muscle, tendon and/ fascia. This patient’s ulcer is Stage 3. Moreover, the treatment of Stage 4 ulcers is the same as for Stage 3 ulcers – operative debridement and wound coverage.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man was brought to the emergency department by EMS for right foot pain. The patient states that he has had right foot pain for “weeks” and that it has progressively worsened. The patient is unsure whether there has been drainage from the wound, and given that it's on the underside of his right foot, he has not been able to visualize it. He has no pain in his legs or feet when walking. He has a history of substance use disorder. He is currently experiencing homelessness. He does not have access to healthcare or medication, but he knows that he should be on medication for one of his health conditions. Temperature is 38.5 °C (101.3 °F), pulse is 110/min, blood pressure is 105/75 mmHg, and SpO2 is 100% on room air. Physical exam of the right foot is notable for a clean-based ulcer on the bony prominence of the first toe of the right foot with surrounding induration - a probe reaches the bone. There is no lower extremity edema and pulses are intact bilaterally. Lab results are shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test to perform at this time?

No further testing as clinical exam is sufficient for diagnosis

questions.solution:
This patient presents with risk factors and a physical exam consistent with a diabetic foot ulcer. Given his fever, elevated inflammatory markers, uncontrolled diabetes mellitus (Hgb A1c > 6.5%), and probe extending to the bone, he likely has underlying osteomyelitis and an MRI of the right foot should be performed for diagnosis.

Ulceration in diabetic patients can result from neuropathy alone or a combination of neuropathy and ischemia. Diabetic ulcers commonly occur in locations that experience repeated trauma, such as the plantar metatarsal heads and dorsal interphalangeal joints. When evaluating diabetic foot ulcers, it is important to determine the extent and depth of the wound, the presence of ischemia, and the presence of infection, all of which will help determine which diagnostic studies and treatments are appropriate. Approximately 60% of diabetic foot ulcers are complicated by infection.

Osteomyelitis is a common complication of diabetic foot ulcers. Certain clinical findings should raise suspicion of osteomyelitis. These include grossly visible bone or probe-to-bone, large and deeper ulcers, and elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (70 mm/h). MRI is the diagnostic modality of choice - it is highly sensitive and specific for osteomyelitis and superior to radiographs, three-phase bone scans, and white blood cell scans.  

Option Analysis

❌ X-Ray of the right foot  :
Incorrect: Plain radiographs can detect structural foot deformities, soft tissue gas, and foreign bodies and may be able to detect osteomyelitis. However, radiologic changes in osteomyelitis typically occur late in the course of the disease, and negative radiographs do not exclude the diagnosis. MRI of the foot should be performed for diagnosis, especially in early disease.  
❌ Tagged WBC Scan:
Incorrect: A tagged WBC, also known as a tagged leukocyte scan, uses radioactive WBCs to identify areas of inflammation. Tagged WBC scans have similar sensitivity to bone scans for evaluation of osteomyelitis. However, they are time-consuming, require complex preparation, and are expensive. They are not the first-line diagnostic test for osteomyelitis, but they are sometimes useful in patients with Charcot arthropathy.  
✅ MRI of the right foot:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ CT-A of the bilateral lower extremities:
Incorrect: CT-A would be useful in cases where there is suspected arterial insufficiency. The locations of ischemic ulcers are typically in the most distal part of the toes. This patient does not have a history or physical exam findings consistent with arterial insufficiency, but instead has signs of infection and poorly controlled diabetes, making an infected diabetic ulcer the most likely diagnosis.  
❌ No further testing as clinical exam is sufficient for diagnosis:
Incorrect: This patient has systemic signs of infection and an ulcer where the probe extends to the bone, which raises suspicion of osteomyelitis. While a clinical exam is sufficient to diagnose the type of ulcer present, it is insufficient to rule out underlying osteomyelitis. MRI is required.

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman is brought to an emergency room from a nursing home due to increased agitation. The patient’s symptoms developed around 12 hours ago. The nursing staff reported that the patient saw people when no one was there. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 153/87 mmHg, and pulse is 102/min. Physical examination is unremarkable except for flushed skin. The patient is oriented to self but not to time or place. She describes seeing “scary animals” in the room. Which of the following medications could be responsible for the patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This elderly individual presents with agitation, visual hallucinations, and flushed skin. Among the answer choices listed, diphenhydramine best accounts for these symptoms. Furthermore, diphenhydramine is listed in Beers criteria, a set of guidelines to reduce polypharmacy, inappropriate drug prescriptions, and drug-related side effects in patients over 65-years-old. Examples of medications listed in Beers criteria include:  

Alpha-blockers- increased risk of orthostatic hypotension  
Anticholinergics and antihistamine- increased risk of confusion, falls, urinary retention, and constipation  
Antidepressants- causes sedation, orthostatic hypotension  
Benzodiazepines- increased risk of cognitive impairment, delirium, falls  
NSAIDs- increased risk of gastrointestinal bleeding  

Option Analysis

❌ Lisinopril:
Incorrect: Lisinopril is an ACE inhibitor and can cause side effects, including angioedema, hyperkalemia, and hypotension. However, the medication does not typically cause agitation or hallucinations in elderly patients.  
❌ Omeprazole:
Incorrect: Omeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor (PPI). The Beer criteria recommend against scheduling PPIs for more than 8-weeks in elderly individuals, given the medication can cause bone loss and increased risk of Clostridium difficile infection. However, PPIs do not typically cause agitation, hallucinations, or flushed skin in elderly patients.  
❌ Acetaminophen:
Incorrect: Acetaminophen is a relatively safe drug and would not account for the symptoms experienced by this patient.  
❌ Zoledronate:
Incorrect: Zoledronate is a bisphosphonate and is used to treat osteoporosis. The drug can cause pill esophagitis, osteonecrosis of the jaw, and atypical stress fractures. However, bisphosphonates do not typically cause agitation, hallucinations, or flushed skin in elderly patients.    
✅ Diphenhydramine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for his yearly visit. The patient states he has been well since his last visit one year ago, and he has no new medical problems. The patient has a history of hypertension for which he takes amlodipine daily. He has no other significant medical or surgical history. He has no family history of colon cancer or coronary artery disease. He drinks 1-2 alcoholic beverages a week and lives with his partner with whom he is sexually active. He does approximately 30-60 minutes of moderate exercise daily. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 127/60 mmHg, heart rate is 82 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 14 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Body mass index (BMI) is 23.7 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. The patient is well appearing, and a full physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following additional historical elements, if present, would prompt further evaluation or treatment?

choices.text: History of normal colonoscopy 6 years ago
History of laceration repair and Tdap 7 years ago

questions.solution:
This patient presents for a well-patient geriatric care visit. A core component of this annual evaluation is a comprehensive history and physical exam. Patients with a history of tobacco smoking should be further evaluated regarding the need to screen for lung cancer with chest computed tomography (CT). Low dose CT-chest imaging is indicated for patients up to age 80 years old who have a 20-pack-year smoking history and are currently smoking or have quit smoking within the last 15 years.

The well-patient geriatric care visit for adults aged 65 years and older refers to an annual check-up that promotes physical, mental, and social health while building trust between the healthcare provider and patient. At each yearly visit, patients should have a comprehensive history and physical exam performed, followed by screening and counseling about a variety of topics, including substance use, mental health, functional status, and fall risk. All patients should be asked about past medical and surgical history, family and social history, sexual activity, medications, and diet and exercise habits. The physical examination should include height, weight, body mass index, vital signs, and a comprehensive physical examination. Additional screening and counseling should be provided based on individual risks and biological sex.   

Option Analysis

✅ History of daily tobacco smoking:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ History of travel to Europe:
Incorrect: Travel history is not typically a core component of a focused history for geriatric patients presenting for well-patient visits. High-risk patients, such as those who have recently immigrated from a country with increased prevalence of tuberculosis, should have a PPD placed. Travel to Europe is not considered high-risk.
❌ History of normal colonoscopy 6 years ago:
Incorrect: Patients who are at average risk for colon cancer like this patient should have a colonoscopy performed every 10 years. This patient is not due for another colonoscopy for 4 more years.
❌ History of laceration repair and Tdap 7 years ago:
Incorrect: Tdap should be given every 10 years. This patient is not yet due for another Tdap vaccination.  
❌ History of daily caffeine consumption:
Incorrect: Geriatric patients presenting for well health visits should be asked about tobacco alcohol and other recreational substance use. However, caffeine consumption is not typically considered a risk factor that needs targeted screening and interventions.

questions.text: An 85-year-old man presents to a new primary care physician for a routine wellness examination. The patient states he has been well since his last visit several years ago, and he has no new medical issues. The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, coronary artery disease, and diabetes for which he takes amlodipine, carvedilol, aspirin, clopidogrel, and metformin daily. He has no other significant medical or surgical history. There is no family history of colon cancer. He received all childhood vaccinations, and his last vaccine was a Tdap administered 6 years ago after he cut his index finger with a kitchen knife. The patient does not drink alcohol and smoked for 5 years when he was in his 30’s. He lives with his partner and has no issues performing activities of daily living. He has no sexual concerns and no urinary incontinence. He eats a diet of lean protein, fruits, vegetables, and healthy carbohydrates. The patient does approximately 30-60 minutes of light exercise daily. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 132/70 mmHg, heart rate is 76 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 14 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Body mass index (BMI) is 25 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. The patient is well appearing, and a full physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Osteoporosis screening with dual energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) scan
Low dose computed tomography (CT) chest imaging

questions.solution:
This patient presents for a well-patient geriatric care visit. A core component of this annual evaluation is to determine the need for additional diagnostic evaluations, screenings, and immunizations based on patient age and risk factors. This patient has received childhood vaccinations and Tdap vaccination within 10 years. Given that he has never received the herpes zoster (shingles) vaccination, he should have it administered during this visit. This vaccine should be administered to all patients ≥ 50 years old.

At each well-patient geriatric visit, patients should undergo a comprehensive history and physical exam, followed by screening and counseling about a variety of topics, including recreational substance use, mental health, functional status, and fall risk. All patients should have their past medical and surgical history, family and social history, sexual activity, medications, and diet and exercise habits reviewed. Patients should have a physical examination, including height, weight, body mass index, and vital signs. These factors then help determine the need for further diagnostic screening and management. Geriatric patients may get yearly vaccinations for COVID-19, influenza, and RSV. Pneumococcal vaccination is recommended for all adults over 65 years old. Also, patients ≥ 50 who have not been vaccinated against herpes zosters (shingles) should be vaccinated. Adult patients should also receive a Tdap or Td vaccine every 10 years.

Option Analysis

✅ Herpes zoster (shingles) vaccination:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Stool-based testing for colon cancer:
Incorrect: Stool-based testing for colorectal cancer screening is not indicated for this patient given his age and average risk. This type of colorectal screening is only indicated for patients up to age 75. All adults between the ages of 45 and 75 should be screened for colorectal cancer. But in patients between the ages of 76 and 85, the decision should be made on a case-by-case basis.
❌ Tdap vaccination:
Incorrect: This patient received a Tdap vaccination within the last 10 years. Repeat vaccination is not indicated at this time.
❌ Osteoporosis screening with dual energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) scan:
Incorrect: Biological males are not routinely screened for osteoporosis; however, certain factors increase the risk of osteoporotic fractures, including long-term corticosteroid use, low BMI, active smoking, and excessive alcohol consumption. These factors are absent in this patient's history.
❌ Low dose computed tomography (CT) chest imaging:
Incorrect: Low dose CT-chest imaging is indicated for patients up to age 80 who have a 20-pack-year smoking history and are currently smoking or have quit smoking within the last 15 years. This patient's history does not meet criteria for lung cancer screening.
